(Ord. No. 456, § 1 (4), 7-1-91; Ord. No. 2011-32, § 11, 12-5-11) 
Sec. 7-220. - Landscape specifications. 
(a)  General requirements. All landscaping shall be installed in accordance with accepted and proper planting procedures. Plant material shall be Florida Number One as defined in the "Grades and Standards for Nursery Plants," Parts I and II, Florida Department of Agriculture and Consumer Services. The plants shall be native to Manatee County, drought tolerant, and appropriate to the conditions in which they are to be planted. 
(b)  Maintenance responsibility. Property owners other than owners of a single lot of record shall be responsible for the maintenance of all landscape areas in a manner that is consistent with an approved landscape plan. Any dead plant material shall be replaced with the same variety and size within ninety (90) days after its removal. Vegetation is deemed not maintained if the plant material is removed or replaced with a smaller size or a different variety, or if the material is not replaced within ninety (90) days. When vegetation is not maintained in a healthy state, it shall be subject to enforcement action by a special magistrate. 
(c)  Tree specifications. Trees planted shall be of a species that requires minimal water and maintenance and shall have a minimum height of ten (10) feet, a minimum trunk caliper of one and one-half (11/2) inches and a minimum spread of four (4) feet. Container-grown trees are preferred. 
(d)  Shrub specifications. Shrubs planted shall be container grown. 
(e)  Hedge specifications. Shrubs used for hedges shall be a minimum height of twenty-four (24) inches immediately upon planting and shall be spaced to form a continuous visual screen. 
(f)  Fence and vine specifications. Required fences shall be constructed of wood, brick, stone, block with stucco or split-face block. Chainlink fences and exposed block may not be used as a landscape screen. Vines shall be a minimum of thirty (30) inches in height at the time of planting and attach to the fence with a maximum of ten (10) feet on center. Notwithstanding the foregoing, all such fences must be constructed and maintained in conformance with the Palmetto Fence Ordinance [section 7-181 et seq.]. 
(g)  Grass. All lawn areas shall be planted with species suitable as permanent lawns in Manatee County. Effective erosion control is mandatory in swales, rights-of-way or other areas subject to erosion. In areas where grass seed is used, the seed shall be sown for immediate effect and maintenance shall be provided until coverage is complete. 
(Ord. No. 456, § 1 (5), 7-1-91; Ord. No. 07-914, § 2, 2-26-07; Ord. No. 2018-02, § 3(Exh. B), 2-26-18) 
Sec. 7-221. - Landscape plan. 
(a)  Landscape plan requirements. The landscape plan submitted under subsection 7-218(c) above shall consist of the following: 
(1)  A boundary survey and legal description sealed by a land surveyor registered in Florida. 
(2)  The location of significant drainage features, the location and size of existing and proposed buildings, utility easements, driveways, the zoning of adjacent property, streets, parking, sidewalks, existing plant communities, and similar features. 
(3)  A complete description of plant material to be utilized in the plan, the location and dimensions of the proposed landscape including quantities, container size, diameter of tree trunks, height, spread, genus and species, and spacing. Further, the plan shall include a description of existing trees to remain or to be protected and those to be removed. Notwithstanding anything herein to the contrary, the landscape plan must include the specific plant type (meaning the specific genus, species, and subspecies of the plant and not a general plant classification or list of possible plant types) and indicate the specific size, location, spacing, dimensions, and other required characteristics of proposed plantings. 
(4)  The location of all visibility triangles and any other information as may be required under the city ordinances. 
(b)  Irrigation. The applicant shall provide a detailed irrigation plan which provides one hundred (100) percent coverage for landscaped areas. The use of drip or micro-jet irrigation is encouraged. 
(Ord. No. 456, § 1 (6), 7-1-91; Ord. No. 07-914, § 3, 2-26-07) 
Sec. 7-222. - Prohibited and controlled plants. 
(a)  Prohibited species. The following species shall not be planted within the city: 
Punk Tree (Melaleuca quinquenervia) Brazilian Pepper (Schinus terebinthifolius) Australian Pine (Casuarina species) Rose Myrtle (Rhodomyrtus tomentosa)  
(b)  Controlled species. The following species may comprise a maximum of ten (10) percent of the total number of trees required under this article: 
Silk Oak (Grevillea robusta) Toog (Bischofia janvanica) Sissoo (Dalbergia sissoo)  
(Ord. No. 456, § 1 (7), 7-1-91) 
Sec. 7-223. - Tree protection. 
(a)  Protected trees. A tree having a four-inch caliper or greater shall be protected consistent with techniques set out in the Tree Protection Manual for Builders and Developers, Florida Department of Agriculture and Consumer Services, or an equivalent method. To facilitate plan review, all protected trees for a proposed development shall be physically tagged and marked with numbers corresponding to their numbering as exists on the landscape plan submitted under section 7-218(c) above. 
(b)  Exemptions. Protected trees may only be removed, replaced or relocated under the following circumstances: 
(1)  Trees grown in the course of a nursery business; or 
(2)  An emergency determined by the public works department under section 7-224. 
(Ord. No. 456, § 1 (8), 7-1-91) 
Sec. 7-224. - Permits for tree removal. 
(a)  The department of public works shall approve a permit for the removal of a protected tree in the event that an applicant demonstrates one (1) or more of the following conditions to exist: 
(1)  The tree presents a hazard to the public health, safety or welfare of inhabitants of the city; 
(2)  The tree has contracted a disease or is infested with pests destructive to such trees; 
(3)  Tree removal is necessary for construction of improvements to the property; or 
(4)  Tree removal is necessary in order to comply with other city ordinances. 
(b)  In the event tree removal is found necessary for the construction of improvements on a property, a plan shall be submitted by the permit applicant demonstrating that the replacement can be completed at a ratio of one (1) inch to one (1) inch measured at the caliper of such trees. 
(Ord. No. 456, § 1 (9), 7-1-91) 
Sec. 7-225. - Enforcement. 
    Installation of all landscaping under this article shall be completed prior to issuance of a certificate of occupancy. Such landscaping is subject to periodic inspection by code enforcement officers to ensure continuing compliance with the provisions of this article. In the event a violation of this article is discovered, the code inspector shall give written notice of the violation to the owner of the property who shall have ninety (90) days to correct the violation. Should the violation continue beyond ninety (90) days, the code inspector shall initiate a hearing before a special magistrate under chapter 2, article IV, section 2-81, et seq., of this Code of Ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 456, § 1 (10), 7-1-91; Ord. No. 2018-02, § 3(Exh. B), 2-26-18) 
Sec. 7-226. - Authority of public works superintendent to create forms, lists and other helps. 
    The superintendent of the department of public works is authorized to create such forms, lists of suggested trees, accents, shrubs, ground covers and turf grasses, and such other details necessary to carry out the provisions of this article as he deems necessary in his sole discretion. 
(Ord. No. 456, § 1 (11), 7-1-91) 
Secs. 7-227-7-236. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XI. - MINIMUM MAINTENANCE STANDARDS AND GUIDELINES[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 470, adopted Dec. 16, 1991, amended Ch. 7 by adding the provisions set out above but did not provide the exact manner of their inclusion. Therefore, their codification as a new Art. XI, §§ 7-237-7-249 has been at the editor's discretion. 

Sec. 7-237. - Building front, side and rear walls abutting streets or public areas. 
(a)  Requirements: 
(1)  All deteriorated or damaged structural and decorative elements visible from a public right-of-way, including signage, shall be repaired or replaced to match as closely as possible the existing or original materials and construction of the building, except that changes shall be permitted that are otherwise required or encouraged under this article. 
(2)  Every such part of a structure visible from a public right-of-way or abutting a street shall be kept structurally sound. Rotten or weakened portions shall be removed, repaired or replaced in such a manner as to be compatible with the rest of the structure or to match the original materials and construction methods. All exposed wood shall be stained or painted. Every such part shall be free of graffiti, litter, dirt, mildew or other debris. Where surfaces are painted, once painted or normally painted, not more than ten (10) percent of such surface may be without paint. Painted surfaces must be maintained without peeling or chalking. 
(3)  Walls shall be repaired and painted to present a neat and clean appearance. Side walls where visible from the street shall be finished or painted in a manner harmonious with the front of the building. 
(4)  Existing miscellaneous nonfunctional elements on the buildings, such as empty electrical conduit, unused sign brackets, etc., shall be removed and the building surface repaired or rebuilt to match adjacent surfaces and original or former condition. Wires and conduit shall be secured and located in an inconspicuous manner. 
(b)  Recommendations: 
(1)  Architectural details, window frames, sashes, door frames and doors should be painted, generally a lighter shade than the wall color, or accented by a vivid color that is harmonious with the wall color. 
(2)  The original appearance is in most cases the most desirable for buildings. Veneers such as metal, wood, brick or stone often hide original and interesting details of an older building. When possible, removal of veneers and the repair, restoration or replacement of the original material (brick, stucco, wood, etc.) is encouraged. 
(Ord. No. 470, § 1, 12-16-91) 
Sec. 7-238. - Windows. 
(a)  Requirements: 
(1)  Every broken or missing window or window glass shall be repaired or replaced. New windows shall closely resemble the building's other existing windows. 
(2)  All windows must be tight-fitting and have sashes of proper size and design. Sashes with rotten wood, broken joints or loose mullions or muntins shall be repaired or replaced with a similar design and material. 
(3)  Window openings in the building shall not be boarded or filled except as provided for under chapter 7 of the code. Window panes or glass shall not be painted. When repair or replacement is undertaken, windows capable of being open and closed shall not be substituted with fixed, single-sheet glass. 
(4)  All windows shall be kept clean and transparent and the visible interior neat and clean. Any interior screening, including curtains, drapes and blinds, must be kept in good repair and appearance. Reflective glass is not permitted for any windows, except to the extent expressly recommended herein. 
(b)  Recommendations: 
(1)  Storefront windows are a very important part of creating a rhythm of building openings, as well as offering the pedestrian an inviting view of the display area within the building. The use of clear glass on the first floor will encourage visibility. 
(2)  Slightly tinted or "filmed" glass with a minimum of fifty (50) percent light transmission may be used above the first story. 
(3)  Storefront windows should remain the same size as the original openings. Remodeled windows should be as large as possible and allow room for a bulkhead at the ground level. Original transom heights should be maintained. Windows having aluminum trim, mullions or muntins not consistent or compatible with the overall facade design should be replaced or the trim painted. 
(4)  Display windows and platforms, entrance areas, signs, transoms, lighting, sun protection, awnings, porches, security grills, and other exterior features should be compatible and harmonious with the original scale and character of the structure. All display window elements should utilize their original dimension. 
(Ord. No. 470, § 2, 12-16-91) 
Sec. 7-239. - Awnings. 
(a)  Requirements: 
(1)  Soft, retractable, flame-proof awnings are permitted over the first floor and upper floor windows. They shall not project more than seven (7) feet from the building front, shall not be lower than seven (7) feet above grade, and shall terminate against the building at a height not to exceed fourteen (14) feet above grade. 
(2)  Rigid or fixed awnings or canopies are permitted if they are an original or integral part of the structure, are compatible and harmonious with the scale and character of the structure and adjacent structures, and pose no unreasonable visual impediment to adjacent buildings. New rigid or fixed awnings or canopies may be added to existing structures subject to restrictions outlined above. 
(3)  Awnings that are torn, badly faded or structurally compromised shall be repaired or replaced. 
(b)  Recommendations: 
(1)  Awnings are among the most important features in the total appearance of a building; the location, size and color must be carefully chosen. 
(2)  For the first floor awnings, the highest point should not be higher than the midpoint between the storefront windows and the second-story window sills. They should not cover or unreasonably interfere with any original architectural features of the building. 
(3)  The color and design of the awning should be compatible with the color and design of the building. It is recommended that the name of the store be placed within the valance area of the awning. 
(Ord. No. 470, § 3, 12-16-91) 
Sec. 7-240. - Requirements for roofs. 
(a)  Rooftop structures. Chimneys and all other rooftop structures shall be repaired and maintained in the same manner as required for the rear and side walls. Any part of the building visible from the street or from other buildings shall be finished so as to be harmonious with other visible building walls. Television and radio antennas, pipes, duct work and mechanical equipment, such as air conditioning units and auxiliary enclosures or sheds, shall be erected in an inconspicuous manner. 
(b)  Roofs, gutters and downspouts. All roofs and existing gutters and downspouts shall be maintained to prevent damage to the structure and adjoining properties and the public. Leaking roofs shall be repaired or replaced. 
(Ord. No. 470, § 4, 12-16-91) 
Sec. 7-241. - Requirements for trash and receptacle areas. 
    There shall be no trash placed upon sidewalks or other areas open to the public except on those days when such trash is to be picked up by the city. All private trash receptacle areas shall be screened from the view of the public right-of-way, except where trash receptacle placement is authorized in alleyways. Such areas shall be kept neat and clean in appearance. 
(Ord. No. 470, § 5, 12-16-91) 
Sec. 7-242. - Requirements for auxiliary structures. 
(a)  Structures, fences, walls, etc. Structures at the rear of buildings, whether attached or unattached to the principal commercial structure, which are structurally unsound shall be properly repaired or demolished. All fences, lighting devices and supports, retaining walls, nonstructural walls, outdoor service and seating areas, signs and their supporting elements shall be structurally sound, kept free of overgrowth, trash and debris and shall be repaired and painted to present a neat and clean appearance. 
(b)  No more than three (3) vending machines, including refrigerated vending or storage machines but not including newsracks, may be located outside any one business premises within the city and shall be placed immediately adjacent to such premises. Vending machines that exceed three (3) in number shall be kept and maintained inside such premises. 
(c)  All auxiliary and other structures including but not limited to buildings, fences, gates, nonstructural walls, retaining walls, fountains, parking areas, lighting devices and supports, outdoor service and seating areas, signs and their supporting elements, which are out-of-doors and exposed to the general public, shall be kept free of graffiti as defined herein. 
(Ord. No. 470, § 6, 12-16-91; Ord. No. 480, § 1, 8-3-92; Ord. No. 578, § 2, 6-16-97) 
Sec. 7-243. - Requirements for sites. 
(a)  Landscaping. All areas (front, side and rear yards) shall be kept free of overgrowth, weeds, trash and debris. All dead tree limbs and dead trees shall be removed. 
(b)  Vacant lots. Where a vacant lot exists or is created through demolition, the owner must cover all areas not actively used for parking or loading with grass or other such ground cover. Such ground cover shall be maintained and the property kept free of trash and debris. 
(c)  Parking lots. All parking areas shall be constructed as provided in the city zoning code. Parking areas shall be well maintained and kept free of overgrowth, potholes, weeds, trash and debris. Paving and striping will be maintained in good repair and in a neat and clean appearance. 
(d)  All natural features of a property including but not limited to rocks, trees and landscaping shall be kept free of graffiti as defined herein. 
(Ord. No. 470, § 7, 12-16-91; Ord. No. 578, § 3, 6-16-97) 
Sec. 7-244. - Requirements for temporary coverings. 
    No temporary covering, including, but not limited to, a board covering a broken or missing window, on any part of a structure may remain more than fifteen (15) days after on-going construction has been completed or sixty (60) days total, whichever is longer. 
(Ord. No. 470, § 8, 12-16-91) 
Sec. 7-245. - Applicability. 
    The minimum maintenance standards and guidelines shall be applicable to all unimproved and improved properties, both residential and nonresidential, within the geographic boundaries of the city. The minimum maintenance standards and guidelines shall be in addition to any other standards, codes, ordinances, rules, regulations or other statutory requirements applicable to such properties. 
(Ord. No. 470, § 9, 12-16-91; Ord. No. 05-836, § 2, 1-24-05) 
Sec. 7-246. - Enforcement. 
    The minimum maintenance standards and guidelines shall be enforced pursuant to the provisions of chapter 2, article IV, section 2-81 through 2-90, inclusive, of this Code of Ordinances relating to special magistrates. The mayor shall designate the employee(s) to serve as the minimum maintenance standards official for purposes of enforcing compliance with these minimum maintenance standards. Such designated employee(s) shall assist property owners in an effort to achieve an understanding of and compliance with the minimum maintenance standards and guidelines. 
(Ord. No. 470, § 10, 12-16-91; Ord. No. 2018-02, § 3(Exh. B), 2-26-18) 
Sec. 7-247. - Correction of noncompliance. 
    Upon receipt of written notification from the minimum maintenance standards official of noncompliance with the minimum maintenance standards and guidelines, a property owner or his representative shall have ten (10) days to commence application for a certificate of review for approval of proposed correction of the cited deficiency. No building permit for the correction of a deficiency shall be issued until a certificate of review has been issued and approved by the minimum maintenance standards official. A failure to secure a certificate of review in any instance, including those in which no building permit is required, shall constitute a violation of this article, enforceable by a special magistrate. 
(Ord. No. 470, § 11, 12-16-91; Ord. No. 2018-02, § 3(Exh. B), 2-26-18) 
Sec. 7-248. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2015-15, § 2.A.11., adopted on Sept. 14, 2015, repealed § 7-248 in its entirety. Former § 7-248 pertained to downtown design review and derived from Ord. No. 470, § 12, adopted Dec. 16, 1991. 
Sec. 7-249. - Variances. 
    The special magistrates may authorize such exemptions or variances from the provisions of this article as will not be contrary to the public interest where, owing to special conditions, a literal enforcement of the provisions of this article would likely result in an unreasonable hardship to the landowner. In granting such an exemption or variance, the special magistrates may prescribe alternate reasonable requirements that are in furtherance of and in conformity with this Code. Violation of such alternate requirements when made a part of the terms under which a variance is granted shall be deemed a violation of this article and enforceable as provided by chapter 2, article IV of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 470, § 13, 12-16-91; Ord. No. 2018-02, § 3(Exh. B), 2-26-18) 
Sec. 7-250. - Prohibition on possession of spray paint and markers by minors. 
(a)  Possession on public property prohibited. No person under the age of eighteen (18) shall have in his or her possession any aerosol container of spray paint or broad tipped indelible marker while on any public property, highway, street, alley or way except in the company of a supervising adult. 
(b)  Possession on private property prohibited without consent of owner. No person under the age of eighteen (18) shall have in his or her possession any aerosol container of spray paint or broad tipped indelible marker while on any private property unless the owner, agent, manager or person in possession of the property knows of the minor's possession of the aerosol container or marker and has consented to the minor's possession while on his or her property. 
(Ord. No. 578, § 4, 6-16-97) 
Sec. 7-251. - Prohibition of graffiti. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to deface, destroy or otherwise damage private or public, real or personal property by or through the application or placement thereon of graffiti as defined herein. 
(Ord. No. 578, § 5, 6-16-97) 
Sec. 7-252. - Removal of graffiti. 
(a)  The city shall notify the owner, lessee or agent for the owner of property of the existence of graffiti and shall provide seven (7) days for the owner, lessee or agent to remove or effectively obscure such graffiti as set forth in section 7-253 below. It shall be a violation of this article for any owner, lessee, or agent for the owner of property to fail to remove, cause the removal of or effectively obscure any graffiti from such property, or to fail or refuse to allow the city to so remove any graffiti, after receipt of notice from the city for such removal as provided in section 7-253. 
(b)  If the owner, lessee or agent for the owner of property fails to remove, cause the removal of or effectively obscure the graffiti in a timely manner, the city may cause the graffiti to be removed or effectively obscured. The city, in painting or obscuring the graffiti, shall not faint any more extensive area than the area where the graffiti is located. The city shall not be required to restore the obscured area to its original condition (i.e. texture and color, etc.) It is the city's intent to utilize white paint for this purpose. If an alternative color of paint is provided by the property owner, the city may utilize the provided color paint to obscure the area of the graffiti. The city shall not be responsible for storage of any paint provided by a property owner. 
(Ord. No. 578, § 6, 6-16-97) 
Sec. 7-253. - Notice. 
(a)  When the city becomes aware of the existence of graffiti on property within the city, the city shall give, or cause to be given, written notice to the property owner, lessee and/or owner's agent to remove, cause the removal of or effectively obscure such graffiti or authorize the city to so remove as provided in section 7-252, within seven (7) days of receipt of notice as provided herein. 
(b)  Notice shall be given to the owner and if the owner is not in possession of the property, notice may also be given to the occupant or person in possession of the premises described in the notice. The notice may be personally delivered or deposited in the U.S. Mail, postage pre-paid addressed to the person or persons designated as the owner in the records of the property appraiser for Manatee County, or if no address is known, then to general delivery, and a copy of such notice shall be posted in a conspicuous place upon the property. The validity of the city's actions or any proceedings shall in no way be affected by the failure on the part of any property owner to actually receive said notice provided that the person mailing or posting such notice files an affidavit of mailing or posting. 
(Ord. No. 578, § 7, 6-16-97) 
Sec. 7-254. - Enforcement. 
    This article may be enforced as provided by general law and city ordinance including but not limited to enforcement by a special magistrate or through a duly adopted citation procedure, as same may be amended from time to time. In addition to establishing a penalty for a violation, a special magistrate is empowered to order a violator to repay the city for any costs incurred resulting from the city's removal of said graffiti. Penalties imposed by the special magistrate shall be separate and distinct from any costs incurred by the city resulting from the city's removal of said graffiti. Alternatively, or as a supplemental enforcement process, the city may obtain compliance through suit in a court of competent jurisdiction to recover all expenses, including but not limited to all administrative personnel costs, attorney's fees and costs relating to enforcing this article. 
(Ord. No. 578, § 8, 6-16-97; Ord. No. 2018-02, § 3(Exh. B), 2-26-18) 
Sec. 7-255. - Exemption. 
    This article shall not be construed to prohibit temporary, easily removable chalk or other water soluble markings on public or private sidewalks, streets, or other paved surfaces which are used in connection with traditional children's activities such as drawing or bases for stick ball, kick ball or hand ball, hopscotch and the like nor temporary, easily removable chalk or other water soluble markings used in connection with any lawful business or public purpose or activity. 
(Ord. No. 578, § 9, 6-16-97) 
Sec. 7-256. - Penalty. 
    Any person convicted of a violation of this article shall be punished as provided by law. Where a minor is found to have violated section 7-251, any fine or other applicable penalty imposed by this section shall be assessed against the minor and such minor's parents or legal guardian as provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 578, § 4, 6-16-97) 
Sec. 7-257. - Restitution. 
    In addition to any penalty for violation as may be assessed by a court of competent jurisdiction, the court shall order the person convicted of a violation hereof to make restitution to the victim for the damage or loss caused directly or indirectly by that convicted person's offense in a reasonable amount or manner to be determined by the court. Where the convicted person is a minor, the court may also order the parent or legal guardian of such minor to make such restitution. 
(Ord. No. 578, § 11, 6-16-97) 
Chapter 9 - CEMETERIES[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2015-03, §§ 2, 3, adopted May 4, 2015, repealed Ch. 9 in its entirety and enacted a new Ch. 9 to read as set out herein. Former Ch. 9, §§ 9-1-9-8, pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 267, § 2, adopted May 19, 1986; Ord. No. 06-893, § 2, adopted Aug. 7, 2006; and Ord. No. 07-919, § 2, adopted June 19, 2007. 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2; alcoholic beverages prohibited in the cemetery and area adjacent thereto, § 4-3; streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 25. 

Sec. 9-1. - Definitions. 
    These terms shall have the following meanings in this chapter, unless the context otherwise requires: 
    Burial permit means the permit issued by the city that provides permission for interment of the person in the specific block, lot, and space in the cemetery. 
    Burial right certificate means the certificate issued by the city showing proof of ownership for a specific block, lot, and space in the cemetery. Burial right certificates have been issued by the city starting in the year 2006. 
    Casket vault means the underground, outermost burial chamber or tomb, excluding a wood enclosure, and includes, but is not limited to, vaults made of concrete, steel, fiberglass, or copper, in which a single casket holding one (1) deceased person, or one (1) parent and one (1) infant, is placed. The container must be capable of sustaining a static load of four thousand five hundred (4,500) pounds per square inch. 
    Cemeteries means the two (2) cemeteries owned and maintained by the City of Palmetto: 
(1)  Yellow Fever Cemetery, located at 510 14th Avenue West (5th Street West and 14th Avenue West), Palmetto, Florida. No new burials take place in this historic cemetery. 
(2)  Palmetto Cemetery, located at 900 14th Avenue West (14th Avenue West between 8th and 10th Streets), Palmetto, Florida. The city issues burial right certificates for this cemetery only. 
    Deed means the document issued by the city prior to 2006 showing proof of ownership of a specific block, lot, and space in the cemetery. 
    Gravesite means the location of interment. 
    Owner means the purchaser of a burial space of the person lawfully entitled to designate who may be buried in such space, in accordance with the provision of this section and state property and inheritance law. 
    Space means the smallest subdivided part of the cemetery that may be purchased. A municipal cemetery is divided into blocks, lots, and spaces. The blocks are subdivided into four (4) lots, and the lots are subdivided into eight (8) spaces. 
    Transfer means a conveyance or assignment of ownership of a space. The conveyance or assignment changes the actual owner of the space and entitles that person to designate who may be buried in the transferred space. 
    Urn vault means the underground, outermost burial chamber or tomb in which one (1) deceased persons cremains are interred either via urn or scattered inside. 
(Ord. No. 2015-03, § 3, 5-4-15) 
Sec. 9-2. - Same-Required. 
    All ground interments in the Palmetto Cemetery require the use of a vault. 
(Ord. No. 2015-03, § 3, 5-4-15) 
Sec. 9-3. - Management and supervision. 
    The responsibility for the management, operation, maintenance, and general supervision of the grounds of the municipal cemeteries shall be vested in the city's parks and recreation department. 
(Ord. No. 2015-03, § 3, 5-4-15) 
Sec. 9-4. - Purchase and transfer of spaces. 
(a)  Records of ownership. The city clerk or designee shall keep full and complete records of the ownership of all spaces in the municipal cemeteries, which shall include the burial capacity of each space, the location of each gravesite (block, lot, and space number), names and ages, if ages are available, of persons buried in each gravesite, and the date of the burial. 
(b)  Prices and fees. Spaces within the municipal cemeteries may be purchased at the office of the city clerk. Payment for a space shall be subject to payment of fees, as set forth in the cemetery fee schedule published in the supplemental rules and procedures, as may be amended from time to time, which will be kept in the office of the city clerk. 
(c)  Method of purchase. Fees must be paid in full at the time of purchase or transfer of space(s). There shall be no discrimination in the sale of spaces based upon race, religion, or national origin. 
(d)  Purchase by burial right certificate. Any individual wishing to purchase a space within the Palmetto Cemetery shall come to the office of the city clerk. Any available spaces at the Palmetto Cemetery in the city's inventory shall be available for purchase. All fees must be paid at the time of the sale of the space(s). The city clerk, or designee, will then issue a burial right certificate to the purchaser identifying the owner's name, address, and the block, lot and space(s) purchased. The mayor shall execute the burial right certificate, attested to by the city clerk. 
(e)  Transfer by burial right certificate. Transfer of burial spaces owned by the city or one (1) holding a burial right certificate shall be by burial right certificate. No owner of a cemetery space shall transfer the space or any rights therein to a person other than the city without first allowing the city clerk or designee to review the instrument for such transfer and providing reliable evidence of the owner's right to make such transfer. Upon confirmation of burial right ownership, the city clerk or designee will issue a burial right certificate transferring ownership and accordingly adjust city records. A transfer fee, as provided in the cemetery fee schedule, shall be payable at the time of transfer. 
(f)  Transfer of ownership by deed. In addition to the requirement as set forth in subsection (e), above, the city clerk or designee shall verify ownership, wherein the original transfer to the owner was made by deed and no transfer of the deed to the city has been made subsequent thereto, only after the person transferring ownership provides reliable evidence that the transferor has (or the transferors have) good and sole title to the burial space. The city clerk or designee shall consider all reliable evidence provided by other claimants as to the title of the burial space prior to providing written verification of ownership. 
(g)  Transfer of ownership by deed without warranty. Written review and verification by the city clerk or designee, the mayor, or the city, in general, of a transfer of ownership by deed under this section shall not act to warrant that good title exists in the transferee. The transferee shall agree to indemnify and hold the city harmless against any claims and costs that may arise from disputes over title in the transferred burial space(s). 
(h)  Repurchases by the city. Upon request by the owner of a space, the city may repurchase a space for the purchase price then in effect for the purchase of a space, as reflected in the cemetery fee schedule in place at the time of the repurchase. 
(i)  City exemption. No transfer fees shall be imposed on repurchase of burial spaces by the city. 
(Ord. No. 2015-03, § 3, 5-4-15) 
Sec. 9-5. - Presumption of abandonment-Unused burial spaces. 
(a)  There is hereby created a presumption that burial rights in any city cemetery as defined in this chapter have been abandoned when an owner of unused burial rights has failed to provide the city with a current residence address for a period of fifty (50) consecutive years and the city is unable to communicate by certified letter with said owner of unused burial rights for lack of address. 
(b)  Upon the occurrence of a presumption of abandonment as set forth in subsection (a), the city will first send a letter to the last known address if available and if no address is available and/or no response to the city's letter is received, the city shall file a notice in a daily newspaper of general circulation in the city. The notice shall do the following: 
(1)  Describe the burial rights certified to have been abandoned; 
(2)  Set forth the name of the owner or owners of the burial rights, or if the owner is known to the cemetery to be deceased, then the names, if known to the city, of such claimants as are heirs at law, next of kin, or specific devisees under the will of the owner; 
(3)  Detail the facts with respect to the failure of the owner or survivors as outlined in this section to keep the city informed of the owner's address for a period of fifty (50) consecutive years or more. 
(c)  The notice shall run two (2) times in a consecutive two-week period. After one hundred twenty (120) days from the final notice and publication, the city shall have the right to sell such burial rights. 
(Ord. No. 2015-03, § 3, 5-4-15) 
Sec. 9-6. - Rules for interment. 
(a)  No person shall be interred in a municipal cemetery unless the city clerk or designee has issued a burial permit. 
(b)  The city clerk or designee shall issue a burial permit when the following conditions are met: 
(1)  The space in which the burial is to be made has been fully paid for. 
(2)  The person for whom such burial is being arranged has the right to the use of such space. The city clerk's office shall require proof of a consent in writing, signed by the owner of the burial space, to verify that the owner has consented to the burial. If a signed consent is unavailable or in dispute, the city clerk or designee shall have sole discretion to determine who has the right to the use of the burial space; provided that such determination is based on at least the written consent of the following (in the following order of priority, where each successive subparagraph requires, as a condition precedent, the unavailability of all persons mentioned in the preceding subparagraph): 
a.  Any and all owners who can be reasonably located; 
b.  Any and all persons designated as a devisee, or a contingent or actual beneficiary as provided in the owners' legally executed wills or trusts, who are to receive ownership of the burial space upon the owners' deaths; 
c.  The spouse of the owner or spouses of the owners; 
d.  The lineal descendants of all owners, beginning with the children, then if no children can be reasonably located, to the grandchildren, then if no grandchildren can be reasonably located, to the great-grandchildren, and then if no great-grandchildren can be reasonably located, then to any other remote, directly lineal descendants; 
e.  The lineal antecedents of all owners, beginning with the parents, then if no parents can be reasonably located, to the grandparents, and then if no grandparents can be reasonably located, to any other remote, directly lineal antecedents; or 
f.  Any living family member of the owner(s) who is the sibling(s) of the owner(s) or, if unavailable, who is borne from or adopted by the sibling(s) of the owner(s); 
g.  If none of this criteria can be met, a notice must be made in a newspaper of general circulation in the city. The notice must run two (2) times in a consecutive two-week period. It must describe the location of the burial space, the name of the purported owner(s) of the burial space, and must contain information as to how to contact the Palmetto City Clerk's office. 
(3)  The space is not used beyond its capacity. A maximum of six (6) urn vaults, or one (1) burial vault and urn vaults, or one (1) burial vault in one (1) space shall be permitted. Each additional interment of more than one (1) burial will be charged a separate interment fee as listed on the cemetery fee schedule. 
(4)  The city has received reliable documentation indicating that the interment will be supervised by a funeral director who is licensed in the State of Florida for a casket burial or by a vault company who is licensed in the State of Florida for a cremain burial. 
(c)  Prior to interment, a staking fee shall be paid in accordance with the cemetery fee schedule, as amended from time to time. 
(d)  Except when religious tenets preclude it or other extenuating circumstances are present as determined in the sole judgment of the city, a minimum of forty-eight (48) hours' notice shall be required prior to any interment. The city shall then locate and stake the space to be used. 
(e)  The funeral director, or vault company director in the case of a cremain burial, shall be responsible for completing and signing the certificate of compliance that is located in the supplemental rules and procedures provided by the city clerk's office. 
(f)  The city shall not be made responsible for the removal of remains of others in contravention of this section or state and federal law. 
(Ord. No. 2015-03, § 3, 5-4-15) 
Sec. 9-7. - Supplemental rules and procedures. 
(a)  Supplemental rules and procedures regarding the management, operation, and the use of spaces in the municipal cemeteries may be recommended and approved by the mayor. A current copy of all supplemental rules shall be maintained on file in the offices of the parks and recreation department and the city clerk. Such rules shall not be inconsistent with the following: 
(1)  Spaces owned by or assigned to parties other than the city shall not be resold by the city without prior written consent of the owner or assignee, or a party lawfully entitled to convey the owner's or assignee's interest in the space; 
(2)  No disinterment of a body or relocation of cremains within the same municipal cemetery shall occur without the written approval of the owner of the space(s) involved and the city clerk or designee. All other disinterment shall be by order of the court of a competent jurisdiction or permission from a person having authority to permit same; and 
(3)  No new burial spaces shall be created without the approval of the city commission. 
(b)  Financial records. The office of the city clerk shall make available all financial records pertaining to the municipal cemeteries at reasonable time for examination by the Florida Department of Financial Services. 
(c)  Consumer complaints. The city shall follow the procedures set forth in F.S. § 497.260 for consumer complaints involving a municipal cemetery in excess of five (5) acres. The city shall prepare and implement its own procedures for consumer complaints for a municipal cemetery five (5) acres or less. 
(d)  State reporting requirements. The city clerk shall maintain all reporting requirements under F.S. § 497.287, including payment of all applicable fees set forth therein and five-year filing of the exempt-cemetery application. 
(e)  State regulations. The city shall comply with other regulations set forth in F.S. Ch. 497, and other applicable state laws and regulations. 
(Ord. No. 2015-03, § 3, 5-4-15) 
Sec. 9-8. - Variance. 
    Any person affected by the implementation of this chapter may request a hearing before the city commission. Such hearing shall determine whether strict application of this section unduly burdens, or creates an undue hardship on, the petitioner. All decisions under this chapter shall be uniformly applied to similarly situated individuals under similar circumstances. 
(Ord. No. 2015-03, § 3, 5-4-15) 
Chapter 10 - COASTAL AREAS AND WATERWAYS[1] 
Footnotes:

Ch. 327; local regulation of boats, F.S. § 327.60; saltwater fishing regulation, preemption to state, F.S. § 370.102; seawalls and bulkheads, F.S. § 403.91 et seq.; freshwater fishing regulation preempted to the state, Fla. Const., Art. IV, § 9. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 10-1-10-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SEAWALLS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 7. 
State Law reference- Seawalls construction, F.S. § 403.918. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 10-26. - Ownership. 
    The seawalls, retaining walls and bulkheads for which a permit has been approved in accordance with the provisions of this article and whose construction has been inspected by the city building inspector shall remain the property of the owner cited in the application for such permit, his heirs and assigns, who will be solely responsible for maintenance and repair of the structures. 
(Code 1975, § 7-69) 
Sec. 10-27. - Repair and maintenance. 
    Should the failure or collapse of any seawall, retaining wall or bulkhead, in the opinion of the city or other governmental agency having jurisdiction in such matters, endanger navigation or abutting properties, the owner will be notified in writing. Upon receipt of such written notice, the owner shall, at his expense, take remedial action to repair and restore the structure to relieve the above-described condition. 
(Code 1975, § 7-70) 
Sec. 10-28. - Bulkhead line-Generally. 
(a)  The map prepared by Pullara, Bowen & Watson, Engineers, showing the proposed bulkhead line of the city, is hereby adopted and made a part of this section and is on file in the city clerk's office. 
(b)  The legal description of the proposed bulkhead line of the city prepared by Pullara, Bowen & Watson, Engineers, is hereby adopted and made a part of this section and is on file in the city clerk's office. 
(c)  The proposed bulkhead line adopted in this section is hereby declared to be the bulkhead line of the city under the provision of the power and authority given to the city to establish its bulkhead line. 
(Code 1975, § 7-71) 
Sec. 10-29. - Same-Terra Ceia Bay. 
(a)  The map prepared by Pullara, Bowen & Watson, Engineers, showing the proposed bulkhead for the property within the city limits bordering Terra Ceia Bay, fronting U.S. Lot 3, Section 9 and U.S. Lot 3, Section 16, all in Township 34 South, Range 17 East, is hereby adopted and made a part of this section and is on file in the city clerk's office. 
(b)  The legal description of the proposed bulkhead line of the city for the property within its limits bordering Terra Ceia Bay set forth as follows, is hereby adopted: 
Commence at the southeast corner of U.S. Government Lot 3, Section 9, Township 34 South, Range 17 East (southeast corner of Section 9, Township 34 South, Range 17 East); run thence north 0° 10' 00? west 728 feet to the northeast corner of said U.S. Government Lot 3; thence west 940.13 feet to the point of beginning of proposed bulkhead line; run thence south 61° 22' 00? west 623.22 feet; thence south 0° 10' 00? east 1751.52 feet to the westerly extension of the north boundary of the southeast one-quarter of the northeast one-quarter of Section 16, Township 34 South, Range 17 East, at a point 164 feet west of the northwest corner of the southeast one-quarter of the northeast one-quarter of said Section 16. 
(c)  The proposed bulkhead line set out in this section is hereby declared to be the bulkhead line of the city for the property bordering Terra Ceia Bay, under the provisions of the power and authority given to the city to establish its bulkhead line. 
(Code 1975, § 7-72) 
Sec. 10-30. - Standards. 
    All seawalls within this city shall conform to the applicable graphic standards as adopted by the city council according to the ultimate usage of the seawall, including length, height, thickness, and exposure. The graphic standards adopted by the city council are identified as follows: 
(1)  Standard I. Twelve-Foot Seawall For Protected Areas, dated 6, November, 1972, prepared by Benson Associates, Consulting Engineers. 
(2)  Standard II. Ten-Foot Seawall For Protected Areas, dated 6, November, 1972, prepared by Benson Associates, Consulting Engineers. 
(3)  Standard III. Eight-Foot Seawall For Protected Areas, dated 6, November, 1972, prepared by Benson Associates, Consulting Engineers. 
(4)  Standard IV. Twelve-Foot Seawall For Exposed Areas, dated 6, November, 1972, prepared by Benson Associates, Consulting Engineers. 
(Code 1975, § 7-73) 
Secs. 10-31-10-45. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Seawall construction, dredge and fill permits, F.S. § 403.91 et seq.; local participation in permitting process, F.S. § 403.916; criteria for granting or denying permits, F.S. § 403.918 et seq. 

Sec. 10-46. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to construct, alter, repair, remove or demolish any seawall, retaining wall or bulkhead until an application for a permit therefor has been filed, payment of the prescribed fees has been made, and a permit for such work issued pursuant to the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1975, § 7-82) 
Sec. 10-47. - Application and fee. 
(a)  Application for a permit as required by this division shall be submitted to the city building inspector together with detailed plans and specifications for each structure, and such other information, including soil data, as may be reasonably required by the building inspector. 
(b)  The application shall be signed by the applicant, reciting the full name, residence or business address of the owner; the address or location of the premises upon which the structure is to be erected, altered, repaired or removed; the cost of the proposed work; and the name of the contractor or other person or firm authorized by the owner to perform the contemplated work. All plans and specifications for seawalls, retaining walls or bulkheads shall be approved by the city engineer. 
(c)  Each application shall be accompanied by: 
(1)  A permit fee of ten dollars ($10.00) plus ten cents ($0.10) per linear foot of the seawall, retaining wall or bulkhead. 
(2)  Three (3) sets of drawings and specifications. 
(Code 1975, § 7-83) 
Sec. 10-48. - Conditions for issuance. 
    The building inspector shall, after submission to him of an application for a permit required by the provisions of this division, examine and analyze the application including the attached plans and specifications. Upon determination that the contemplated work meets the requirements of this article and has the approval of the city engineer, the inspector shall issue a permit to perform such work, subject to such reasonable schedule of inspections, final approval and conditions as the building inspector shall deem necessary. 
(Code 1975, § 7-84) 
Sec. 10-49. - Display. 
    The permit issued under the provisions of this division shall be prominently posted in close proximity to the work allowed by such permit during the progress of the work. 
(Code 1975, § 7-85) 
Sec. 10-50. - Excavations. 
(a)  The permit issued under the provisions of this division applies solely to the construction, repair, alteration, removal or demolition of the seawall, retaining wall or bulkhead structure, and is not a permit to excavate, dredge or fill any area adjacent to or removed from the site of such construction even though the drawings and specifications indicate that excavation, dredging and filling is contemplated. 
(b)  Such contemplated excavation, dredging and filling shall be made the subject of a separate application. 
(c)  If a permit to excavate or dredge and fill is granted by the city or other governmental agency having jurisdiction over such matters, no excavation or dredging of the natural undisturbed bottom will be permitted within twenty-five (25) feet of the outboard or water face of the seawall, retaining wall or bulkhead unless expressly authorized in writing by the building inspector. 
(Code 1975, § 7-86) 
Sec. 10-51. - Duration. 
    All approvals of applications and permits issued under the provisions of this division shall expire six (6) months after the date of issuance, unless the work has been started and has been carried out with reasonable diligence and continuity but in no event longer than two (2) years from the date of original approval and issuance. 
(Code 1975, § 7-87) 
Secs. 10-52-10-75. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - BOATS 

Sec. 10-76. - Reckless operation prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a motorboat or other vessel in a reckless or negligent manner so as to endanger the life, limb or property of any person upon or in any waters within the city. 
(b)  The provisions of this section shall not apply to regularly supervised or sponsored motorboat races. 
(Code 1975, § 17-3) 
State Law reference- Reckless or careless operation of vessel, F.S. § 327.33. 
Sec. 10-77. - Speed regulated. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a motorboat or other vessel upon or in the waters of the Manatee River within the city at a speed greater than four (4) miles an hour within four hundred (400) feet of the municipal pier. 
(b)  The provisions of this section shall not apply to regularly supervised or sponsored motorboat races. 
(Code 1975, § 17-4) 
Sec. 10-78. - Obstruction of city boat ramp. 
(a)  No person shall by using any commercial boat or vessel, work boat or vessel, or any other boat or vessel, obstruct the use of the boat ramp owned by the city, which is located south of Riverside Drive between Eighth Avenue and Ninth Avenue. 
(b)  No boat, including commercial boats, work boats, vessels, or pleasure boats, shall tie to the dock for more than two (2) hours. This provision shall not apply to emergency situations or to the dockage of law enforcement agency watercraft. 
(Code 1975, § 17-4.1) 
Secs. 10-79-10-95. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - FISHING[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Saltwater fishing regulation, preempted by the state, F.S. § 370.102; freshwater fishing regulation preemption by the state, Fla. Const., Art. IV, § 9; fishing in certain bodies of water in Palmetto, Laws of Fla., Ch. 67-1883. 

Sec. 10-96. - Net spreads and driers, fish storage facilities restricted. 
    No person shall build, erect, maintain or cause to be built, erected or maintained any net spreads, net driers, or wharf with building for storage of fish or other seafoods, at any place on the Manatee River or over the Manatee River from a point where the city limits intersects the Manatee River on the east to a point where Palmetto Street would intersect the Manatee River if same were extended along its present lines in a western direction. 
(Code 1975, § 17-8) 
Sec. 10-97. - Fishing restricted in salt water. 
(a)  The following bodies of water lying within the city are hereby declared to be entirely salt water and these bodies of water are inhabited only by saltwater fish and are not inhabited by any kind or type of freshwater fish: 
All canals, bayous and waterways within the city which are connected to the Manatee River or Terra Ceia Bay, and all waters of the river or bay within seventy-five (75) feet of the entrance to such canals, bayous or waterways. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to use or cause to be used for the purpose of taking fish, any seine, haul seine, drag net, gill net, or any other seine or net except a common hand-cast net or a common handheld bait or dip net within any water described in subsection (a). 
Any canals, bayous and waterways within the city which are connected to the Manatee River or Terra Ceia Bay, and all waters of the river or bay within seventy-five (75) feet of the entrance to such canals, bayous and waterways. 
(c)  Any person violating any of the provisions of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor in the second degree. 
(d)  The placing of any net or seine of any kind or character except as specified in this section shall be prima facie evidence of its use for the purpose of taking fish. 
(Laws of Fla., Ch. 63-1883, §§ 1-4; Code 1975, § 17-2(a), (b); Ord. No. 229, § 1(17-2(a)-(d), 12-3-84) 
State Law reference- Special act regulating fishing in certain bodies of water in Palmetto, Laws of Fla., Ch. 67-1883. 
Sec. 10-98. - Fishing restricted in Manatee River. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to throw or release into the water of the Manatee River any net or nets, commonly known as a cast net, for the purpose of catching fish, upon or from the municipal pier, or the approach leading to the pier, at the foot of Tenth Avenue. 
(Code 1975, § 17-9) 
Secs. 10-99-10-109. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - DOCKS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 07-946, adopted September 24, 2007, was not specifically amendatory of the Code. The editor has treated these new provisions as superseding article V, which contained similar provisions and derived from Ord. No. 06-909, adopted December 18, 2006. 

Sec. 10-110. - Intent and applicability. 
(a)  The city commission finds and determines that it is necessary to regulate coastal and waterfront construction activities for the purpose of promoting the safe navigation of the city's waterways, protecting shorelines and aquatic resources, and preserving the economic value of real property within the city. It is therefore the intent and purpose of this article to regulate waterfront construction and to minimize negative impacts associated with this construction including but not limited to: interference with navigation, hazards to health and safety, environmental degradation and reduction of real property values. 
(b)  The requirements of this article shall govern docks, dock related structures and floating structures located on or adjacent all waterways within the city limits. Notwithstanding the foregoing, however, sections 10-117 and 10-118 herein shall apply only to docks and dock related structures located on or adjacent to manmade canals greater than forty (40) feet in length or width within the city. 
(Ord. No. 07-946, § 2, 9-24-07) 
Sec. 10-111. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Adverse environmental impact means any change in the physical or biological conditions of the natural environment within or adjacent to the area that results in a detrimental effect upon flora, fauna, air, water, minerals or other natural characteristic of the area. 
    Boat means any manmade item which floats and is designed to be propelled by oars, paddles, sail, motorized power or by any other means. 
    Boathouse means any structure, designed to accommodate the storage of a boat on or above the water which is partially or totally enclosed with walls. Roofed structures without any walls are not boathouses. 
    Dock means a private or public structure located on a parcel of property which is lawfully used for single-family residential, multifamily residential, commercial or recreational purposes and which structure extends into the water or rests on submerged land and which is used as a place to which a boat can be moored, a landing place or promenade or a place for the loading or unloading of materials. The term shall include the construction of structures attached to a dock which are only suitable for the mooring or storage of boats (e.g., boat lifts), and shall include piers and marinas, as those terms are commonly used. 
    Dock related structure means davits, mooring pilings, dolphins and tie poles, as those terms are commonly used and other accessory structures consistent with the use of a dock. 
    Floating structure means a barge-like structure, with or without accommodations, which is not used as a means of transportation on water but which serves purposes or provides services typically associated with a structure upon or improvements located upon real property such as but not limited to use as a residence, place of business, office, hotel, motel, restaurant, lounge, retail or wholesale store, clubhouse, helicopter pad, meeting facility, or a storage or parking facility. Incidental movement or the capability of movement upon water shall not preclude a structure from classification as a floating structure. Registration of the structure as a vessel in accordance with F.S. chapter 327 shall not preclude a structure from classification as a floating structure. 
    Riparian lines means lines resulting from the allocation of riparian rights that generally extend perpendicular from the channel, line of deep water, line of navigability or line of navigation to each upland parcel's or lot's side property lines. The allocation of riparian rights shall follow the established standards of the Florida Department of Environmental Protection. 
    Seawall means any manmade structure, wall or encroachment made to break the force of waves and to protect the shore from erosion. For the purposes of this article the term seawall shall include but not be limited to retaining walls, revetment and bulkheads. 
    Submerged lands means lands below the ordinary high water mark of fresh waters and below the mean high water line of salt waters extending waterward to the outer jurisdiction of the city. 
    Waters or waterways means all waters or bodies of water including but not limited to rivers, lakes, streams, springs, bays, bayous, harbors and canals, which include fresh, brackish, saline, tidal or surface waters. 
    Work means any project, activity, alteration, construction, maintenance, repair, placement or replacement of or with respect to any dock, dock related structure, or floating structure. 
(Ord. No. 07-946, § 2, 9-24-07) 
Sec. 10-112. - Building official duties and powers. 
(a)  The use of the term "building official" in this article shall include a qualified designee of the building official. The duties, functions, powers and responsibilities of the building official under this article shall include the following: 
(1)  The enforcement of the provisions of this article and the rules and regulations promulgated hereunder. 
(2)  The power to issue a notice to correct or to cease any violation of this article. 
(3)  The power and authority to order the immediate cessation of any acts or correction of any condition in violation of this article which threatens the public health, safety or welfare, or threatens damage to property. Any person receiving such an order for cessation of acts or correction of conditions shall immediately comply with the requirements thereof. 
(b)  Whenever this article specifies the need for an approval, a determination, the issuance of permits, review or the promulgation of standards or criteria, said approval, determination, review, permitting, or promulgation shall be the duty and responsibility of the building official unless otherwise specifically provided. Such approvals, determinations, reviews, decisions to permit and the promulgation of standards and criteria shall be based upon federal, state or local regulations, the requirements of this article or generally accepted scientific concepts and professional standards of the particular professional discipline concerned. 
(Ord. No. 07-946, § 2, 9-24-07) 
Sec. 10-113. - Prior permits and construction 
    All docks and dock related structures in existence on the effective date of this article shall be regarded and regulated as nonconforming structures pursuant to article VII of appendix B of the City Code of Ordinances so long as they comply with the requirements of, and any conditions of, an existing permit, if any. 
    The violation of any permit, requirement or condition lawfully issued by another jurisdiction shall be a violation of this article such that the building official may suspend or revoke a permit issued by the city pursuant to this article until such violation is cured. Any work on a previously permitted dock, dock related structure, or floating structure commenced after adoption of this article must comply with all the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 07-946, § 2, 9-24-07) 
Sec. 10-114. - Permit required; exceptions. 
(a)  A permit is required to perform any work wholly or partially in, on, or upon waterways or submerged lands within the city limits. In addition to ensuring that a permit applicant meets applicable requirements of the Florida Building Code and the City Code of Ordinances, the building official shall determine that a dock, dock related structure or floating structure is structurally sound prior to approving a permit for same. 
(b)  A permit is not required for the following: 
(1)  The addition of handrails of up to three and one-half (31/2) feet in total height on an existing dock, dock related structure, or floating structure provided that the railing consists of see-through construction (shadow box or stockade fencing is not acceptable) a maximum of three and one-half (31/2) feet high measured from the deck surface. 
(2)  Repair work consisting of the replacement of any portion or all of the decking of a permitted dock, dock related structure, or floating structure, provided the dock is within the extended side property lines and the repair maintains or reduces in size the original configuration as permitted. 
(3)  Replacement of any or all pilings of any existing legally permitted dock, dock related structure, or floating structure, provided the pilings are within the extended side property lines. 
(Ord. No. 07-946, § 2, 9-24-07) 
Sec. 10-115. - Application procedures; incomplete applications. 
(a)  The applicant shall submit to the building official an application in such form as required by the building official. The building official shall determine when an application is complete and may request additional information when such application is determined to be incomplete. An application shall be approved or denied within sixty (60) days of the determination by the building official that the application is complete. Where a determination of the building official is determinant upon approval of another agency, an application shall not be deemed complete until the building official's receipt of such approval or denial of approval. 
(b)  In addition to any other penalties provided for violations of this article, any person who begins any work without first obtaining the required permit shall pay a double permit fee for the first offense and a triple permit fee for the second offense and each subsequent offense. 
(c)  In order to protect the health, safety, and welfare of the general public, or to obtain compliance with local, state or federal laws, the building official may add special terms, conditions, limitations or restrictions, which shall be binding upon the applicant, to any permit or other form of approval that may be issued. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person to whom a permit or other form of approval has been issued to violate any of the terms or conditions that have been imposed by the building official as a condition to its issuance. 
(e)  The building official, all code enforcement officers and building inspectors for the city shall be granted as an implied or express condition of each and every dock or dock related structure permit the right to ingress and egress onto real property lying adjacent to all docks and dock related structures to inspect such facilities for compliance with this and all codes of the City of Palmetto. Further, such personnel shall be immune from prosecution, civil or criminal, for reasonable, good faith trespass upon real property while discharging his duties pursuant to this article. 
(Ord. No. 07-946, § 2, 9-24-07) 
Sec. 10-116. - Maintenance; abatement of hazardous conditions. 
(a)  Any work and any dock, dock related structure, or floating structure shall be privately maintained by the owner or possessor of the property. Work or structures that are not maintained in such a manner as to prevent deterioration or such work or structures that become a hazard to the public or to navigation or limit access for drainage maintenance purposes or damage adjacent property or which are unfit or unsafe shall be in violation of this article. 
(b)  Unfit or unsafe docks, dock related structures, or floating structures shall be subject to the provisions of chapter 7 of the City Code of Ordinances concerning the repair, securing, demolition or removal of unfit or unsafe structures and the procedures and liens therefore. 
(Ord. No. 07-946, § 2, 9-24-07) 
Sec. 10-117. - Factors for evaluation of permit applications. 
    This section shall govern docks, dock related structures and floating structures located on or adjacent all waterways within the city limits. The approval, denial or approval subject to terms, conditions, limitations or restrictions, for such docks or dock related structures located on or adjacent to manmade canals greater than forty (40) feet in width or length within the city shall be based upon the following factors, as applicable. For purposes of this section, the term "dock" shall include dock, dock related structures, and floating structures: 
(1)  Zoning requirements. Applications for a dock shall only be processed when the dock is associated with one (1) of the following: 
a.  Accessory uses to contiguous upland properties. One (1) dock may be permitted and constructed as an accessory use to an existing lawfully permitted principal land use on contiguous upland property. One (1) pair of davits may be constructed on or next to a seawall as an accessory use if they meet the side setback requirements for the property and are designed to function independently of the seawall. 
b.  Use on noncontiguous platted water lots. One (1) dock may be permitted and constructed on a noncontiguous water lot, as that term is defined appendix B, article III of this Code. 
c.  Commercial marina. A dock may be permitted and constructed if it is part of a commercial marina approved by all required outside agencies. A copy of permits or approvals issued by all such agencies shall be submitted to the building official. 
d.  Planned developments. Docks and dock related structures may be permitted and constructed as an accessory use to a planned residential development which has common area amenities if proposed by an incorporated association and approved by all required outside agencies. A copy of permits or approvals issued by all such agencies shall be submitted to the building official. 
(2)  Development standards. Applications for docks shall be permitted when such applications comply with the following requirements: 
a.  Side setbacks. Side setbacks for docks and dock related structures shall be measured from the riparian lines of platted waterfront lots or parcels, or from the actual lot lines in those cases where side lot lines actually extend out into the waterway. Such setbacks for docks or dock related structures shall be the same as those required within the zoning district in which abutting upland property is located. 
b.  Joint docks. Two (2) or more contiguous waterfront lots or parcels with at least forty (40) feet of combined waterfront frontage located on the headlands of a manmade canal may join in an application for construction of a joint dock. A joint dock shall be regulated under this article as if the combined lots were a single lot or parcel. All requirements within this article apply to joint docks. A joint dock or dock related structure that runs parallel to the headland shoreline shall be located within the middle one-third ( 1/3 ) of the combined lots and shall be constructed as one (1) continuous structure across the common property line(s). Where a joint dock is permitted and constructed pursuant to this section, no other docks or dock related structures shall be constructed on the subject properties. 
c.  Waterway encroachment. No portion of a dock or boat may encroach into the waterway more than the lesser of twenty-five (25) percent of the width of the waterway or twenty-five (25) feet. 
d.  Visual obstruction. No vertical side of a dock related structure shall be enclosed with any wall or barrier which is not of see-through construction (stockade or shadowbox fence are not see-through). Railing systems are permitted, provided that the rails comply with the opacity and height standards for fences in waterfront yards. 
e.  [Boathouses.] Boathouses, and dock related structures with roofs or canopies, are prohibited. 
f.  Required dimensions. All docks and portions thereof shall be a minimum of two (2) feet wide. No dock related structure shall exceed a height of twenty (20) feet above the highest point on the walkway. The elevation of the walking surface of a dock shall not exceed five (5) feet above the mean high water line or, where a seawall is present, the top of a seawall cap. 
g.  Number of boats. Docks on inland canals shall be designed or constructed to accommodate no more than the number of boats that may be safely moored to a given dock while maintaining applicable setbacks and not extending into the canal more than twenty-five (25) percent of the canal. Other than for access from the uplands, the walkway and head of a fishing pier or observation deck must have a continuous railing which prevents ingress and egress from a boat. 
h.  Environmental impact. Construction of docks which, in the discretion of the building official, results in verifiable adverse environmental impacts but complies with the aforementioned criteria may be denied a permit unless and until the applicant demonstrates to the building official that any such impacts will be addressed in accordance with mitigation standards established or approved by the Florida Department of Environmental Protection. 
i.  Ownership. Evidence of ownership of uplands or a written lease of the submerged land upon which work is proposed must be provided prior to issuance of a permit pursuant to this article. Such evidence of ownership may, in the discretion of the building official, be in the form of an affidavit of ownership executed by the owner or lessee of the property. 
j.  [Additional provisions.] None of the provisions of this article shall be implemented in a manner that would unreasonably infringe upon the traditional, common law riparian rights, as defined in F.S. section 253.141, of upland property owners adjacent to sovereignty submerged lands. 
(3)  Commercial marina. Any dock used for a commercial purpose shall comply with all rules and regulations of authorized local, state and federal agencies. 
(Ord. No. 07-946, § 2, 9-24-07) 
Sec. 10-118. - Mooring of boats. 
    This section shall govern docks, dock related structures and floating structures located on or adjacent all waterways within the city limits. It shall be unlawful to dock, moor, park, store or in any other manner attach to or place upon any dock, dock related structure, or floating structure more than two (2) boats greater than sixteen (16) feet in length. No boat may be docked, moored, parked, stored, attached to or placed upon any structure identified as or restricted to use as a fishing pier or observation deck. 
(Ord. No. 07-946, § 2, 9-24-07) 
Sec. 10-119. - Variances 
    This section shall govern docks, dock related structures and floating structures located on or adjacent all waterways within the city limits. Requests for variances from the requirements of this article shall be heard by the planning and zoning board after following the criteria, standards and procedures set forth in article XII of appendix B of the City Code of Ordinances. The notice requirements of article XII of appendix B of the City Code of Ordinances are not required to be followed if notarized letters of approval from the owners of lots within two hundred (200) feet of the side(s) where a side setback variance is requested are provided. Those letters may be considered as evidence that the variance criteria have been met. 
(Ord. No. 07-946, § 2, 9-24-07) 
Sec. 10-120. - Modification; penalties for violation. 
(a)  Modification to a permit issued for work hereunder must be approved by the building official and made part of the permit. 
(b)  Violation of this article, any lawful order of the building official issued pursuant to this article, or the terms and conditions of a permit issued pursuant to this article, or failure to perform work in accordance with the approved plans and specifications thereof, or any material false statement in the application, may result in the revocation in whole or in part of a permit issued for work hereunder, or the execution of any other enforcement measures authorized by the City Code of Ordinances or other applicable law. 
(Ord. No. 07-946, § 2, 9-24-07) 
Sec. 10-121. - Appeals 
    Any person aggrieved by any action or decision of the building official may appeal such action or decision to the planning and zoning board by following the procedures set forth in section 12.4 (c) of appendix B of the City Code of Ordinances. The words "action" and "decision" as used herein shall not include the initiation of any action by the building official in any court. 
(Ord. No. 07-946, § 2, 9-24-07)

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 11-1-11-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - COMMUNITY REDEVELOPMENT 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 11-26. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Act means the Community Redevelopment Act, F.S. § 163.330 et seq. 
    Agency means the Community Redevelopment Agency of the City of Palmetto. 
    Area means an area designated as a redevelopment area and as described and mapped on documents in the city clerk's office. 
    Fund means the community redevelopment trust fund. 
    Plan means the community redevelopment plan. 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Secs. 11-27-11-40. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - COMMUNITY REDEVELOPMENT AGENCY[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2. 

Sec. 11-41. - Created. 
    Pursuant to F.S. § 163.356, there is hereby created a public body corporate and politic to be known as the community redevelopment agency. 
(Ord. No. 259, § 1, 11-4-85; Ord. No. 09-985, § 1, 2-23-09) 
Sec. 11-42. - City commission as governing body of the community redevelopment agency. 
    Pursuant to F.S. § 163.357, and Resolution 09-09, the city commission shall serve as the governing body of the community redevelopment agency. The mayor shall not be a voting member of the community redevelopment agency but shall preside over the meetings. 
(Ord. No. 259, § 2, 11-4-85; Ord. No. 321, § 1, 6-15-87; Ord. No. 329, § 2, 12-7-87; Ord. No. 09-985, § 1, 2-23-09) 
Sec. 11-43. - Governance. 
    The community development agency shall be governed by and shall act in conformity with the provisions of general law and this division, as either shall be amended from time to time. The community redevelopment agency may adopt rules and procedures as it may deem appropriate from time to time. The director of the community redevelopment agency shall coordinate with the mayor regarding the agenda for meetings of the community redevelopment agency. The city clerk shall serve as secretary to the community redevelopment agency and shall be responsible for keeping records of the board's actions, providing necessary background material, keeping a record of attendance, keeping a record of all official actions of the board, including the vote of the members on each questions requiring a vote, or if absent or abstaining from voting, indicating such fact. 
(Ord. No. 259, § 3, 11-4-85; Ord. No. 09-985, § 1, 2-23-09; Ord. No. 2015-15, § 2.A.1., 9-14-15) 
Sec. 11-44. - Jurisdiction. 
    The area of operation of the community redevelopment agency shall be the redevelopment area as generally shown on the map depicted on Map 11-1. A detailed map shall be on file at City Hall and the Palmetto Community Redevelopment Agency office. 
(Ord. No. 259, § 4, 11-4-85; Ord. No. 323, 8-17-87; Ord. No. 555, § 1, 3-8-96; Ord. No. 09-985, § 1, 2-23-09; Ord. No. 2011-34, § 1, 12-19-11; Ord. No. 2015-15, § 2.A.2., 9-14-15) 
Editor's note- Updated maps have been adopted by Ord. No. 330 (2-25-88) and 369 (5-15-89). Exhibits B and C are adopted as if fully set out herein and are on file and available for inspection at the offices of the city. 
Sec. 11-45. - Powers of community redevelopment agency.
