A completed application for permit shall be filed with the office of the city clerk at least thirty (30) calendar days prior to a planned event having less than three hundred (300) attendees and at least sixty (60) calendar days prior to a planned event having three hundred (300) or more attendees. 
(Ord. No. 608, § 1, 1-5-98; Ord. No. 09-997, § 2, 10-19-09; Ord. No. 2016-10, § 2.B., 12-19-16) 
Sec. 19-175. - Review and approval of application. 
    Upon filing of the application for a permit, the city clerk or the clerk's designee shall route the application to all department heads for review and sign-off and then present the application to the city commission for approval or denial, subject to the provisions set forth in section 19-176. Review criteria regarding issuance of the permit shall be as follows: 
(1)  Is the facility of adequate size and type to handle the event; 
(2)  Are there adequate safety precautions to protect participants and the public; 
(3)  Are there other events scheduled at the same time which conflict with the proposed event or adversely affect use of the park or other city facilities; and 
(4)  Are there any other matters related to public health, safety and welfare? 
    The applicant is recommended to attend the city commission meeting in order to be able to respond to questions. 
(Ord. No. 608, § 1, 1-5-98; Ord. No. 09-997, § 2, 10-19-09; Ord. No. 2016-10, § 2.A., 12-19-16) 
Sec. 19-176. - Review if city commission unable to vote. 
    In the event the city commission is not scheduled to meet on an application prior to the date of the event, the mayor shall review the application and prepare a notice of intent to approve or deny the request. The notice of intent shall be forwarded to the city commission. If a commissioner requests a special meeting of the commission within forty-eight (48) hours after transmittal of the notice of intent, the mayor shall schedule a special meeting to review and consider the application. If no special meeting is requested within the forty-eight-hour time period, the special function permit application shall be approved or denied consistent with the notice of intent. 
(Ord. No. 09-997, § 2, 10-19-09; Ord. No. 2016-10, § 2.C., 12-19-16) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 09-997, § 2, adopted Oct. 19, 2009, amended § 19-176 in its entirety, which previously pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 608, § 1, adopted Jan. 5, 1998. 
Sec. 19-177. - Fee and security deposit required. 
    After use the facility shall be returned to a condition substantially consistent with its condition prior to the use. Any damage or cleaning necessary to return the facility to such prior condition shall be the responsibility and the cost of sponsor. A fee and security deposit shall be required for use of city property or facilities pursuant to a special function permit. The required fee and security deposit amounts shall be established, and amended from time to time, by resolution of the city commission. The city commission shall have the authority to require an additional security deposit for a particular activity or function where it finds that doing so is in the best interest of the public health, safety or welfare. 
(Ord. No. 608, § 1, 1-5-98; Ord. No. 04-824, § 2, 10-4-04; Ord. No. 09-997, § 2, 10-19-09) 
Sec. 19-178. - Alcoholic beverages on city-owned or -leased property or right-of-way and various restrictions. 
(a)  The sale of consumption of alcoholic beverages on city-owned or -leased property or upon rights-of-way within the city by any person sponsoring or attending an event for which a special function permit has been issued is prohibited, except where the special function permit specifically authorizes the sale and consumption of alcoholic beverages. 
(b)  If permitted pursuant to a special function permit, no glass containers shall be allowed to be sold or used by event attendees. If permitted pursuant to a special function permit, the special function permit shall identify the time and location that such alcoholic beverages may be sold and consumed at the function, and the sponsor shall be required to hire police security for the event. 
(Ord. No. 608, § 1, 1-5-98; Ord. No. 04-824, § 3, 10-4-04; Ord. No. 09-997, § 2, 10-19-09; Ord. No. 2013-15, § 2, 10-21-13) 
Sec. 19-179. - General liability insurance to be procured. 
    A policy of general liability insurance shall be procured by the sponsoring organization which shall insure the city, its officers, employees and agents from liability arising out of the event for which the permit is issued. Evidence of such insurance shall be a condition of issuance of a special function permit. The required amount of such insurance shall be established by the city and the necessary insurance may be provided through the city or procured separately by the sponsoring organization. The city commission may require additional types of insurance depending on the use and type of facility. 
(Ord. No. 608, § 1, 1-5-98; Ord. No. 09-997, § 2, 10-19-09) 
Sec. 19-180. - City facility rentals. 
    Regardless of whether a special function permit is required pursuant to section 19-173, the city permits individuals and organizations to rent certain city property and facilities for exclusive use pursuant to established policies and procedures. In these instances, the sponsoring organization must complete a facility use agreement and pay the applicable rental fee and insurance fee pursuant to the fee structure on the facility use agreement. 
(Ord. No. 04-824, § 4, 10-4-04; Ord. No. 09-997, § 2, 10-19-09) 
Secs. 19-181-19-200. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - INTERNET OR SWEEPSTAKES CAFES 

Sec. 19-201. - Title. 
    This article shall be known and may be cited as the "Internet/Sweepstakes Cafe Moratorium Ordinance" 
(Ord. No. 2012-01, § 2, 1-9-12) 
Sec. 19-202. - Definitions. 
    [The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:] 
    Internet/sweepstakes cafe (cafe) means any business or entity that provides one (1) or more simulated gambling devices for use by the public at the business' or entity's licensed business location. The use of simulated gambling devices does not have to be the business' or entity's primary source of business or income. 
    Person means an individual, association, partnership, joint venture, corporation, or any other type of organization, whether conducted for profit or not for profit, or a director, executive, officer, manager, or employee of an association, partnership, joint venture, corporation, or other organization. 
    Simulated gambling device means any device that, upon connection with an object, is available to play or operate a computer simulation of any game, and which may deliver or entitle the person or persons playing or operating the device to a payoff. The following rules of construction apply to this definition of "simulated gambling device": 
(1)  The term "device" means any mechanical or electrical contrivance, computer, terminal, video, or other equipment that may or may not be capable of downloading games from a central server system, machine, computer, or other device or equipment. 
(2)  The term "upon connection with" means insertion, swiping, passing in range, or any other technical means physically or electromagnetically connecting an object to a device. 
(3)  The term "object" means a coin, bill, ticket, token, card, or similar object, obtained directly or indirectly through payment of consideration, or obtained as a bonus or supplement to another transaction involving the payment of consideration. 
(4)  The terms "play or operate" or "play or operation" includes the use of skill, the application of the element of chance, or both. 
(5)  The term "computer simulation" includes simulations by means of a computer, computer system, video display, video system, or any other form of electronic video presentation. 
(6)  The term "game" includes slot machines, poker, bingo, craps, keno, any other type of game ordinarily played in a casino, a drawing, contest or other promotion, lotto, sweepstakes, and any other game associated with gambling or which could be associated with gambling, but the term "game" does not necessarily imply that actual gambling is involved. 
(7)  The term "payoff" means cash, monetary or other credit, billets, tickets, tokens, or electronic credits to be exchanged for cash or to receive merchandise or anything of value whatsoever, whether made automatically from the machine or manually. 
(8)  The use of the word "gambling" in the term "simulated gambling device" is for convenience of reference only. The term "simulated gambling device" as used in this article is defined exclusively by this subsection and does not incorporate or imply any legal definition or requirement applicable to gambling that may be found elsewhere. 
    Slot machine means any electrical, mechanical, or electromechanical device which is adapted for use such that by the insertion of coin(s), token(s), or other method of payment the device will allow an operator to play or operate the machine such that the device displays pictures, icons, or other images which may, depending upon the displayed combination of said pictures, icons, or other images, allow the operator to obtain an item or items of value, including, but not limited to, money, objects, or coupons. Such devices shall be deemed slot machines regardless of whether the operation of the device is affected by chance, by the application of skill, or by any combination thereof. Examples of slot machines include, but are not limited to, the games known as "Fruit Paradise", "New Cherry", "Fruit Bonus", "Triple Jack", "Magical Odds", "Mystery J&B", "Klondike", and "Reel of Fortune". Games such as pinball, mechanical grab machines, shooting games, and other similar games are not slot machines. 
(Ord. No. 2012-01, § 2, 1-9-12) 
Sec. 19-203. - Boundaries subject to the moratorium. 
    This article shall be applicable to all properties located within the boundaries of the City of Palmetto. 
(Ord. No. 2012-01, § 2, 1-9-12) 
Sec. 19-204. - Intent. 
(a)  The intent of the city commission acting as the governing body of the City of Palmetto, Florida, in adopting this article is to inhibit the unregulated growth of internet/sweepstakes cafes within the City of Palmetto until: 
(1)  The state legislature enacts such regulation with statewide application; or 
(2)  The Courts of the State of Florida make a determination as to whether simulated gambling devices are "slot machines" as defined in F.S. chapter 849. 
(b)  It is specifically not the intent of the city commission by the adoption of this article to condone or approve the use of simulated gambling devices. 
(Ord. No. 2012-01, § 2, 1-9-12) 
Sec. 19-205. - Temporary moratorium. 
    The city commission finds that the proliferation of Internet/sweepstakes cafes, along with the questionable legality of the simulated gambling devices in use by the cafes, requires regulation and further interpretation of the statues regulating gambling. The interest of the citizens of the City of Palmetto and the State of Florida will be better served if such regulation and statutory interpretation is provided uniformly by the state legislature and the state court system. In an effort to limit the expansion of such questionable business activity until the legislature or courts act, a temporary moratorium is established for the licensing of any new Internet/sweepstakes cafes which are not established and conducting business as of the effective date of this article. This temporary moratorium shall be in place from the effective date of this article through September 30, 2012. The city commission may rescind or extend this moratorium for periods of up to six (6) months by resolution. 
(Ord. No. 2012-01, § 2, 1-9-12) 
Sec. 19-206. - Exemptions. 
(a)  This article does not prohibit the personal and recreational ownership, possession, play, operation, or use of a device which could be construed to be a simulated gambling devices, provided such ownership, possession, play, operation, or use is not otherwise prohibited by Florida law and provided ownership, possession, play, operation, or use does not constitute a lottery under Article X, Section 7 of the Florida Constitution. 
(b)  This article does not prohibit the ownership, possession, play, operation, or use of a computer, video display, or the Internet in a retail business setting provided such ownership, possession, play, operation, or use is not a pretext or sham for using such devices as a simulated gambling device. 
(c)  This article does not prohibit the ownership, possession, play, operation, or use of any device expressly permitted by the Florida Statutes and not otherwise prohibited by the Florida Constitution. Except for the businesses specifically designated as not intended to be regulated by this article in paragraph (e) below, devices permitted by Article X, Section 23 of the Florida Constitution and F.S. chapter 551 in Broward and Miami-Dade Counties are not permitted by this article. 
(d)  This article does not prohibit a charitable organization from conducting a fund raising activity involving gaming, provided the charitable organization does not conduct the activity more than twice in one (1) calendar year, the organization provides advance written notice to the Palmetto Police Chief of the date, time, place, nature of the activity as well as who will be conducting it, and the activity is not otherwise unlawful. 
(e)  This article is specifically not intended to regulate in any manner the following businesses located in the City of Palmetto which are currently regulated by federal law, state statute, and/or local ordinance: 
(1)  Any properly authorized recreation and amusement services including amusement arcades and bingo halls operated pursuant to sections 3.2 and 6.22 of the City of Palmetto Code of Ordinances. 
(2)  Any properly authorized arcade amusement center, amusement machines, and truck stop arcades operated pursuant to F.S. section 849.161. 
(Ord. No. 2012-01, § 2, 1-9-12) 
Sec. 19-207. - Conflict with state law. 
    Nothing in this article is intended to conflict with the provisions of the Florida Constitution or F.S. chapter 849 concerning gambling. In the event of a direct and express conflict between this article and either the Florida Constitution or F.S. chapter 849, then the provisions of the Florida Constitution or F.S. chapter 849, as applicable, control. 
(Ord. No. 2012-01, § 2, 1-9-12) 
Sec. 19-208. - Enforcement, penalties, and injunctive relief. 
    The city's code enforcement officers, law enforcement, or any other person authorized to enforce county ordinances in the City of Palmetto may enforce the provisions of this article. Any enforcement action or legal remedy available under controlling state law including, but not limited to, prosecution as a misdemeanor with a fine not exceeding five-hundred dollars ($500.00) or by imprisonment for a term not exceeding sixty (60) days or by both fine and imprisonment, may be imposed as a penalty. Nothing contained herein shall prevent the city from taking such other lawful action in law and equity as may be necessary to remedy any violation of, or refusal to comply with, any part of this article, including, but not limited to: 
(1)  Code enforcement action pursuant to City of Palmetto Ordinances; 
(2)  Pursuit of injunctive and/or declaratory relief in a court of competent jurisdiction; 
(3)  Initiating an action to recover any and all damages that may result from a violation of, or a refusal to comply with, any part of this article; or 
(4)  Utilizing any other action or enforcement method allowable by law. 
(Ord. No. 2012-01, § 2, 1-9-12) 
Secs. 19-209-19-219. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - REGULATION OF THE USE OF VARIOUS PORTABLE OR TEMPORARY USES 

Sec. 19-220. - Definitions. 
    [The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:] 
    Drop box means any container, storage unit or structure, other than an accessory building or shed complying with all building codes and land use requirements, that can or is used for the holding of charitable or for profit donations with collection of these donations made at a later date or time and which is located for such purposes outside an enclosed building. 
    Portable storage container means any container, (including a shipping or cargo container), storage unit, or other portable container (including "PODS"), other than an accessory building or shed, which is the subject of a building permit and which complies with all building codes and land use requirements, that can or is used for the storage of personal property of any kind, which is located for such purposes outside an enclosed building. 
(Ord. No. 2013-19, § 2b., 3-3-14; Ord. No. 2013-21, § 2.b., 1-26-15) 
Sec. 19-221. - Drop boxes. 
(a)  Drop boxes are prohibited on all public and private property in the city except under the following conditions: 
(1)  Drop boxes shall be allowed on property where the primary structure is used by a not for profit organization, as defined by state statutes, as well as authorized affiliates, or agencies of such organizations, and the box is used exclusively to support said organization. 
(2)  Drop boxes shall be permitted by the city and placed within the buildable area of the lot in a side or rear yard. Drop boxes with P zoning shall meet the setbacks of the adjacent zoning district closest to the drop box. 
(3)  Drop boxes shall be anchored to the ground or a structure and shall be located in an area which does not interfere with required parking or drive isles. 
(4)  There shall be no more than one (1) drop box per property. 
(5)  The drop box shall be no larger than six (6) feet wide, six (6) feet deep and eight (8) feet high. 
(6)  All donations shall be placed completely within the drop box. Donations that are not fully enclosed in a drop box are considered a public nuisance and subject to removal at the property owner's expense by the city. 
(Ord. No. 2013-19, § 2c., 3-3-14) 
Sec. 19-222. - Portable storage containers. 
(a)  In all residential zoning categories and any residential areas of a designated planned development zoning category, the use of portable storage containers shall be allowed only under the following conditions: 
(1)  There shall be no more than one (1) portable storage container per property. A portable storage container which does not exceed seven (7) feet in length, seven (7) feet in width, or five (5) feet in height and which is not located in the front yard as defined in appendix B of the Palmetto Code of Ordinances, is exempt from the provisions of this subsection. 
(2)  Portable storage containers shall be no larger than ten (10) feet wide, twenty-four (24) feet long and ten (10) feet high. 
(3)  A portable storage container shall not remain at a property in any zoning district in excess of sixty (60) consecutive days, and must not be placed at any one (1) property more than twice during each calendar year. 
(4)  A portable storage container shall be set back a minimum of five (5) feet from all property lines. 
(5)  A portable storage container shall not be placed in any location that interferes with the drainage system. 
(6)  A portable storage container shall not obstruct access to any building or block the visibility triangle of any roadway. 
(7)  Portable storage containers associated with active construction at a site with an active building permit shall be permitted for the duration of construction and shall be removed from the site at the end of construction pursuant to subsection 7-9(c)(4) [of the Palmetto Code of Ordinances]. Portable storage containers associated with construction are exempt from the other conditions set forth in this section. 
(b)  In all properties except those that are residentially zoned or in residential areas of a designated planned development zoning category (which includes commercial, office and industrial zoning categories), the use of portable storage containers shall be allowed only under the following conditions: 
(1)  The portable storage container shall be no larger than ten (10) feet wide, twenty-four (24) feet long and ten (10) feet high. 
(2)  A portable storage container shall not be located in a front yard, as defined in appendix B of the Palmetto Code of Ordinances, and shall be set back a minimum of five (5) feet from all property lines. 
(3)  A portable storage container shall not be placed in any location that interferes with the drainage system. 
(4)  A portable storage container shall not obstruct access to any building or block the visibility triangle of any roadway. 
(5)  Portable containers shall not be located in any part of a drive aisle. 
(6)  Portable storage containers associated with active construction at a site with an active building permit shall be permitted for the duration of construction and shall be removed from the site at the end of construction pursuant to subsection 7-9(c)(4) [of the Palmetto Code of Ordinances]. Portable storage containers associated with construction are exempt from the other conditions set forth in this section. 
(Ord. No. 2013-21, § 2.c.(19-221), 1-26-15) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2013-21, § 2.c., adopted Jan 26, 2015, added provisions designated as § 19-221. Inasmuch as there were already provisions so designated, these provisions have been redesignated as § 19-222 at the discretion of the editor. 
Chapter 20 - MISCELLANEOUS OFFENSES 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2015-07, § 1, adopted Oct. 19, 2015, amended Art. I in its entirety to read as set out herein. Former Art. I, §§ 20-1-20-5, pertained to similar subject matter and derived from the Code of 1975, § 8-1, 17-1, 17-6, Ord. No. 335, § 1, adopted June 6, 1988; and Ord. No. 04-801, § 2, adopted April 26, 2004. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 20-1. - Court costs assessed. 
(a)  There is hereby assessed by the city commission in compliance with state law an additional two dollars ($2.00) as court costs against every person convicted for violation of a state penal or criminal statute or convicted of violating a municipal or county ordinance where the offense occurred within the city limits. In addition, two dollars ($2.00) shall be deducted from every bond estreature or forfeited bail bond related to such penal statutes or ordinances. However, no such assessment shall be made against any person convicted of a state statute, municipal or county ordinance related to parking of vehicles. 
(b)  All such assessments shall be collected by the appropriate court and shall be remitted to the city and earmarked for law enforcement education and training for members of the police department. The use and expenditure of such funds shall be approved by the chief of police and in accordance with state law. 
(Ord. No. 2015-07, § 1, 10-19-15) 
Sec. 20-2. - State misdemeanors and felonies adopted. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to commit within the city any act which is or shall be recognized by the laws of the state as a misdemeanor and felony. 
(Ord. No. 2015-07, § 1, 10-19-15) 
Sec. 20-3. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2018-01, § 2, adopted February 26, 2018, repealed § 20-3, which pertained to park operating hours. See Code Comparative Table for complete derivation. 
Sec. 20-4. - Applicability and enforcement of county fireworks ordinance. 
    The city hereby incorporates by reference Manatee County Ordinance 04-27, as amended from time to time, as if fully rewritten herein. The city shall have the authority to enforce this provisions of said county ordinance within the city by citation, referral to a special magistrate, or in any other manner provided for in this Code. 
(Ord. No. 2015-07, § 1, 10-19-15; Ord. No. 2018-02, § 3(Exh. B), 2-26-18) 
Secs. 20-5-20-8. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PROHIBITED ACTIVITIES IN CITY PARKS AND CITY FACILITIES 

Sec. 20-9. - Definitions. 
(a)  The following words and phrases, when used in sections 20-10 through 20-14, shall have the following meaning: 
(1)  City facility includes all city-owned facilities, including but not limited to City Hall, the police department, public works, and wastewater treatment facility, however city parks are addressed separately and are therefore specifically excluded from this definition. 
(2)  City park includes all park facilities and cemeteries owned by the city. 
(3)  Living accommodation purposes means to remain living, to dwell or to reside at a place for a period of time for the purpose of using such a place as a home. 
(4)  Lodging out-of-doors means using any city park, city facility, or other public property for living accommodation purposes by the erection, use or occupation of any tent, hut, lean-to, shack or temporary shelter for sleeping purposes or the laying down of bedding, such as a blanket or sleeping bag or similar material for the purpose of sleeping. 
(5)  Loitering means the act of standing or remaining idly in or about any city facility, under circumstances where the peace and order are threatened or where the safety of persons or property is jeopardized. 
(Ord. No. 2018-01, § 3(Exh. A), 2-26-18) 
Sec. 20-10. - Prohibited activities within city parks. 
(a)  No person shall engage in activities within a city park that create an unreasonable risk of harm or danger to other city park users; that unreasonably interfere with the use of the city park by others; or that are likely to damage personal or city park property. 
(b)  Persons shall not use city parks and city park facilities for commercial use, unless specifically allowed by a special function permit. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to drink or consume any alcoholic beverage containing more than one (1) percent of alcohol by weight in a city park, unless consumption of alcohol is specifically allowed under a city special function permit or a city sponsored event, if approved by the city commission. 
(d)  No person shall play golf or hit golf balls at a city park not specifically designated for such activity. No person shall engage in archery at a city park. 
(e)  No person shall drive motorized vehicles or golf carts in a city park unless authorized by the city, nor use any other motorized device in a way that creates an unsafe condition. 
(f)  No person shall deface, paint, damage or destroy, or remove or relocate buildings, structures, equipment, sculptures or other facilities or amenities in a city park. 
(g)  No person shall damage or destroy natural or cultural resources in a city park. This includes, but is not limited to, cutting, carving, painting, defacing, marring, mutilating, breaking, moving, digging, or otherwise harmfully disturbing or removing any of the following: plants, trees, grass, ground cover, sand, soil, pine needles, bark, mulch, rocks, stones, minerals, fossils, artifacts, and animals. 
(h)  No person shall introduce any plant species, release any animals, or add structures, equipment, or amenities to a city park, without written permission from the city commission. 
(i)  No person shall enter or remain in an area of a city park or a city park facility that is posted indicating no admittance, no trespassing, under repair or construction, or not open to the public. 
(j)  Unless specifically prohibited, pets are allowed in city parks under the following conditions: pets must remain under the direct control of their handler at all times; pets must be kept on a leash or be tethered in the immediate vicinity of their handler; owners must pick up and properly dispose of pet waste. 
(k)  Persons are prohibited from defecating or urinating in a city park, except in facilities specifically designated for that purpose. 
(l)  Persons using city parks and city park facilities shall clean up and properly dispose of all trash and debris that they may generate. 
(m)  Persons are prohibited from using utility services at city parks, to include water or electricity, unless expressly authorized by the city or allowed these services by special function permit. WiFi may be utilized within any city park. 
(n)  Any person found to be in violation of this section shall first be given a verbal warning of the violation. If the violation continues after a reasonable period of time to cease such violation, that person shall be issued a trespass warning pursuant to section 20-13. 
(Ord. No. 2018-01, § 3(Exh. A), 2-26-18) 
Sec. 20-11. - Loitering at city facilities. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to loiter at a city facility in such manner so as to: 
(1)  Obstruct, impede, or hinder the free and uninterrupted passage of pedestrians; 
(2)  Obstruct or interfere with the free and uninterrupted use of the city facility by those conducting or transacting business there; or 
(3)  Occupy the premises at a time or in a manner not usual for law-abiding individuals, being during times outside of business hours for the city facility or when the person has no business to transact at the city facility. 
(b)  Any person found to be in violation of this section shall be issued a trespass warning pursuant to section 20-13. Prior to issuing a violation under this section, the law enforcement officer shall: 
(1)  Point to specific and articulable facts which, taken together with rational inferences from those facts reasonably warrant a finding that a breach of the peace is imminent or the public safety is threatened; 
(2)  Order that person to stop causing or committing such conditions and to move on or disperse; and 
(3)  Afford the person an opportunity to dispel any alarm or immediate concern which would otherwise be warranted by requesting him to identify himself and explain his presence and conduct. 
(Ord. No. 2018-01, § 3(Exh. A), 2-26-18) 
Sec. 20-12. - Unlawful lodging out-of-doors prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to use any public property in the city, including but not limited to city facilities and city parks, out-of-doors for lodging except with the permission and consent of the city. 
(b)  Being in a tent, hut, lean-to, shack or in a temporary shelter or being asleep atop or covered by materials in a public place out-of-doors without the permission and consent of the city may be evidence of a violation but is not alone sufficient to constitute a violation of this section. One or more of the following must also exist before a law enforcement officer can find probable cause to issue a trespass warning pursuant to section 20-13: 
(1)  Numerous items of personal belongings are present; 
(2)  The person is engaged in cooking activities; 
(3)  The person has built or is maintaining a fire; 
(4)  The person has engaged in digging or earth breaking activities; 
(5)  The person is asleep and when awakened states he or she has no other place to live. 
(c)  Whenever a law enforcement officer has probable cause to believe that a violation of this section has occurred, he or she shall advise the person of the violation and afford the person an opportunity to be transported by a law enforcement officer to a public shelter, except as provided for in subsection (d). The law enforcement officer shall advise the person that all his or her personal property which is not taken to the public shelter, except that which is of no apparent utility or which is in an unsanitary condition, shall be inventoried and stored by the Palmetto Police Department for a maximum of sixty (60) days, until reclaimed. If the person elects to be transported to a public shelter the law enforcement officer shall make available such transportation as may be available for such purpose and the person making such election shall not be issued a trespass warning for a violation of this section. If the person refuses to be transported to a public shelter, then such person may be charged with a violation of this section and issued a trespass warning pursuant to section 20-13. 
(d)  Affording the opportunity to be transported to a public shelter pursuant to subsection (c) shall not apply to any person who cannot be properly identified, or is intoxicated by alcohol or drugs or who, within the past three hundred sixty five (365) days, was previously charged with a violation of this section or, within the past three hundred sixty five (365) days, who elected to be transported to a public shelter. For purposes of this subsection, proper identification shall include, but be limited to, a driver's license, a government or employment identity card with photograph or other form of identification, which would satisfy a reasonable law enforcement officer as to the identity of the person. 
Any personal property that was inventoried and stored by the Palmetto Police Department for a person transported to a shelter under the provisions of this section which has not been reclaimed within sixty (60) days of the date the personal property was inventoried and stored shall be deemed abandoned and disposed of according to F.S. Ch. 705. 
(Ord. No. 2018-01, § 3(Exh. A), 2-26-18) 
Sec. 20-13. - Trespass warnings on public property. 
(a)  Officers of the city police department are authorized to issue a trespass warning to any individual who violates any city ordinance, rule or regulation, or state law which violation was committed while on or within any city facility, building, or outdoor area that is open to the general public, including city and county parks. The trespass warning shall be limited to the specific property where the violation occurred. 
(b)  Trespass warnings shall be in writing and issued for a period not to exceed three hundred sixty-five (365) days. 
(c)  A copy of the trespass warning shall be provided by mail or hand delivery to the individual given the warning. The written trespass warning shall advise of the right to appeal and the location at which to file the form to initiate the appeal. 
(d)  A trespass warning shall also be issued when officers of the city police department are acting on behalf of another governmental agency and issuing a trespass warning to an individual located on public property not owned by the city. 
(e)  Any person found on or within any city facility, building, or outdoor area, including city and county parks, in violation of a trespass warning issued in accordance with this section may be arrested for trespassing, except as otherwise provided in this section. 
(f)  Any person found on or within any public property belonging to another governmental agency other than the city, in violation of a trespass warning issued in accordance with this section may be arrested for trespassing. 
(g)  The city clerk (or his/her designee) may upon request, authorize an individual who has received a trespass warning to enter the property or premises to exercise his or her First Amendment rights if there is no other reasonable alternative location to exercise such rights or to conduct necessary municipal business. Such authorization must be in writing, shall specify the duration of the authorization and any conditions thereof, and shall not be unreasonably denied. 
(h)  This section shall not be construed to limit the authority of officers of the city police department to arrest or cite individuals for violating any section of the City Code or the Florida Statutes. 
(i)  Appeal of trespass warning: A person to whom a trespass warning is issued under this section shall have the right to appeal the issuance of the trespass warning as follows: 
(1)  An appeal of the trespass warning must be filed, in writing, within twenty (20) days of the issuance of the warning, and shall include the appellant's name, address and phone number, if any. No fee shall be charged for filing the appeal. 
(2)  The city attorney shall recommend special magistrates to exercise the authority and powers set forth in this section. The city commission may appoint up to three (3) special magistrates upon recommendation by the city attorney. Those serving as special magistrates shall be licensed Florida attorneys in good standing. 
(3)  Within seven (7) business days following the filing of the appeal, the special magistrate shall schedule a hearing. Notice of the hearing shall be provided to the appellant in one (1) of three (3) ways: 
a.  By providing the appellant a copy of the notice of hearing in person at the time he or she files the appeal. When it is not reasonably practical or possible to provide notice in this manner, the appellant shall be informed that notice of the hearing will be provided in accordance with either paragraph b. or c. below; 
b.  By leaving or posting the notice at the front desk of the city police department and on the bulletin board at city hall; or 
c.  By telephone if a telephone number has been provided and mailing when an address has been provided. 
(4)  The special magistrate shall hold the hearing as soon as possible. In no event shall the hearing be held later than forty (40) days from the filing of the appeal except that the person appealing may request an additional forty (40) days during the appeal period. 
(5)  Copies of documents in the city's control which are intended to be used at the hearing, and which directly relate to the issuance of the trespass warning to the appellant, shall be made available upon request to the appellant at no cost. 
(6)  The appellant shall have the right to testify and to call witnesses and present evidence and the right to engage an attorney to represent him or her. The appellant shall have the right to bring a court reporter, at his or her own expense. 
(7)  The special magistrate shall consider the testimony, reports or other documentary evidence, and any other evidence presented at the hearing. Formal rules of evidence shall not apply, but fundamental due process shall govern the proceedings. 
(8)  The city shall bear the burden of proof by clear and convincing evidence that the trespass warning was properly issued pursuant to the criteria of this section. 
(9)  If the appellant fails to attend a scheduled hearing, the special magistrate shall review the evidence presented and determine if the trespass warning was properly issued pursuant to the criteria of this section. 
(10)  Within seven (7) business days of the hearing, the special magistrate shall issue a written decision on the appeal which shall be mailed to the appellant at the address provided or hand delivered. 
(11)  The decision of the special magistrate shall be final and the appellant shall be deemed to have exhausted all administrative remedies. Such decision may be subject to judicial review in the manner provided by law. 
    The trespass warning shall remain in effect during the appeal and review process, including any judicial review. 
(Ord. No. 2018-01, § 3(Exh. A), 2-26-18) 
Sec. 20-14. - City park operating hours. 
    All cemetery and park facilities owned and operated by the City of Palmetto are open from 30 minutes before sunrise to 30 minutes after sunset with the following exceptions: 
• Riverside Park East and West will be open 24 hours. 
• Sutton Park will be open from 30 minutes before sunrise to 10:00 p.m. 
• Lamb Park will be open from 30 minutes before sunrise to 11:00 p.m. 
• City of Palmetto Cemetery at 900 14 th Ave. West will be 30 minutes before sunrise to 10:00 p.m. 
• All walking trails in the city will be open 24 hours. 
    All park hours can be modified via a special function permit and approval by city commission. 
(Ord. No. 2018-01, § 3(Exh. A), 2-26-18; Res. No. 2018-14, § 2(Exh. A), 4-2-18; Res. No. 2018-41, § 2(Exh. A), 12-3-18) 
Secs. 20-15-20-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CRIMINAL NUISANCE ABATEMENT[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2012-05, § 1, adopted Mar. 19, 2012, amended Art. II in its entirety to read as set out herein. Former Art. II, §§ 20-51-20-58, pertained to drug-related nuisance abatement and derived from Ord. No. 336, §§ 1-8, adopted June 20, 1988. 

Sec. 20-51. - Declaration of public nuisance and definitions. 
(a)  The following places and premises are hereby declared to be a public nuisance in the City of Palmetto, and are subject to abatement pursuant to the procedures provided in this article: 
(1)  Any place or premises that has been used: 
a.  On more than two (2) occasions within a six-month period as the site of a violation of F.S. section 796.07; 
b.  On more than two (2) occasions within a six-month period, as the site of the unlawful sale, delivery, manufacture, or cultivation of any controlled substance; 
c.  On one (1) occasion as the site of the unlawful possession of a controlled substance, where such possession constitutes a felony and that has been previously used on more than one (1) occasion as the site of the unlawful sale, delivery, manufacture, or cultivation of any controlled substance; 
d.  By a criminal street gang or criminal street gang member as defined by F.S. section 874.03; or 
e.  On more than two (2) occasions within a six-month period as the site of a violation of F.S. section 812.019. 
(2)  Any pain management clinic, as described in F.S. section 458.3625 or F.S. section 459.0137 which has been used on more than two (2) occasions within a six-month period as the site of a violation of: 
a.  F.S. section 784.011, section 784.021, section 784.03 or section 784.045 relating to assault and battery; 
b.  F.S. section 810.02 relating to burglary; 
c.  F.S. section 812.014 relating to dealing in theft; 
d.  F.S. section 812.131 relating to robbery by sudden snatching; or 
e.  F.S. section 893.13 relating to the unlawful distribution of controlled substances. 
(b)  When used in this article, the term "controlled substances" shall include any substances sold in lieu of controlled substances in violation of F.S. section 817.563. 
(c)  When used in this article, the term "place" or "premises" shall be defined as the extent of fee ownership. For example, a multi-unit residential facility under common ownership shall be considered a single "place" or "premises", whereas a multi-family residential facility under condominium ownership shall be reviewed on a unit-by-unit basis. 
(Ord. No. 2012-05, § 1, 3-19-12) 
Sec. 20-52. - Complaint procedures. 
(a)  Any employee, officer, or resident of the city may file a complaint with the city police department alleging the existence of a public nuisance as defined in section 20-51, after first giving not less than three (3) days' written notice of such complaint to the owner of the premises sent via certified mail or hand delivered to owner's last known address. 
(b)  Upon the receipt of a complaint alleging activity meeting the definition of public nuisance in section 20-51, and complying with the notice provisions contained herein, the chief of police shall investigate the allegations and, if warranted, shall request a hearing before the criminal nuisance abatement board by providing notice to the city clerk with a copy to the mayor and city attorney. 
(c)  Upon receipt of such request for hearing, the clerk of the criminal nuisance abatement board shall schedule a hearing, and shall provide the owner of the premises with a minimum of fourteen (14) calendar days' written notice, sent via certified mail or hand delivered to the owner of the premises. The notice shall include a statement of the time, place and nature of the hearing, a reference to the specific sections of the ordinance or Florida Statutes alleged to have been violated, and a brief statement summarizing the facts underlying the allegations. 
(Ord. No. 2012-05, § 1, 3-19-12) 
Sec. 20-53. - Establishment and composition of the criminal nuisance abatement board. 
    The criminal nuisance abatement board is hereby established to carry out the duties and powers ascribed to it in this article. The board shall consist of five (5) members to be appointed by the mayor and approved by a majority vote of the city commission. The terms of the office shall be for two (2) years from the date of their appointment, except that the initial terms of two (2) members shall be only one (1) year from the date of their appointments. All subsequent terms shall be for two (2) years. Any vacancy occurring during the term of any member of the board shall be filled for the unexpired portion of the term. Any person who resides or is engaged in business, which means owning a business, practicing a profession, or performing a service for compensation, or serving as an officer or director of a corporation or other business entity so engaged, within the city shall be eligible for appointment to the criminal nuisance abatement board. 
(Ord. No. 2012-05, § 1, 3-19-12) 
Sec. 20-54. - Vacancies and removal of members. 
    In case of vacancies occurring in membership of the criminal nuisance abatement board, the city commission shall fill such vacancies within sixty (60) days or at least ten (10) days prior to a hearing. Any person appointed by the city commission to fill a vacancy shall serve for the unexpired term of the original appointment. Members of the criminal nuisance abatement board may be removed by majority vote of the city commission, in the event that the city commission determines that such action is in the best interest of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2012-05, § 1, 3-19-12) 
Sec. 20-55. - Officers; rules of procedure; meetings; compensation; counsel. 
(a)  The criminal nuisance abatement board shall elect a chair and a vice-chair from among its members. They shall serve for one-year terms. 
(b)  Subject to confirmation by the commission, the criminal nuisance abatement board shall adopt such additional rules as are necessary to conduct its affairs and in keeping with the provisions of this article. The city clerk, or the clerk's designee, shall be the clerk to the criminal nuisance abatement board and shall be responsible for keeping the records of the board's actions, providing necessary background material, keeping a record of attendance, keeping a record of all official actions of the board, including the vote of the members on each question requiring a vote, or if absent or abstaining from voting, indicating such fact. 
(c)  The criminal nuisance abatement board shall meet on an as-needed basis. The board shall not transact any business at any meeting unless a quorum of three (3) members is present, and every official action taken and every decision rendered by the board shall be approved by a majority of the board members present. If necessary, the board may continue any matter before it. 
(d)  Members of the criminal nuisance abatement board shall receive no compensation. 
(e)  The criminal nuisance abatement board shall be represented by independent legal counsel. 
(Ord. No. 2012-05, § 1, 3-19-12) 
Sec. 20-56. - Conduct of hearings. 
(a)  The chief of police, or the chief's designee, shall present cases before the criminal nuisance abatement board and shall be represented by the city attorney's office. Both parties shall have the opportunity to present evidence and to cross-examine witnesses. When authorized by the board, members of the public may be permitted oral or written testimony or evidence for consideration by the board, but both parties shall be given the opportunity to cross-examine, challenge or rebut such evidence or testimony. The board shall consider all evidence presented, including evidence of the general reputation of the premises. The board will not be bound by the Florida Rules of Evidence and may receive and consider hearsay or other evidence not admissible under the Florida Rules of Evidence. 
(b)  At the conclusion of the hearing, the board may declare the place or premises to be a public nuisance as defined in section 20-51, and may enter an order: 
(1)  Immediately prohibiting the maintaining of the nuisance; 
(2)  Immediately prohibiting the operating or maintaining of the place or premises, including the closure of the place or premises or any part thereof; or 
(3)  Immediately prohibiting the conduct, operation or maintenance of any business or activity on the premises which is conducive to such nuisance. 
    The chief of police, or his designee, shall notify the commission of any action taken by the board. 
(c)  An order entered under subsection (b) shall expire after one (1) year or at such earlier time as stated in the order. 
(Ord. No. 2012-05, § 1, 3-19-12) 
Sec. 20-57. - Enforcement. 
(a)  An order of the criminal nuisance abatement board may be enforced by any or all of the following procedures: 
(1)  The city may pursue enforcement pursuant to the provisions contained in F.S. section 120.69. 
(2)  The city may bring a complaint under F.S. section 60.05 seeking temporary and permanent injunctive relief. 
(3)  The city may bring an enforcement action before the criminal nuisance abatement board. An enforcement action before the criminal nuisance abatement board shall follow the notice provisions in subsection 20-52(c) and the hearing procedures in subsection 20-56(a). 
(b)  Upon a finding by the court or by the criminal nuisance abatement board that an order issued pursuant to subsection 20-56(b) has been violated, the following penalties may be imposed by the board, in addition to the other remedies available at law: 
(1)  Imposing fines not to exceed two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) per day. 
(2)  Requiring the payment of the reasonable costs, including reasonable attorneys fees, associated with the investigations of and hearings related to the public nuisance. 
(3)  Providing for continuing jurisdiction for a period of one (1) year over any place or premises declared to be or have been a public nuisance. 
(4)  Imposing fines not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) per day for recurring public nuisances. 
(5)  Providing for the recording of the order so that notice must be given to subsequent purchasers, successors in interest, or assigns, of the real property that is subject to the order. 
(6)  Providing that the recorded order shall be a lien against the real property that is subject to the order. 
(7)  Providing for the foreclosure of the property subject to a lien, and the recovery of all costs, including reasonable attorney's fees, associated with the recording of orders and foreclosure. 
(c)  Any lien arising from fines or costs imposed pursuant to this section, shall run in favor of the city, and only the city commission shall be authorized to reduce a lien amount and execute a release of satisfaction of lien for that amount. The mayor shall be authorized to execute a release of satisfaction of lien where the full amount of the lien is being paid. 
(d)  The total fines imposed pursuant to this section shall not exceed fifteen thousand dollars ($15,000.00) 
(e)  No lien created under this section may be foreclosed on real property which is a homestead under Section 4, Article X of the Florida Constitution. 
(f)  Where an enforcement action is brought based on a stolen property nuisance, against a property owner operating an establishment where multiple tenants on one (1) site conduct their own retail businesses, the property owner shall not be subject to a lien against the property or the prohibition of operation provision if the property owner evicts the business declared to be a nuisance within ninety (90) days after notification by registered mail to the property owner of a second stolen property conviction of the tenant. 
(Ord. No. 2012-05, § 1, 3-19-12) 
Secs. 20-57-20-69. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - ALARM SYSTEMS 

Sec. 20-70. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Alarm business means the business engaged in by any individual, partnership, corporation or other entity of selling, leasing, maintaining, servicing, repairing, altering, replacing, moving, monitoring or installing any alarm system, or causing any alarm system to be sold, leased, maintained, serviced, repaired, altered, replaced, moved, monitored or installed, in or on any property, both real and personal, building, structure or facility. 
    Alarm noise means the sound and/or signal of an alarm system. 
    Alarm system means any device designed for the detection of unauthorized entry or for alerting others of the commission of an unlawful act, or of the need of medical assistance, or the need for emergency evacuation, which, when activated, emits a sound and/or transmits a signal beyond the premises. 
    Alarm user means any individual, partnership, corporation or other entity that owns, leases and/or is in control of the premises and/or property where an alarm system is located. 
    Automatic telephone dialing device or digital alarm communicator system means an alarm system which automatically sends a prerecorded voice message, coded signal or other similar communication over regular telephone lines by direct connection or otherwise, indicating the existence of the emergency situation that the alarm system is designed to detect. 
    Enforcement official means the chief of police, city clerk, code enforcement officer, or any of their designated representatives. 
    False alarm means the activation of an alarm system whereby alarm noise or an alarm signal occurs through mechanical failure, malfunction, improper installation or maintenance; or because of the negligent or intentional misuse of the system by the owner, lessee, occupant or manager of the premises and/or property where the alarm system is located; or because of negligence or misuse of the system by an employee, servant or agent of such person; or any other occurrence of alarm noise not caused by a forced entry, attempted forced entry, robbery or burglary; or other emergency or occurrence which the alarm system was designed to detect; or not caused by fire, heat, smoke or medical emergency; provided, however, "false alarm" does not include alarms caused by acts of God or by external power failure or those alarms intentionally activated by an owner, lessee, occupant or manager of the premises, who visually observed or heard suspicious circumstances which would cause a careful and prudent person to believe that a fire, forced entry, robbery, burglary or other felony or emergency or circumstance had occurred or was in progress which the alarm system was designed to detect. 
    Fine means the assessment of a monetary charge, as authorized pursuant to this article, to defray the expense of, response to, investigation of and potential liability of emergency response to false alarms. 
    Key holder means a person or persons who are authorized to enter the premises and designated as having the responsibility for deactivation of an alarm system and securing the property. The key holder may be an alarm user (as defined herein), an owner (as defined herein), or any other person designated by the alarm user or owner of the property that the alarm is located at. 
    Owner means any person who owns the premises and/or property in which an alarm system exists or any person who possesses, leases, operates, occupies or manages the premises. 
    Premises means any building, structure or combination of buildings and structures which serve as dwellings, single or multifamily; or any area within a building, structure or combination thereof which is used for any purpose other than residential wherein an alarm system exists. 
(Ord. No. 2016-07, § 2, 6-6-16) 
Sec. 20-71. - Exemption from article provisions. 
    The provisions of this article shall not be applicable to alarm systems affixed to motor vehicles or equipment. 
(Ord. No. 2016-07, § 2, 6-6-16) 
Sec. 20-72. - Responsibility for false alarm. 
    For the purposes of this article, the responsibility for a false alarm shall be that of the alarm user. A response to a false alarm shall result when any police officer or enforcement official shall be dispatched to the premises and/or property where the alarm noise has been transmitted or emitted from or learns of such transmission or emission, by any means whatsoever, and responds thereto by traveling to the premises and/or property. After responding and determining the alarm to be a false alarm, the enforcement official shall notify any person identified as a key holder for the location. If the enforcement official requests a response from the key holder, such person shall travel to the location of the alarm to deactivate the alarm system or otherwise assist the police officer or enforcement official in resolving suspicious or other circumstances at the location. Persons designated as having the responsibility for deactivation of an alarm system must appear within thirty (30) minutes after being notified to do so. Failure to do so shall constitute a violation subject to fines payable by the alarm user and pursuant to the provisions of section 20-77. 
    Reasons that a police officer or enforcement official will require a response of a key holder to a false alarm include: 
(1)  An alarm that will not reset or that otherwise continues to generate alarm noise (as defined herein); 
(2)  Evidence of a crime at the location of the alarm; 
(3)  Any condition that leaves the premises or location unsecure; 
(4)  Any other situation or circumstances at the location of the alarm that requires a key holder, alarm user, or owner. 
(Ord. No. 2016-07, § 2, 6-6-16) 
Sec. 20-73. - Maintenance standards. 
    It shall be the obligation and responsibility of the alarm user to ensure that an alarm system is installed and maintained sufficiently to avoid false alarms. Nothing in this article shall prohibit an alarm user from contracting with private persons to maintain an alarm system and assume responsibility for false alarms; provided, that such a contract shall not affect the responsibilities provided for in this article. 
(Ord. No. 2016-07, § 2, 6-6-16) 
Sec. 20-74. - Effect on, conflict with fire codes. 
    Nothing in this article shall be construed to repealing or modifying any provision of existing, applicable fire codes; and to the extent that the provisions of this article conflict with applicable fire codes, the fire codes shall control. 
(Ord. No. 2016-07, § 2, 6-6-16) 
Sec. 20-75. - Automatic telephone dialing alarm device or digital alarm communicator system. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to install, maintain, operate or use any automatic telephone dialing alarm device, digital alarm communicator system or other similar device or appliance within the city if the system requires connection to the emergency communications center of the police or fire department. 
(Ord. No. 2016-07, § 2, 6-6-16) 
Sec. 20-76. - Violations. 
    The following activities shall constitute a violation of this article: 
(1)  For any premises within the city (commercial or residential) to have more than two (2) false alarms within any calendar year. 
(2)  Failure of the alarm user of any residential dwelling or unit to provide the name, address and telephone number of at least two (2) persons who are key holders. A violation of this section shall be waived if the alarm user provides documentation or proof establishing that two (2) key holders were provided to the alarm business by the alarm user. 
(3)  Failure of the representative designated pursuant to section 20-72 to respond to an alarm within thirty (30) minutes after being notified to do so. 
(4)  Failure to otherwise comply with the provisions of this article. 
    All violations shall subject the alarm user to the penalties stated herein. 
(Ord. No. 2016-07, § 2, 6-6-16) 
Sec. 20-77. - Enforcement procedures. 
(a)  This article shall be enforced pursuant to division 3 of article IV of chapter 2 of the Code of Ordinances. 
(b)  City police department officials and/or city code enforcement officials shall track the occurrence of all false alarms in the city (commercial or residential) and will document all alarm violations in the city during a calendar year. 
(Ord. No. 2016-07, § 2, 6-6-16) 
Chapter 21 - MOBILE HOMES[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Code enforcement, § 2-81 et seq.; buildings and building regulations, Ch. 7; coastal areas and waterways, Ch. 10; fire prevention and protection, Ch. 13; garbage, trash and refuse, Ch. 15; health and sanitation, Ch. 16; procedure for abatement of nuisances involving excessive growth of weeds or other noxious plants, accumulations of trash, fill and other matter, excavations or depressions in which pools of water are located, § 16-26 et seq.; housing, Ch. 17; junked, wrecked, abandoned property, Ch. 18; planning and development, Ch. 23; streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 25; subdivisions, Ch. 26; utilities, Ch. 29; zoning code, App. B. 

Sec. 21-1. - Exclusion. 
    This chapter shall not apply to licensed rental trailer parks operating within the city. 
(Code 1975, § 16-15) 
Sec. 21-2. - Permit required. 
    A permit shall be secured from the building inspector before a house trailer or mobile home may be placed upon any private property in the city even though such property is zoned for trailer residences. 
(Code 1975, § 16-16) 
Sec. 21-3. - Conformance with technical codes. 
    All mobile homes and house trailers set up within this city under the provisions of this chapter shall conform to all applicable provisions of the various building, electrical, plumbing, sanitary and other technical codes adopted by this city. 
(Code 1975, § 16-17) 
Sec. 21-4. - Connection to water, sewer systems required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any mobile home or automobile trailer to park within the city, for living purposes therein, except in a duly licensed and authorized mobile home or trailer park or unless such mobile home or trailer car is so parked as to have sewage and water connections with the city sewer and water systems. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate or maintain any mobile home or automobile trailer park within the city, unless such trailer park is connected with the city sewer and water systems. 
(Code 1975, § 16-3) 
Cross reference- Utilities, Ch. 29. 
Sec. 21-5. - Manner of placement. 
    All mobile home or house trailers shall be placed upon lots with the trailer hitch facing a street. 
(Code 1975, § 16-18) 
Sec. 21-6. - Minimum lot size, setbacks. 
    All mobile home or house trailer lots shall be a minimum of fifty (50) feet in width, three thousand (3,000) square feet in area, and there shall be a minimum yard size of five (5) feet each front, rear and side, to be measured from the property line to the nearest building wall. 
(Code 1975, § 16-19) 
Sec. 21-7. - Foundation requirements. 
    All mobile homes or house trailers shall be blocked and/or mounted on masonry piers having a depth of not less than four (4) inches, shall be of solid masonry, not open-core block, and shall be installed under the mobile home a maximum of ten (10) feet on the center of each side of the mobile home frame. 
(Code 1975, § 16-20) 
Sec. 21-8. - Temporary uses. 
(a)  One (1) manufactured building may be used in any zoning district as a temporary office or sales office incidental to construction of the premises upon which the mobile home is located where the valuation on the face of the building permit which applies to the premises exceeds five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00). One (1) manufactured building may also be used as a temporary residence for a watchman guarding such a construction site during construction, but no such residential use shall be allowed until a water and sewer hookup has been obtained for the manufactured building A mobile home may be utilized for the purposes set forth herein in those zoning districts that permit mobile homes. Any manufactured building or mobile home use allowed by this section shall be limited to the time period during which an active building permit is in place. 
(b)  The building contractor of the project shall apply to the city's building department for a permit for mobile homes or manufactured buildings regulated by this section. 
(c)  In no event shall the use continue for more than one hundred eighty (180) days without the approval of the building official, who may grant extensions upon finding that the requirements of this section are met. 
(d)  This section shall also allow for contractor's construction of a manufactured building where such building is to be utilized for the purposes set forth in this section. A valid building permit shall serve as the contractor's permit for the construction of such manufactured building. 
(e)  Any and all mobile homes or manufactured buildings regulated by this section must be maintained in good condition and must comply with all other codes, ordinances and statutes applicable thereto. 
(f)  Any and all mobile homes or manufactured buildings regulated by this section shall be removed from the construction site no later than fifteen (15) days after completion of the project or the expiration of a valid building permit, whichever occurs first. 
(g)  This section shall be enforced as provided for by Florida law, including but not limited to enforcement mechanisms provided for in the Florida Building Code, referral or citation to the code enforcement board, issuance of a notice of nuisance as may be provided for by city ordinance, or the filing of an action in a court of competent jurisdiction to obtain civil remedies. Any enumeration of enforcement mechanisms set forth herein is supplemental and not exclusive. The city shall be entitled to collect reasonable attorney's fees, costs of enforcement and other costs or fees reasonably related to obtaining compliance with this Code. 
(Ord. No. 274, § 1, 7-21-86; Ord. No. 08-959, § 2, 2-18-08)

ARTICLE III. - SOCIAL SECURITY[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2. 
State Law reference- Social security for public employees, F.S. Ch. 650. 

Sec. 22-56. - Exclusion. 
    There is hereby excluded from this article any authority to make any agreement with respect to any position or any employee or official now covered, or authorized to be covered, by any other ordinance or law creating any retirement system for any employee or official of the city. 
(Code 1975, § 2-91) 
Sec. 22-57. - Adoption of law. 
    The city does hereby adopt the terms, conditions, requirements, reservations, benefits, privileges and other conditions thereunto appertaining of Title II of the Social Security Act, as amended by Public Law No. 734 of the 81st Congress, for and on behalf of all the officers and employees thereof and of its departments and agencies, except any of such officers and employees now covered or authorized to be covered by any retirement system provided by law or any official or employee who occupies any position, office or employment not authorized to be covered by applicable state or federal laws or regulations. 
(Code 1975, § 2-92) 
Sec. 22-58. - Extension of benefits. 
    It is hereby declared to be the policy and purpose of the city to extend, effective as of October 1, 1951, to the employees and officials thereof not excluded by law, and whether employed in connection with a governmental or proprietary function, the benefits of the system of old-age and survivors insurance as authorized by the Federal Social Security Act and amendments thereto, including Public Law No. 734 of the 81st Congress, and by F.S. Ch. 650; and to cover by such plan all services which constitute employment as defined in section 2 of F.S. Ch. 650 performed in the employ of this city by employees thereof. In pursuance of this policy, and for that purpose, the city shall take such action as may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations. 
(Code 1975, § 2-86) 
Sec. 22-59. - Withholdings from salaries. 
    Withholdings from salaries, wages or other compensation of employees and officials for the purpose of this article are hereby authorized to be made, and shall be made, in the amounts and at such times as may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations, and shall be paid over to the state agency designated by such laws or regulations to receive such amounts. 
(Code 1975, § 2-88) 
Sec. 22-60. - City's contributions. 
    There shall be appropriated from available funds, derived from the general fund of the city, such amounts at such times as may be required to pay promptly the contributions to the system of old-age and survivors insurance required of the city as employer by applicable state or federal laws or regulations, which shall be paid over to the lawfully designated state agency at the times and in the manner provided by law and regulation. 
(Code 1975, § 2-89) 
Sec. 22-61. - Custodian of funds. 
    The city clerk is hereby designated the custodian of all sums withheld from the compensation of officers and employees and of the appropriated funds for the contribution of the city for the purposes of this article. The city clerk is hereby made the withholding and reporting agent and is charged with the duty of maintaining personnel records for the purposes of this article. 
(Code 1975, § 2-93) 
Sec. 22-62. - Records, reports. 
    The city shall keep such records and make such reports as may be required by state or federal laws or regulations, applicable to this article and shall adhere to the rules and regulations of the state agency for the enforcement of these laws and regulations. 
(Code 1975, § 2-90) 
Secs. 22-63-22-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - GENERAL EMPLOYEES' RETIREMENT SYSTEM[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note- Sections 1-27 of Ord. No. 575, adopted November, 4, 1996, amended Article IV, §§ 22-81-22-94, §§ 22-111-22-130, and §§ 22-146-2-155, in its entirety. Formerly, said article pertained to the same subject matter. See the Code Comparative Table for derivation of said sections. 

Sec. 22-81. - Definitions. 
    As used herein, unless otherwise defined or required by the context, the following words and phrases shall have the meaning indicated: 
    Accumulated contributions means a member's own contributions with interest at the rate of five (5) percent from January 1, 1986 to October 1, 1996 and the rate of four (4) percent per annum, subsequent to October 1, 1996 but only for persons who are employed beyond their probationary period. For those members who purchase credited service with interest or at no cost to the system, any payment representing the amount attributable to member contributions based on the applicable member contribution rate, any payment representing interest and any required actuarially calculated payments for the purchase of such credited service, shall be included in accumulated contributions, without the crediting of interest for non-vested members and with interest for members who are vested. 
    Actuarial equivalent means a benefit or amount of equal value, based upon the RP-2000 Combined Healthy Unisex Mortality Table and an interest rate equal to the investment return assumption set forth in the last actuarial valuation report approved by the board. This definition may only be amended by the city pursuant to the recommendation of the board using assumptions adopted by the board with the advice of the plan's actuary, such that actuarial assumptions are not subject to city discretion. 
    Average final compensation means one-twelfth ( 1/12 ) of the average salary of the five (5) best years of the last ten (10) years of credited service prior to retirement, termination, or death, or the career average as a fulltime general employee, whichever is greater. A year shall be twelve (12) consecutive months. 
    Beneficiary means the person entitled to receive benefits hereunder at the death of a member who has or have been designated in writing by the member and filed with the board. If no such designation is in effect, or if no person so designated is living, at the time of death of the member, the beneficiary shall be the estate of the member. 
    Board means the board of trustees, which shall administer and manage the system herein provided and serve as trustees of the fund. 
    City means City of Palmetto, Florida. 
    Code means the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 as amended from time to time. 
    Credited service means the total number of years and fractional parts of years of service as a general employee with member contributions, when required, omitting intervening years or fractional parts of years when such member was not employed by the city as a general employee. A member may voluntarily leave his accumulated contributions, if any, in the fund for a period of five (5) years after leaving the employ of the city pending the possibility of being reemployed as a general employee, without losing credit for the time that he was a member of the system. If a non-vested member should not be reemployed as a general employee within five (5) years, then his accumulated contributions, if one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) or less, will be returned. If a member who is not vested is not reemployed within five (5) years, his accumulated contributions, if more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), will be returned only upon the written request of the member and upon completion of a written election to receive a cash lump sum or to roll over the lump sum amount on forms designated by the board. If a vested member leaves the employ of the city, his accumulated contributions will be returned only upon his written request. A member shall be given credit for all periods of employment for which no member contributions were required. Upon return of a member's accumulated contributions, all of his rights and benefits under the system are forfeited and terminated. However, if a terminated employee receives a payment pursuant to subsection 22-89(a), (b) or (c) and is subsequently reemployed by the city, his prior credited service shall be reinstated only if the member repays to the fund the amount of his entire prior distribution, with interest at five (5) percent per annum, compounded annually from date of distribution to date of repayment. 
    A member shall be given a credited service for the entire month in which his employment with the city commences or terminates. A member shall be given credited service during an authorized leave of absence without pay provided the member returns to the employment with the city upon the expiration of such leave and pays the contributions to the fund within sixty (60) days which he would have been paid at his normal rate of salary during his absence. If a member does not return to employment with the city upon the expiration of an authorized leave of absence or make the required payment, he will not be given credited service for the pay period of such leave. 
    In the event that a member of this system has also accumulated credited service in the police officers' retirement system maintained by the city, then such other credited service shall be used in determining vesting as provided for in section 22-89, and for determining eligibility for early or normal retirement. Such other credited service will not be considered in determining benefits under this system. Only his credited service and salary under this system on or after his date of membership in this system will be considered for benefit calculation. In addition, any benefit calculation for a member of this system who is or becomes eligible for a benefit from this system after he has become a member of another pension system maintained by the city, shall be based upon the members average final compensation, credited service and benefit accrual rate as of the date the member ceased to be a general employee. 
    The years or parts of a year that a member performs "qualified military service" consisting of voluntary or involuntary "service in the uniformed services" as defined in the Uniformed Services Employment and Reemployment Rights Act (USERRA) (P.L.103-353), after separation from employment as a general employee to perform training or service, shall be added to his years of credited service for all purposes, including vesting, provided that: 
(1)  The member is entitled to reemployment under the provisions of USERRA. 
(2)  The member returns to his employment as a general employee within one (1) year following the earlier of the date of his military discharge or his release from service, unless otherwise required by USERRA. 
(3)  The member deposits into the fund the same sum that the member would have contributed, if any, if he had remained a general employee during his absence. The maximum credit for military service pursuant to this subdivision shall be five (5) years. The member must deposit all missed contributions within a period equal to three (3) times the period of military service, but not more than five (5) years, following reemployment or he will forfeit the right to receive credited service for his military service pursuant to this paragraph. 
(4)  This paragraph is intended to satisfy the minimum requirements of USERRA. To the extent that this paragraph does not meet the minimum standards of USERRA, as it may be amended from time to time, the minimum standards shall apply. 
    In the event a member dies on or after January 1, 2007, while performing USERRA qualified military service, the beneficiaries of the member are entitled to any benefits (other than benefit accruals relating to the period of qualified military service) as if the member had resumed employment and then died while employed. 
    Beginning January 1, 2009, to the extent required by Section 414(u)(12) of the Internal Revenue Code, an individual receiving differential wage payments (as defined under section 3401(h)(2) of the code) from an employer shall be treated as employed by that employer, and the differential wage payment shall be treated as compensation for purposes of applying the limits on annual additions under Section 415(c) of the Internal Revenue Code. This provision shall be applied to all similarly situated individuals in a reasonably equivalent manner. 
    Leave conversions of unused accrued paid time off shall not be permitted to be applied toward the accrual of credited service either during each plan year of a member's employment with the city or in the plan year in which the member terminates employment. 
    Effective date means October 1, 1996. 
    Fund means the trust fund established herein as part of the system. 
    General employee means any actively employed person in the regular fulltime service of the city, including those in their initial probationary employment period, but not including certified police officers employed by the city. 
    Member means an actively employed general employee who fulfills the prescribed membership requirements.
