ARTICLE II. - PUBLIC SERVICE TAX[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Utilities, Ch. 29; franchises, App. A, 
State Law reference- Public service tax, F.S. §§ 166.231, 166.232. 

Sec. 27-26. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Purchaser means any person acting as a unit who purchases or causes to be purchased electricity or metered or bottled gas, natural or manufactured, within the city. 
    Seller means any person acting as a unit who sells, furnishes or delivers for sale or who causes to be sold, furnished or delivered for sale electricity or metered or bottled gas, natural or manufactured, within the city. 
    Utility service means the purchase, sale, delivery or receipt of electricity or metered or bottled gas, natural or manufactured. 
(Code 1975, §§ 26-35, 26-55; Ord. No. 296, § 1, 1-5-87) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 27-27. - Levied, amount. 
(a)  There is hereby levied by the city on each and every sale in this city of electricity and metered or bottled gas, natural or manufactured, a tax upon such purchases within the municipality in an amount equal to ten (10) percent of the payments received by the seller of the taxable item from the purchaser for the purchase of such service. The tax in every case shall be paid by the purchaser, for the use of the city, to the seller of such electricity and gas, upon paying the charges to the seller, but not less often than monthly. 
(b)  There is hereby imposed and levied by the city on each and every purchase of fuel oil in the corporate limits of the city a tax in the amount of four cents ($0.04) per gallon. This tax shall be paid by the consumer to the seller of fuel oil, and the seller shall remit the tax to the offices of the city clerk not less often than monthly. 
(Code 1975, §§ 26-37, 26-54; Ord. No. 269, § 1, 6-2-86; Ord. No. 296, § 3, 1-5-87; Ord. No. 345, § 2, 9-19-88) 
Sec. 27-28. - Exempt purchasers. 
(a)  All federal, state, county and municipal governments, their commissions and agencies, all public schools, and all churches recognized in this state where utility services are used exclusively for church purposes, shall be exempt from the payment of the taxes imposed and levied by this article. 
(b)  Purchasers of electrical energy who are eligible for the exemption provided in F.S. § 212.08(14) pursuant to rules promulgated by the department of revenue, shall be exempt from payment of fifty (50) percent of the tax imposed and levied by this article on the purchase of electrical energy. 
(c)  Pursuant to F.S. § 166.231(8), the city grants an exemption of fifty (50) percent of the municipal tax imposed for purchases of electrical energy on purchasers of electrical energy who are determined by the state department of revenue, pursuant to F.S. § 212.08(15), to be a qualified business at a fixed location in an enterprise zone. Such enterprise zone is more particularly described in resolution number 95-06 which is on file in the city clerk's office. 
(Code 1975, § 26-38; Ord. No. 280, § 1, 9-2-86; Ord. No. 296, § 4, 1-5-87; Ord. No. 554, § 2, 12-4-95) 
State Law reference- Churches exempt, F.S. § 166.231(5). 
Sec. 27-29. - Exclusions from tax on fuel oil. 
    There is excluded from the tax levied and imposed by section 27-27(b): 
(1)  Purchases of special fuels as defined in F.S. Ch. 206; 
(2)  The purchase of not more than five (5) gallons of fuel oil delivered at the seller's place of business into the purchaser's container of not more than five (5) gallons' capacity; and 
(3)  The purchase of fuel oil for use in the propulsion of ships, motorboats, aircraft, railroad trains and other media of transportation. 
(Code 1975, § 26-56) 
Sec. 27-30. - Fuel adjustment charges. 
    The tax imposed by this article shall not be applied against any fuel adjustment charge, and such charge shall be separately stated on each bill. Fuel adjustment charge means all increases in the cost of utility services to the ultimate consumer resulting from an increase in the cost of fuel to the utility subsequent to October 1, 1973. 
(Code 1975, § 26-45) 
Sec. 27-31. - Bottled gas invoices. 
(a)  All persons selling bottled gas within the city shall, at the time of each sale and not later than the time when delivery is made, prepare an invoice setting forth the following information: 
(1)  The date of sale; 
(2)  The vendor; 
(3)  The vendee; 
(4)  The vendee's address; 
(5)  A description of goods sold and the gross amount of the sale; 
(6)  The amount of the city utility tax applicable to the sale. 
(b)  The invoices referred to in this section shall be typed or block printed and shall be completely legible. 
(c)  At each time tax payments are delivered to the city by the sellers of bottled gas, the invoices or copies thereof, together with an adding machine tape of the utility tax applicable, shall be delivered to the city with the tax payment. 
(d)  Each seller of bottled gas within the city shall deliver to the city each month a report on the sales made that month, together with the invoices and adding machine tapes referred to in this section, or if no sales were made that month, a sworn statement stating that no sales had been made that month on which the city utility tax was applicable. 
(Code 1975, § 26-43.1) 
Sec. 27-32. - Computation. 
    In all cases where a seller of electricity, fuel oil, or metered or bottled gas, natural or manufactured, collects the price thereof at monthly periods, the tax hereby levied may be computed on the aggregate amount of sales during such period; provided that the amount of tax collected shall be the nearest whole cent to the amount computed. 
(Code 1975, § 26-44; Ord. No. 296, § 7, 1-5-87) 
Sec. 27-33. - Seller's duty to collect. 
    It shall be the duty of every seller of electricity, fuel oil, or metered or bottled gas, natural or manufactured, within the city to collect from the purchaser, for the use of the city, the tax levied by this article at the time of collecting the selling price and to report and pay over to the city, on or before the fifteenth day of each calendar month, all such taxes levied and collected during the preceding calendar month. 
(Code 1975, § 26-39; Ord. No. 296, § 5, 1-5-87) 
Sec. 27-34. - Records required. 
    Each seller of electricity, fuel oil or metered or bottled gas, natural or manufactured, shall keep complete records showing all sales in the city of such commodities. Such records shall show the price charged upon each sale, the date of sale and the date of payment. Such records shall be kept open for inspection by the duly authorized agents of the city during business hours on all business days. Such duly authorized agents of the city shall have the right, power and authority to make any transcripts from these records during such times as they may desire. 
(Code 1975, § 26-43; Ord. No. 296, § 6, 1-5-87) 
Secs. 27-35-27-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - TELECOMMUNICATIONS SERVICE TAX[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- General telephone company franchise, App. A, art. II. 
State Law reference- Public services tax on telecommunications services authorized, F.S. § 166.231(9). 

Sec. 27-51. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Purchase means every act or transaction whereby possession of, utilization of, or control over telecommunications services becomes vested in the purchaser within the city for which payment is made pursuant to a duty and obligation therefor. 
    Purchase within city means the communication originates or terminates within the city and is billed to a purchaser, telephone or telephone number, or telecommunications number or device within the city. 
    Purchaser means every person legally liable for the payment of telecommunications services rendered to him by a seller. 
    Seller means every person rendering telecommunications services to any purchaser. 
    Telecommunications service means telecommunication service which originates and terminates in this state, excluding public telephone charges collected on-site, access charges, any customer access line charges paid to a local telephone company, and intrastate toll charges billed to a telephone number other than the originating or terminating telephone number located within the city; provided, however, purchases within the city of telecommunications services as defined in F.S. § 203.012(5)(b), shall be taxed only on the monthly recurring customer service charges, excluding variable usage charges. 
(Ord. No. 296, § 8, 1-5-87) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 27-52. - Levied, amount. 
    There is hereby levied and imposed by the city, upon every purchase within the city of telecommunications services and competitive services, a public service tax which shall be determined as follows: 
(1)  Seven (7) percent of the payments received by the seller from the purchaser for the purchase of telecommunications services within the city which originates and terminates in this state. Services competitive with those enumerated above shall be taxed on a comparable base at the same rate. 
(2)  The amount of tax shall be exclusive of governmental charges and other taxes charged. 
(3)  The amount of such tax shall be entered and shown by the seller as a separate item on each bill delivered to the purchaser and shall become due and payable to the city whenever such bill becomes due and payable under the rules and regulations of the seller, to the extent that such bills are subsequently paid. 
(4)  The purchaser shall pay such tax to the seller, as agent for the city, at the time of the payment of each such bill. 
(Ord. No. 296, § 8, 1-5-87; Ord. No. 346, § 2, 9-19-88) 
Sec. 27-53. - Exemptions. 
    Purchases of the telecommunications services by the United States government, the state, the county, a municipality, any recognized church in this state if used exclusively for church purposes, and purchases of local telephone service or other telecommunications service for use in the conduct of telecommunications services for hire or otherwise for resale are exempt from taxation under this article. 
(Ord. No. 296, § 8, 1-5-87) 
Sec. 27-54. - Seller's duties and compensation. 
(a)  The seller shall be allowed one (1) percent of the amount of the tax levied in this article collected and due to the city in the form of a deduction from the amount collected for remittance. The deduction is allowed as compensation for the keeping of records and collection and remittance of the tax. 
(b)  The seller shall collect such tax from purchasers at the time of the payment of each bill and remit the tax to the city in accordance with subsection (c) of this section. 
(c)  Every seller shall pay to the city, not later than the twentieth day of each month, the amount of tax collected during the preceding month to which the city is entitled. Every seller shall also file, at the time of payment, a statement setting forth the tax collected and the amount due the city. 
(d)  Every seller shall establish and maintain appropriate accounts and records of the tax as prescribed and required by the Federal Communications Commission and the Public Service Commission, and such accounts and records shall be open to inspection by duly authorized officers of the city at all reasonable times where maintained by the seller. 
(Ord. No. 296, § 8, 1-5-87) 
Secs. 27-55-27-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - INSURANCE PREMIUMS[4]

Sec. 27-71. - Levied. 
    There is hereby assessed, imposed and levied on every insurance company, corporation or other insurer engaging in or carrying on the business of insuring with respect to casualty risks, as shown by the records of the state insurance commissioners, an excise tax in addition to any license tax or excise tax now levied by the city, which tax shall be in the amount of one (1) percent of the gross amount of receipts of premiums from policyholders on all premiums collected on casualty insurance policies, covering property within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Code 1975, § 2-76)

ARTICLE V. - HISTORICAL PRESERVATION PROPERTY TAX EXEMPTION PROGRAM 

Sec. 27-81. - Purpose; exemption authorized. 
    This article shall be described as and provide for an historical preservation property tax exemption program of the city. 
    The city hereby authorizes ad valorem tax exemption for historic properties pursuant to F.S. sections 196.1997 and 196.1998, (1997). 
(Ord. No. 619, § A, 8-17-98) 
Sec. 27-82. - Definitions. 
    The following words and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the following meanings: 
    Administrative official shall mean the city clerk or designee. 
    Contributing property shall mean a building, site, structure or object which adds to the historical architectural qualities, historic associations or archaeological values for which a district is significant because: 
(1)  It was present during the period of significance of the district and possesses historic integrity reflecting its character at that time; or, 
(2)  It is capable of yielding important information about the period; or, 
(3)  It independently meets the National Register of Historic Places criteria for evaluation set forth in the land use and development regulations and comprehensive plan of the city. 
    Eligible improvement shall mean changes to the interior and/or exterior condition of real property brought about by the expenditure of labor or money for the restoration, renovation or rehabilitation of such property. Improvements include additions and accessory structures (i.e., a garage) necessary for efficient contemporary use. 
    Eligible property shall mean a site, building, structure or object that, at the time an exemption is granted, is, and is certified to the city council by the historic preservation division to be: 
(1)  Individually designated on the National Register of Historic Places; or, 
(2)  A contributing property in a national register listed historic district; or, 
(3)  Designated as a historic property or landmark under the provisions of a city historic preservation ordinance; or, 
(4)  A contribution property in a historic district designated by an appropriate city ordinance. 
    Government or nonprofit purpose shall mean at least sixty-five (65) percent of the usable space of a historic building is occupied or used by an agency of the federal, state or local government or nonprofit corporation whose articles of incorporation have been filed by the Department of State (DOS) in accordance with F.S. section 617.0125. 
    Preservation exemption covenant shall mean the historic preservation property tax exemption covenant paralleling Florida DOS Form No. HR3E111292 or other subsequently applicable Florida DOS form, which indicates that the owner agrees to maintain and repair the historic property so as to preserve the architectural, historical or archaeological integrity of the property during the exemption period. 
    Regularly and frequently open to the public shall mean public access to the property is provided not less than fifty-two (52) days a year on an equitably spaced basis, and at other times by appointment. The owner may charge a reasonable nondiscriminatory admission fee. 
    Renovation or rehabilitation shall mean the act or process of returning a historic property or portion thereof that is of historical or architectural significance to a state of utility through repair or alteration which makes possible an efficient contemporary use while preserving those portions or features of the property which are significant to its historical, architectural, cultural and archaeological values. For historic properties or portions thereof that are of archaeological significance or are severely deteriorated, renovation or rehabilitation shall mean the act or process of applying measures designed to sustain and protect the existing form and integrity of a property, or re-establish the stability of an unsafe or deteriorated property while maintaining the essential form of the property as it presently exists. 
    Restoration shall mean the act or process of accurately recovering the form and details of a property and its setting as it appeared at a particular period of time by means of the removal of later work or by the replacement of missing earlier work. 
(Ord. No. 619, § A, 8-17-98) 
Sec. 27-83. - Scope and duration of tax exemptions. 
(a)  The city council may grant an ad valorem tax exemption for eligible improvements to eligible properties made after January 1, 1999. The exemption will be for one hundred (100) percent of the assessed value of the eligible improvements, and will apply only to those taxes levied by the city that are not levied for the payment of bonds or authorized by a vote of the electors pursuant to section 9(b) or section 12, Article VII of the Florida Constitution. 
(b)  The amount of the exemption shall be determined by the county property appraiser based upon its usual process for post-construction inspection and appraisal of property following rehabilitation or renovation. 
(c)  Any exemption granted under this article to a particular property shall remain in effect for ten (10) years. The duration of the exemption shall continue regardless of any change in the authority of the city to grant such exemptions or any change in ownership of the property. In order to retain an exemption, however, the historic character of the property, and improvements which qualified the property for an exemption, must be maintained over the period for which the exemption was granted. 
(Ord. No. 619, § A, 8-17-98) 
Sec. 27-84. - Exemption for government or nonprofit purpose. 
(a)  If an improvement qualifies an eligible property for an exemption and the property is used for a government or nonprofit purpose and is regularly and frequently open to the public, the owner is eligible for an exemption from ad valorem taxation of one hundred (100) percent of the assessed value of the property, provided that: 
(1)  The assessed value of the improvement is equal to at least fifty (50) percent of the assessed value of the property as improved; 
(2)  The improvements are made by or for the use of the existing owner; and, 
(3)  The improvements are made on or after the effective date of this article. 
(b)  For an exemption granted under this section, the following conditions, as well as those provided in section 29-82 of this division, shall justify removal of a property from eligibility for the exemption, as described in section 27-85, when: 
(1)  The property is sold or otherwise transferred from the owner who made application and was granted the exemption; or, 
(2)  The property is no longer used for a government or nonprofit purpose, or is no longer regularly and frequently open to the public. 
(Ord. No. 619, § A, 8-17-98) 
Sec. 27-85. - Procedure for obtaining tax exemption. 
(a)  Application. An applicant (owner of record or authorized agent) seeking an ad valorem tax exemption for historic properties must file with the administrative official or designee a two-part historic preservation property tax exemption application with "Part 1: Pre-construction Application" (Part 1) completed. In addition, the applicant shall submit the following: 
(1)  A completed application for a "certificate of appropriateness" for the qualifying restoration, renovation or rehabilitation; and, 
(2)  An application fee of not more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). (Note: the actual amount of the specific fee is to be determined by the administrative official based on the estimated cost of the work to be performed and the administrative costs to be incurred by the city in processing the particular application and monitoring compliance). 
(b)  Review by property appraiser's office. Upon receipt of the pre-construction application, the administrative official will transmit the application to the county property appraiser's office, which will review and provide an estimate of the probable increase in the appraisal of the property to the applicant and the city. The applicant can withdraw the application within forty-five (45) days of receiving the estimate and be reimbursed an appropriate pro-ration amount of the filing fee. 
(c)  Review by historic preservation board. 
(1)  An historic preservation board (HPB) shall be established by resolution of the city council and shall review Part 1 applications for exemptions. The HPB shall determine whether the property is an eligible property and whether Part 1 proposed improvement is consistent with the Secretary of Interior's Standards for Rehabilitation and Guidelines for Rehabilitating Historic Buildings and is therefore an eligible improvement. 
(2)  For improvements intended to protect or stabilize severely deteriorated historic properties or archaeological sites, the HPB shall apply the following standards: 
a.  Before applying protective measures that are generally of a temporary nature and imply future historic preservations work, an analysis of the actual or anticipated threats to the property shall be made; 
b.  Protective measures shall safeguard the physical condition or environment of a property or archaeological site from further deterioration or damages caused by weather or other natural, animal or human intrusions; 
c.  If any historic material or architectural features are removed, they shall be properly recorded and, if possible, stored for future study or reuse; 
d.  Stabilization shall re-establish the structural stability of a property through the reinforcement of loadbearing members or by arresting material deterioration leading to structural failure. Stabilization shall also re-establish weather resistant conditions for a property; and, 
e.  Stabilization shall be accomplished in such a manner that it detracts as little as possible from the property's appearance. When reinforcement is required to re-establish structural stability, such work shall be concealed wherever possible so as to not intrude upon or detract from the aesthetic and historical quality of the property, except where concealment would result in the alteration or destruction of historically significant material or spaces. 
(3)  For applications submitted under the provisions of section 27-84, the HPB shall also determine that the property meets the standards set forth in that section. 
(4)  The HPB shall notify the applicant and the city council, in writing, of the results of its review and shall make recommendations for correction of any planned work deemed to be inconsistent with the requirements for an eligible improvement. 
(5)  When an applicant is applying jointly for the ad valorem tax exemption and for federal historic preservation tax credits, the applicant will complete the National Park Service's (NPS) federal tax credit application Part 1 of the historic preservation property tax exemption application and submit both to the administrative official. The HPB shall defer action on the applications until the NPS has rendered a determination. In the event the NPS approves the federal tax credit application, the Part 1 application shall be amended to reflect any conditions issued by the NPS. The HPB shall then approve the tax exemption application and forward it to the city council to be handled as part of the normal approval process set forth below. A denial by the NPS shall cause the HPB to deny the ad valorem tax exemption. 
(d)  Request for review of completed work application. 
(1)  Upon completion of work specified in the "Part 1" application, the applicant shall submit a "Part 2: Final Application for Review of Completed Work" (Part 2). The HPB shall conduct an inspection of the subject property to determine whether or not the completed improvements are in compliance with the work described and conditions imposed in the approved Part 1 application. Appropriate documentation may include paid contractor's bills and canceled checks, as well as an inspection request by the applicant within two (2) years following approval of the Part 1 application; 
(2)  On completion of review of the Part 2 application, the HPB shall recommend that the city council grant or deny the exemption. The recommendation, and reasons therefor, shall be provided in writing to the applicant and to the city council. The applicant and public shall be given at least ten (10) days notice by publication pursuant to F.S. section 166.041(3)(a), of the date and time for a public hearing by the City Council to consider and act upon the requested exemption. If a denial is recommended, and the applicant submits evaluations and plans which indicate that the applicant intends to undertake the work necessary to comply with the recommendations of the HPB, the denial of the applications may be continued by the administrative official for a period of time not to exceed sixty (60) days, while the applicant may resubmit documents indicating that the reasons for recommendation of denial of the application have been remedied and the administrative official will re-inspect the work; 
(e)  Approval by city council. At the close of the referenced public hearing, a majority vote of the city council shall be required to adopt the referenced ordinance to approve a Part 2 application and authorize the ad valorem tax exemption. The city council, in approving, overturning or modifying the recommendations of the HPB, shall utilize the same standards as used by the HPB in reaching its decision. If the exemption is granted, the ordinance adopted by the city council shall include the following: 
(1)  The name of the owner and the address of the historic property for which the exemption is granted; 
(2)  The date on which the ten-year exemption will expire; 
(3)  A finding that the historic property meets the requirements of this article; and, 
(4)  A copy of the historic preservation exemption covenants, as an attachment, as provided in section 27-86, signed by the applicant and the mayor or designated successor. 
(f)  Notice of property appraiser. The property owner shall have the historic preservation exemption covenants recorded in the official public records of the county, and shall provide a certified copy of the recorded historic preservation exemption covenants to the administrative official. Within fifteen (15) days of receipt of the certified copy, the administrative official shall transmit a copy of the approved "Part 2: Final Application," a copy of the adopted ordinance, and the historic preservation exemption covenants to the county property appraiser with instructions that the property appraiser provide the ad valorem tax exemption to the applicant. Responsibility for paying any and all costs lie with the applicant. 
(g)  Effective date of exemption. The effective date of the ad valorem tax exemption shall be January 1 of the year following the year in which the application is approved and the ordinance adopted by the city council and a historic preservation exemption covenant has been transmitted to the county property appraiser. 
(h)  An applicant previously granted a historic rehabilitation tax exemption by HPB may undertake additional improvement projects during the exemption period, or following its expiration, and reapply for an additional historic rehabilitation tax exemption for such work. 
An additional ten-year exemption shall apply only to the additional improvement. 
(Ord. No. 619, § A, 8-17-98) 
Sec. 27-86. - Required covenant. 
(a)  Effect of covenant. To qualify for an exemption, the property owner must enter into covenants with the city for the term for which the exemption is granted. The form of the covenants shall be the "Historic Preservation Property Tax Exemption Covenant" (DOS Form No. HR3E111292) or other subsequent applicable DOS form. The covenants shall be binding on the current property owner, transferees and their heirs, successors or assigns. 
(b)  Revocation of exemption. Violation of the covenants or agreement will result in the property owner being subject to the payment of the difference between the total amount of taxes which would have been due in March in each of the previous years in which the covenants or agreement was in effect had the property not received the exemption and the total amount of taxes actually paid in those years, plus interest on the difference calculated as provided in F.S. section 212.12(3), as amended. In the event of a violation of the covenants, or damage to the historic property as detailed below, the HPB shall conduct a hearing to allow the property owner to show cause why the exemption should not be revoked. Identification of the following conditions shall result in termination of the historic property tax exemption covenants, revocation of the exemption and removal of a property from eligibility for the property tax exemption: 
(1)  The owner is in violation of the provisions of the historic preservation tax exemption covenants; or, 
(2)  The property has been damaged by accident or natural causes beyond the owner's control to the extent that the historic integrity of the features, materials, appearance, workmanship and environment or archaeological integrity which made the property eligible for listing in the national register or designation under the provisions of the local preservation ordinance have been lost or so damaged that restoration is not feasible. Under this condition, the applicant is not required to pay back interest plus taxes. 
(c)  Appeal of revocation. The applicant can appeal a decision to revoke the exemption to the city council. The procedure for appealing the decision and the conduct of the hearing will be as specified, in writing, by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 619, § A, 8-17-98) 
Chapter 28 - TRAFFIC AND VEHICLES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, Ch. 13; fire lanes designated, § 13-26 et seq.; junked, wrecked, abandoned property, Ch. 18; abandoned vehicles, § 18-26 et seq.; vehicles for hire, Ch. 30. 
State Law reference- Uniform Traffic Control Law, F.S. § Ch. 316. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 28-1. - Present traffic regulations confirmed. 
    The nature and placement of all official traffic-control devices presently within the city which have been erected or placed in accordance with the requirements of F.S. Ch. 316, are hereby confirmed and approved as official action of the city. The traffic engineer shall compile traffic regulations reflecting such official traffic-control devices and cause them to be filed in the traffic regulation book pursuant to section 28-29(b). 
(Code 1975, § 27-67) 
Secs. 28-2-28-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - TRAFFIC ENGINEER 

Sec. 28-26. - Office created; responsibilities. 
    There is hereby created the office of the traffic engineer of the city. The traffic engineer shall have responsibility for the development, promulgation and implementation of traffic regulations within the city as provided in this article. The city engineer, or in his absence his designated deputy, is hereby designated as the traffic engineer. 
(Code 1975, § 27-62) 
Sec. 28-27. - Scope of regulations. 
    The traffic engineer shall, after appropriate investigation and in conformity to criteria promulgated by the department of transportation, propose traffic regulations for the city. Such regulations may extend to any one (1) or more of the following: 
(1)  Regulating or prohibiting stopping, standing or parking; 
(2)  Regulating traffic by means of police officers or official traffic-control devices; 
(3)  Regulating or prohibiting processions or assemblages on the streets or highways; 
(4)  Designating particular highways or roadways for use by traffic moving in one (1) direction; 
(5)  Establishing speed limits for vehicles in public parks; 
(6)  Designating any street as a through street or designating any intersection as a stop or yield intersection; 
(7)  Restricting the use of streets; 
(8)  Regulating the operation of bicycles; 
(9)  Regulating or prohibiting the turning of vehicles or specified types of vehicles; 
(10)  Altering or establishing speed limits in conformance with F.S. Ch. 316; 
(11)  Requiring written accident reports; 
(12)  Designating no-passing zones; 
(13)  Prohibiting or regulating the use of controlled-access roadways by any class or kind of traffic; 
(14)  Prohibiting or regulating the use of heavily traveled streets by any class or kind of traffic found to be incompatible with the normal and safe movement of traffic; 
(15)  Designating and regulating traffic on play streets; 
(16)  Prohibiting pedestrians from crossing a roadway in a business district, or any designated highway except on a crosswalk; 
(17)  Regulating pedestrian crossings at unmarked crosswalks; 
(18)  Regulating persons upon skates, coasters, and other toy vehicles; 
(19)  Such temporary or experimental regulations as may be necessary to cover emergencies or special conditions. 
(Code 1975, § 27-63) 
Sec. 28-28. - Guidelines. 
    In promulgating proposed traffic regulations, the traffic engineer shall propose such regulations as will best provide for the safe and orderly movement of traffic within the city, having due regard for: 
(1)  Established traffic patterns; 
(2)  Frequency and nature of traffic on given streets, alleys and roads; 
(3)  The convenience and safety of motorists and pedestrians alike; 
(4)  The character and population of given areas of the city; 
(5)  Coordination with traffic movement on state highways and on roads, streets and highways connecting with adjacent jurisdictions; and 
(6)  In general, the safety and welfare of the citizens and visitors to the city. 
(Code 1975, § 27-68) 
Sec. 28-29. - Promulgation of regulations. 
(a)  All proposed traffic regulations shall be in writing and signed by the traffic engineer. The traffic engineer shall keep the city council advised of all traffic regulations put into effect. Determination of what constitutes a minor or major traffic regulation is left to the discretion of the traffic engineer. Before any major proposed traffic regulation shall become effective, it shall be submitted to the chief of police for his review and approval, then it shall be conspicuously posted in the city for not less than seven (7) days prior to a regular or special meeting of the city council. Prior to such meeting, the proposed major traffic regulation shall be presented to councilmembers by the traffic engineer, and such proposed traffic regulation shall automatically become effective at the conclusion of such meeting, unless called up for consideration by the city council. Any two (2) members of the city council may call up a proposed traffic regulation for consideration by the council. Upon a proposed traffic regulation being called up for consideration the council shall thereupon or thereafter deliberate and consider such regulation and either approve or disapprove such proposed regulation, or amend and approve such regulation. Proposed traffic regulations shall not go into effect after being called up for consideration by council without approval of a majority of council present at a regular or special meeting. 
(b)  Nothing contained in this section shall prevent the city council from promulgating traffic regulations upon its own motion. Any traffic regulation may at any time after it becomes effective be called up for consideration by the city council upon motion of any two (2) members of the council, and after consideration may be revoked, amended, or confirmed. All council action in approving or amending proposed or existing traffic regulations shall be by resolution, and a certified copy of such resolution, together with the applicable traffic regulation, shall be filed with the city clerk in a separate record book kept for that purpose. 
(c)  Any proposed traffic regulation becoming effective without affirmative council action shall bear the signature of the city clerk or deputy clerk attesting that such regulation became effective without council action, as provided in this section. 
(Code 1975, § 27-64) 
Sec. 28-30. - Effect of regulations. 
    Traffic regulations adopted pursuant to this article shall have the effect of implementing the city's regulatory jurisdiction under F.S. Ch. 316. The traffic engineer shall cause to be placed official traffic-control devices and signs as may be required to implement traffic regulations adopted pursuant to this article. Such placement shall be deemed to be an official act and at the direction of the city council. 
(Code 1975, § 27-65) 
Sec. 28-31. - Violations generally. 
    Violation of traffic regulations promulgated pursuant to this article, or failure to observe official traffic-control devices or signs placed in accordance with such regulations, shall be, where applicable, violations of appropriate sections of the Florida Uniform Traffic Control Law. Failure to conform to, abide by or observe any traffic regulation adopted pursuant to this article, or traffic-control device or sign implementing such regulations, which does not constitute a violation of any section or provisions of F.S. Ch. 316, shall constitute a violation of this article, and anyone so violating the terms of this article shall be deemed charged with a noncriminal infraction and cited for such information, and cited to appear before the court having jurisdiction of traffic infractions generally within the city. Procedure shall be as provided in F.S. § 318.14, as created by Laws of Florida, Ch. 74-377, and civil penalties shall be as provided in F.S. § 318.18, as created by Laws of Florida, Ch. 74-377, and all other incidents and procedures shall be as provided in F.S. Ch. 318 as created by Laws of Florida, Ch. 74-377. 
(Code 1975, § 27-66) 
Secs. 28-32-28-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalk and other public places, Ch. 25. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 28-51. - Parking in violation of signs declared unlawful. 
    Whenever the city shall, by appropriate action, designate any no parking area or area where parking is restricted to permit holders, certain hours or limited to a permissible period of time, and an appropriate sign or other device is posted upon the street or portion of street where such prohibition, restriction or limitation is applicable, it shall be unlawful for any person to park any vehicle in violation of such prohibition, restriction or limitation. 
(Code 1975, § 27-2(a); Ord. No. 07-955, § 2, 1-7-08) 
Sec. 28-52. - Parking of commercial vehicles in residential areas. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person owning or having possession, custody or control of any commercial vehicle, as defined in appendix B, article III, section 3.2 of this Code, to park such vehicle in a residential zoning district in violation of appendix B, article VI, section 6.5, subsection 6.5(b) of this Code. 
(Code 1975, § 27-2; Ord. No. 172, § 1, 12-20-82; Ord. No. 05-862, § 4, 8-29-05) 
Sec. 28-53. - Disabled persons' parking spaces. 
(a)  The city commission shall provide in all parking areas on governmental property specially designed and marked parking spaces for the exclusive use of those severely physically disabled individuals with permanent mobility problems, as required by F.S. section 316.1955. Each parking space shall be prominently outlined with paint and posted with a permanent sign of color and design approved by the state department of transportation bearing the internationally accepted wheelchair symbol and the caption "PARKING BY DISABLED PERMIT ONLY." 
(b)  Any business, firm or person within the city licensed to do business with the public may provide in any parking area owned or leased by such business, firm, or person specifically designed and marked parking spaces for the exclusive use of those severely physically disabled individuals with permanent mobility problems, as required by F.S. section 316.1955. Each such parking space shall be prominently outlined with paint and posted with a permanent sign of a color and design approved by the state department of transportation bearing the internationally accepted wheelchair symbol or the caption "PARKING BY DISABLED PERMIT ONLY." 
(Ord. No. 263, § 2, 5-5-86; Ord. No. 2018-07, § 1A., 12-3-18) 
Sec. 28-54. - Schedule of fines for parking violations. 
(a)  The following schedule of fines as specified for the respective parking violations is hereby enacted and shall be imposed by the chief of police or any police officer of the city upon those person committing the stated offenses: 
(1)  Vehicle unoccupied with motor running: ..... $20.00 
(2)  Parking within fifteen (15) feet of a fire hydrant: ..... $35.00 
(3)  Parking in or blocking a fire lane: ..... $35.00 
(4)  Parking in or blocking a loading zone: ..... $20.00 
(5)  Parking against the flow of traffic: ..... $20.00 
(6)  Parking in front of a yellow curb or red curb: ..... $20.00 
(7)  Parking in a designated handicap space without a permit: ..... $200.00 
(8)  Parking on a sidewalk: ..... $35.00 
(9)  Parking within twenty (20) feet of a crosswalk: ..... $35.00 
(10)  Parking within thirty (30) feet of a stop sign: ..... $35.00 
(11)  Parking in a designated bicycle path: ..... $35.00 
(12)  Parking in front of a public or private driveway: ..... $35.00 
(13)  All other prohibited parking violating Florida Uniform Traffic Control Law: ..... $20.00 
(b)  There shall be a penalty of ten dollars ($10.00) added to each fine if not paid within thirty (30) calendar days from the date of the violation(s). 
(Code 1975, § 27-3; Ord. No. 263, § 2, 5-5-86; Ord. No. 511, § 1, 2-21-94; Ord. No. 2018-97, § 1B., 12-3-18) 
Sec. 28-55. - Traffic violations bureau; collections. 
(a)  The City of Palmetto and its police department is hereby authorized to establish or participate in a traffic violations bureau including any division of such bureau established for the city by the circuit court in and for Manatee County, Florida. The police department and the city clerk's office are authorized to execute any necessary documents to establish or participate in such bureau and comply with any orders issued by the circuit court and the State of Florida Department of Highway Safety and Motor Vehicles. 
(b)  The city shall furnish to the clerk of the court for Manatee County, Florida, a traffic violations bureau, or the State of Florida Department of Highway Safety and Motor Vehicles a magnetically encoded computer tape reel or cartridge of an alphabetized list which is machine readable by the installed computer system of the Florida Department of Highway Safety and Motor Vehicles, of persons who have three (3) or more outstanding parking violations. The provisions of F.S. section 320.03(8), as amended, shall apply to each person whose name appears on such list. 
(c)  Under the authority of F.S. section 320.03(8), if the name of an applicant for a license plate or re-validation sticker appears on the list referred to in paragraph (b) of this subsection and F.S. section 316.1967(6), the license plate or re-validation sticker shall not be issued until the applicant's name no longer appears on said list or until the applicant presents a receipt from city clerk showing the parking fines have been paid. 
(Ord. No. 511, § 2, 2-21-94) 
Sec. 28-56. - Owner of vehicle presumed to be violator. 
    In the prosecution of a violation of any ordinance or section of this Code governing the stopping, standing, or parking or operating of a vehicle, proof that the particular vehicle described in the complaint or citation was parked or operated in violation of any such ordinance or regulation, together with proof that the defendant named in the citation or complaint was at the time of such parking or operating the registered owner of such vehicle, shall create a presumption that the registered owner of such vehicle was the person who stopped, parked or operated such vehicle at the time and place such violation occurred. 
(Ord. No. 07-955, § 3, 1-7-08) 
Sec. 28-57. - Appeal. 
    Any person who receives a citation and believes that the citation was issued in error, has the right to appeal to the special magistrate. Such appeal shall be filed within ten calendar days after the citation was issued. Such appeal shall be filed with the City Clerk's Office who shall provide appropriate forms. If the appeal is not filed within ten (10) calendar days, the citation is final. There shall be an appeal filing charge of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) to be paid at time of filing the appeal at the City Clerk's Office. This fee will be refunded should the special magistrate reverse the citation. Upon notification of the appeal, the City Clerk's Office shall transmit the request for appeal to the special magistrate who will hear the appeal at the next available meeting. 
(Ord. No. 2018-07, § 1C., 12-3-18) 
Secs. 28-58-28-70. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - OFF-STREET PARKING[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Planning and development, Ch. 23; streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 25; subdivisions, Ch. 26. 

Sec. 28-71. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Conversion unit means the remodeling of a single-family dwelling unit into two (2) or more separate living units. 
    Living unit means one (1) bathroom and three (3) habitable rooms which include separate and sanitary cooking and dining facilities. 
    Parking space includes covered garage space and uncovered parking lot space located off the public right-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 226, §§ 2(A), 3(A)2, 10-1-84) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 28-72. - Required. 
    Off-street parking, loading and unloading facilities shall be provided to lessen congestion in the streets. The facilities required in this section shall be available throughout the hours of operation of the particular business or use for which such facilities are provided. 
(Ord. No. 226, § 2(A), 10-1-84) 
Sec. 28-73. - Size of spaces. 
    Each parking space required by this division shall consist of not less than an average of two hundred seventy (270) square feet of usable area for each motor vehicle, including interior driveways, driveways connecting the garage or parking space with a street or alley. Notwithstanding the above, all parking spaces shall be ample in size for the vehicles for which use is intended. The net parking space per vehicle shall be not less than nine (9) feet wide and twenty (20) feet long. 
(Ord. No. 226, § 2(B), 10-1-84) 
Sec. 28-74. - Joint use of facilities and spaces. 
(a)  Nothing in this division shall be construed to prevent the joint use of off-street parking or off-street loading spaces for two (2) or more buildings or uses, if the total of such spaces when used together are not less than the sum of the requirements of the various individual uses computed separately in accordance with the requirements of this division except as may be set forth below. 
Cumulative parking requirements for joint use facilities may be reduced by a maximum of twenty (20) percent of the cumulative parking requirement if the city planner determines that one (1) or more of the following exists: 
• Joint uses have different peak hours of operation or conversely, if they share the same patrons; or 
• Joint uses are located in a pedestrian-oriented setting where there is adequate parking available to the public to serve the proposed use and the other land uses which the parking is intended to serve; or 
• Joint uses are complementary to each other where periods of usage of such buildings will not be simultaneous (such as church buildings, for example); or 
• Joint uses are located in the commercial core and meet the provisions of the downtown design guidelines. 
The city planner may approve an alternative parking plan if the information submitted by the applicant demonstrates that an adequate number of spaces for the proposed use, when reviewed with other existing or previously approved uses by the city in the area, would exist even if the number of parking spaces does not meet the specific requirements of section 28-78 of this Code. 
    The city planner may also approve an alternative parking plan where not less than one (1) space per one hundred seventy-five (175) square feet of gross floor area, including restaurants, may be approved as part of the site plan review of an integrated commercial shopping center which has two (2) or more different commercial uses designed, structured, and located, so as to result in an integrated shopping center, mall, or similar acceptable structure(s), provided the following criteria are met: 
(1)  There is a minimum site area of forty-three thousand five hundred sixty (43,560) square feet; and 
(2)  There is a minimum lot width of two hundred (200) feet. A site development plan shall be provided for all commercial buildings approved under this paragraph in accordance with subsection (d) below. 
(b)  Approval of a parking plan to reduce the cumulative parking requirements by more than twenty (20) percent shall be approved by the city commission. 
(c)  An agreement for such joint use, in the form of a long-term lease, or other methods acceptable to the city attorney, shall be filed with the city planner and recorded by the city at the expense of the applicant in the Public Records of Manatee County. 
(d)  A site plan shall be submitted indicating the number of parking spaces and the type of uses seeking a joint use parking alternative for the city planner's signature. Any change of use shall trigger an evaluation of the approved site plan by the city planner. 
Joint parking facilities shall be evaluated based on the uses proposed, and existing uses on adjoining properties, and any such parking approval shall be limited to those uses subsequently approved by the city planner. 
(Ord. No. 2010-19, § 1, 12-6-10) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2010-19, § 1, adopted Dec. 6, 2010, amended § 28-74 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former § 28-74 pertained to location of facilities and spaces and derived from Ord. No. 226, §§ 2(C), (D), adopted Oct. 1, 1984. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. X, § X, adopted Jan./Feb./March/etc. X, 200X, amended X [usually a chapter, article, division, or subdivision] in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former X, §§ X-X, pertained to X, and derived from X. 
Sec. 28-75. - Construction requirements. 
    All off-street parking facilities, including aisles, travel lanes, and driveways, shall be constructed and maintained in accordance with city standards, but at a minimum shall be constructed of asphalt, concrete, brick, or paver block. 
    The director of public works may approve the utilization of grassed parking areas for infrequently used parking areas such as churches, recreational facilities, overflow parking, or other places of public assembly for meetings or other events, and for temporary uses where it is clear that such grassed surfaces can be adequately maintained due to the infrequency of use and that adequate traffic-control means will be provided for all weekday employees and visitors. 
    In cases involving single-family dwellings, the driveway shall be constructed of asphalt, concrete, brick, paver block, shell or grass. All driveways for such single-family dwellings located along paved streets shall be provided and maintained with a smooth, dustless surface from the edge of the road's pavement to the right-of-way line. 
(Ord. No. 226, § 2(E), 10-1-84; Ord. No. 542, § 1, 8-7-95) 
Sec. 28-76. - Lighting. 
    Any lighting used to illuminate any on- or off-street parking area shall be so arranged as to reflect the light away from adjoining residential premises and public rights-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 226, § 2(F), 10-1-84) 
Sec. 28-77. - Access. 
    There shall be adequate provisions for ingress and egress to all parking and loading spaces required by this division and designed for use by employees, customers, delivery services, sales people and/or the general public. Where a parking or loading area does not abut on a public right-of-way, private alley or easement of access, there shall be provided an access drive per lane of traffic, not less than eighteen (18) feet in width in all cases where the access is to storage areas or loading and unloading spaces required by this division except in situations where a fire lane is required with a width of twenty (20) feet. 
(Ord. No. 226, § 2(G), 10-1-84) 
Sec. 28-78. - Required number of spaces. 
(a)  Generally. Any structure or building erected or enlarged for any of the following uses and any open are hereafter used for commercial purposes shall, subject to the provisions of this division, be provided with not less than the minimum parking spaces, as set forth below, which spaces shall be readily accessible to the uses served thereby. Fractional numbers of parking spaces shall be increased to the next whole number. Existing structures that expand gross floor area by more than five (5) percent over the gross floor area as it existed on the effective date of the ordinance from which this division derives, must comply with the intent of this division and provide the required number of parking spaces. 
(b)  Residential. 
(1)  All residential units shall be provided with two (2) off-street parking spaces per dwelling unit. 
(2)  Conversion units shall be provided with a minimum of one (1) parking space per dwelling unit. The required parking spaces shall not be located between the street right-of-way line and the front building line. 
(3)  Apartment structures in combination with permitted commercial uses shall provide parking spaces as required if both uses were established separately. 
(4)  Boardinghouses or roominghouses, hotels, motels, and tourist houses shall have at least one (1) parking space for each guestroom. If a restaurant in connection with the above is open to the public, the off-street parking facilities shall not be less than those required for restaurants, in addition to those required for guestrooms. 
(c)  Commercial. 
(1)  Theaters, auditoriums, churches, schools, stadiums or any other place of public or private assembly shall have at least one (1) parking space for each three (3) seats provided for public or private assembly. 
(2)  Retail stores and other places for trade or business shall have one (1) vehicle space for each two hundred (200) square feet of floor area for public use. 
(3)  Foodmarkets and grocery stores shall have one (1) vehicle parking space for each one hundred (100) square feet of floor area for public use. 
(4)  Restaurants, tearooms and cafeterias, including taprooms, taverns and nightclubs, shall have one (1) vehicle space for each fifty (50) square feet of floor area for public use. 
(5)  Bowling alleys shall have five (5) vehicle spaces for each alley. 
(6)  Office buildings shall have at least one (1) parking space for each two hundred (200) square feet of floor area or fraction thereof. 
(7)  Public garages, automobile and gasoline service stations shall have at least one (1) parking space for each two hundred (200) square feet of floor area, or fraction thereof, devoted to repair or service facilities, and one (1) space for each employee on the largest shift. This shall be in addition to the space allocated for the normal storage of motor vehicles. No parking shall be permitted on the public rights-of-way. 
(8)  Hospitals, sanitariums and nursing homes shall have at least one (1) parking space for each three (3) beds. Such spaces shall be in addition to those necessary for doctors, administrative personnel and other regular employees. One (1) parking space shall be provided for each employee on the largest shift. 
(9)  Dance halls, roller rinks, clubs, lodges and other similar places shall have at least one (1) parking space for each two hundred (200) square feet of floor space. 
(10)  Mortuaries, funeral homes and undertaking establishments shall have at least one (1) parking space for each one hundred (100) square feet of floor area for public use. Such space shall be in addition to: 
a.  Employee parking needs; and 
b.  Service area for mobile equipment, such as hearses and ambulances. 
(11)  Home occupations and day care centers shall have at least one (1) parking space for the residents, one (1) space for each nonresident employee, and two (2) spaces for patron use. 
(12)  Other commercial buildings shall have at least one (1) parking space for each four hundred (400) square feet of floor area or fraction thereof. 
(13)  Swimming pools shall have at least one (1) parking space for each three (3) persons for whom facilities for dressing are provided; or at least one (1) parking space for every twelve (12) square feet of water surface, including areas for swimming, wading, and diving, whichever requirement is the greater. 
(14)  Open areas used for commercial purposes: 
a.  Golf driving ranges shall have at least one (1) parking space for each tee provided. 
b.  Miniature golf courses shall have at least one (1) parking space for each two (2) persons for whom playing area is provided. 
c.  Other open areas shall have at least one (1) parking space for each two thousand five hundred (2,500) square feet of area or fraction thereof. 
(15)  Not less than one (1) space per one hundred seventy-five (175) square feet of gross floor area, including restaurants, may be approved as part of the site plan review of an integrated commercial shopping center which has five (5) or more different commercial uses designed, structured, and located, so as to result in an integrated shopping center, mail, or similar acceptable structure. 
a.  Minimum site area, forty-three thousand five hundred sixty (43,560) square feet; 
b.  Minimum lot width, two hundred (200) feet. 
A site development plan shall be provided for all commercial buildings in accordance with supplemental regulations, section 23-10, which is on file in the city clerk's office. 
(16)  Manufacturing and warehousing buildings: 
a.  Shall have at least one (1) parking space for each administrative, clerical or sales employee, one (1) parking space for each employee on the shift with the greatest number of employees engaged in the actual operation, manufacture or storage in such manufacturing or warehousing buildings, which is not an administrative, clerical or sales employee, and additional parking spaces equal to the greater of five (5) parking spaces or five (5) percent of the otherwise required parking spaces rounded to the next highest whole number. 
b.  Loading dock areas shall have a parking area for all delivery or pickup vehicles waiting to use loading docks such that they will not adversely impact on-street parking or traffic movements. 
c.  In the event any use of the manufacturing and warehousing building expands or changes beyond that originally permitted hereunder so that it adversely impacts on-street parking facilities, or would require additional parking spaces hereunder, the owner shall mitigate the impact by providing additional off-street parking. 
All buildings, including accessory buildings, shall not cover more than fifty (50) percent of the lot. 
(d)  Handicap parking. Handicap parking shall be as provided by state and federal law. 
(Ord. No. 226, § 3, 10-1-84; Ord. No. 367, § 1, 4-3-89) 
Sec. 28-79. - Penalty for violation. 
    All violations of this division shall be under the jurisdiction of special magistrates pursuant to chapter 2, article IV of this Code, and violations shall be punishable by a fine of up to two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) per day for each day that each violation continues. 
(Ord. No. 226, § 4, 10-1-84; Ord. No. 2018-02, § 3(Exh. B), 2-26-18) 
Secs. 28-80-28-95. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - IMPOUNDMENT OF VEHICLES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 28-96. - Authority. 
(a)  Members of the police department are hereby authorized to remove or cause to be removed any vehicle from any street, alley or city parking lot within the city, to the nearest garage designated or maintained by the police department or the city or other place of safety, under the circumstances hereinafter enumerated: 
(1)  When any vehicle is left unattended upon any bridge, causeway or viaduct, or in any tunnel or subway, or blocking any public or private driveway, designated fire lane or within six (6) feet of a fire hydrant, or upon any street or alley and such vehicle constitutes an obstruction to traffic. 
(2)  When any vehicle is left unattended in any designated handicap parking space without displaying the proper identification emblem. 
(3)  When a vehicle upon a street or alley is so disabled as to constitute an obstruction to traffic, or the person or persons in charge of the vehicle are by reasons of physical injury, incapacitated to such an extent as to be unable to provide for its custody or removal. 
(4)  When a vehicle is found being operated upon the streets and is not in safe operating condition. 
(5)  When any vehicle is left unattended upon a public street, alley or public sidewalk and is parked illegally as to constitute a hazard or obstruction to the normal movement of traffic. 
(6)  When any vehicle is left unattended upon a street continuously for more than twenty-four (24) hours and may be presumed to be abandoned. 
(7)  When the driver of such vehicle is taken into custody by the police department or other law enforcement agency and such vehicle would thereby be left unattended upon a street. 
(8)  When for any reason a vehicle is left on city property continuously for more than forty-eight (48) hours. 
(9)  When removal is necessary in the interest of public safety because of fire, flood, storm or other emergency. 
(b)  This section shall not be construed to prohibit the parking or leaving of any law enforcement, fire fighting or other emergency vehicle by an employee of any law enforcement, fire fighting or other emergency service agency in the performance of their duty. 
(Code 1975, § 27-14; Ord. No. 511, § 3, 2-21-94) 
Sec. 28-97. - Notice required. 
    Whenever an officer removes a vehicle as authorized by this article such officer shall immediately give or cause to be given notice, in writing, by hand or by mail to the owner of such vehicle of the fact of such removal. The notice shall be in a standard form approved by the chief of police and shall include a description of the vehicle, the date and time of the removal, the location from which the vehicle was removed, the reason for such removal and the name and location of the place where the vehicle is stored. If the vehicle is stored in an authorized garage, a copy of such notice shall be given to the proprietor of such garage. If the officer is not able to ascertain the owner or the owner's current address or is unable to give the notice to the owner, the notice shall be delivered to the owner's last known address and to the proprietor of the garage where the vehicle is stored. 
(Code 1975, §§ 27-15, 27-16; Ord. No. 511, § 4, 2-21-94)
