Sec. 28-100. - Costs for towing, storage and maintenance of seized vehicles, vessels and aircraft. 
    If a seized vehicle, vessel, aircraft or similar asset is to be released to its lawful owner, the police department shall determine the actual cost of towing, maintenance and storage for such vehicle, vessel, aircraft or other assets. The police department shall charge such actual cost against the registered owner. The registered owner must pay such cost before the police department may release the vehicle, vessel, aircraft or other assets. 
(Ord. No. 449, §§ 1, 2, 2-4-91) 
Editor's note- Section 3 of Ord. No. 449, adopted Feb. 4, 1991, repealed Ord. No. 338, adopted Aug. 15, 1988, from which was derived § 28-100, which set out administrative fees for vehicles seized under the Florida Contraband Forfeiture Act. Sections 1 and 2 of Ord. No. 449 have been included herein by the editor as a new § 28-100. 
State Law reference- Florida Contraband Forfeiture Act, F.S. §§ 932.701-932.704. 
Secs. 28-101-28-110. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - IMPOUNDMENT FOR PARKING VIOLATIONS 

Sec. 28-111. - Repeated violations. 
    When any vehicle which has, on at least five (5) prior occasions occurring within the preceding six-month period, been found stopped, standing or parked on any street or alley within the city in violation of an offense listed in section 28-54, the city clerk shall notify the registered or titled owner by registered mail of the issuance of the five (5) parking violation notices. If such owner shall fail or refuse to appear in response to the notice within ten (10) days of mailing, and thereafter the same vehicle is found in violation of any of the enumerated offenses in section 28-54, the vehicle may be removed and impounded by members of the police department of this city in any public garage or other place of safety. 
(Code 1975, § 27-24) 
Sec. 28-112. - Notice to owner. 
    Upon taking possession of any vehicle as provided in this division, the police department shall endeavor to notify the owner thereof that such vehicle has been impounded and is being held. A notice shall be given to the person to whom the vehicle is licensed in accordance with the registration list furnished by the office of motor vehicles. The notice shall be served within a reasonable time by certified mail or in person, and a charge of one dollar ($1.00) for the giving of such notice shall be collected at the time the vehicle is returned to its owner. 
(Code 1975, § 27-26) 
Sec. 28-113. - Owner responsible for costs, fines. 
    The cost of towing, removing and storing a vehicle impounded under this division shall be chargeable against the owner, and shall be a lien upon the vehicle. The owner of the vehicle shall pay these charges together with all unpaid fines before the vehicle will be released. The vehicle may be stored in a public or private place. If the vehicle is stored in a private place the amount charged for storage shall be the amount the city must pay for the vehicle storage. If the vehicle is stored on city property, the charges for storage shall be two dollars ($2.00) per day. The charges to the owner for towing shall be the cost of towing to the city. 
(Code 1975, § 27-25) 
Cross reference- Liens generally, Ch. 2, Art. III, Div. 3. 
Sec. 28-114. - Recovery. 
    The registered owner of a vehicle impounded or removed as provided by this division shall be entitled to recover such vehicle only after making payment for the charges set forth in this division. The registered owner of such vehicle shall be responsible for paying the charges and fines as provided in this division, whether such registered owner was the person who unlawfully parked or left standing such vehicle, or not, unless the vehicle was reported as stolen. In each instance the police department shall require payment of the sums provided for in this division before restoring to the registered owner possession of such vehicle. 
(Code 1975, § 27-27) 
Sec. 28-115. - Unredeemed vehicles. 
    If a vehicle impounded pursuant to this division is not claimed and all charges paid within thirty (30) days after the police have given notice of taking possession of such vehicle, an action may be commenced in the county court, or other court having jurisdiction, in the name of the city as plaintiff and against the registered owner as defendant for the amount of charges. 
(Code 1975, § 27-28) 
Secs. 28-116-28-130. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - REGULATIONS OF SKATES, SKATEBOARDS, SCOOTERS, COASTERS, BICYCLES AND SIMILAR DEVICES[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 03-773, § B, adopted April 7, 2003, repealed article V, sections 28-131, 28-132, in its entirety and replaced it with a new article V, sections 28-131-28-136. Former article V pertained to bicycles and derived from the Code of 1975, §§ 27-30, 27-31. 

Sec. 28-131. - Definitions. 
    The following definitions will apply to this article: 
    Bicycle means any human-powered device, with one (1) or more wheels. 
    Designated skating or skateboard facility means an area approved for such activities by the city council. 
    Parking facility means any parking lot or garage, which is owned and maintained by the city, and used to park private and government vehicles. 
    Public buildings means all buildings, as well as the steps, sidewalks and grounds immediately adjacent to all such buildings, owned, leased, occupied or maintained by the city, in whole or in part. 
    Skate or roller skate means any type of roller or in-line skate worn on the feet. 
    Skateboard means any wheeled device, propelled by human power or gravity, upon which the operator stands, sits or kneels, usually consisting of small ball-bearing equipped wheels mounted under a board-like platform; the definition also includes coasters, scooters and other such toys; it also includes, skateboards powered by small motors. 
(Ord. No. 03-773, § B, 4-7-03) 
Sec. 28-132. - Prohibition of use. 
(a)  It is unlawful and a violation of this Code for any person, at or in any building or structure owned by the city, to operate, use or ride upon any skate, skateboard, scooter, coaster, bicycle or similar device on the sidewalks, steps, railings, grounds, benches and access ramps immediately adjacent to, or within the interior or inside of any city-owned public building, unless any such area has been designated by appropriate signage by action of the city council as a designated skating or skateboard facility. 
(b)  It is unlawful and a violation of this Code for any person, in or upon or within any city parking facility to operate or use a skate, skateboard, scooter, coaster, bicycle or similar device; provided, however, that it is not a violation of this Code to walk a bicycle in, through or upon any such parking facility. 
(Ord. No. 03-773, § B, 4-7-03) 
Sec. 28-133. - Parking. 
    No person shall park a bicycle upon a street other than upon the roadway against the curb or upon a sidewalk in a rack to support the bicycle or against a building or at a curb in such a manner as to afford the least obstruction to pedestrian traffic and to avoid improper contact with pedestrians or vehicles. 
(Ord. No. 03-773, § B, 4-7-03) 
Sec. 28-134. - Speed. 
    No person shall ride upon, operate or use skates, skateboards, scooters, coasters, bicycles or similar devices at a speed greater than that posted upon the applicable roadway or highway, or at a speed greater than is reasonable and prudent under the conditions existing, which include, but are not limited to weather conditions, traffic congestion and flow, the presence of pedestrians, the presence of children at play or other similar factors. 
(Ord. No. 03-773, § B, 4-7-03) 
Sec. 28-135. - Penalties. 
    A violation of this article shall be enforced as provided for by law. Furthermore, as supplemental and not restrictive, a violation of the provisions of this article is deemed to be a non-criminal infraction and shall be enforced pursuant to the provisions of chapter 2, article IV, division 3, citations, section 2-101, et seq., City Code, by a fine not to exceed fifty dollars ($50.00), or as provided for under F.S. § 318.18, or by any other lawful and available enforcement mechanism utilized by the city. Both law enforcement officers and code enforcement officers of the city may issue citations for violation of this article. 
(Ord. No. 03-773, § B, 4-7-03) 
Sec. 28-136. - Warning signs. 
    Appropriate signs informing of the existence of this article and warning against action which may be in violation shall be prominently displayed at city public buildings as determined by the city council in order to give persons of ordinary intelligence fair notice and warning of the activities or conduct addressed and prohibited in this article and the penalties provided for violation. The mere failure of posting a sign or the lack of signage at any given time or location, or a violator's failure to read, comprehend or understand the sign shall not, in and of itself, be a defense to any alleged violation of these provisions. 
(Ord. No. 03-773, § B, 4-7-03) 
Secs. 28-137-28-150. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - RAILROADS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Department of transportation authority to regulate crossings, speed, etc., F.S. § 338.21; authority of city to regulate blocking of crossings, F.S. § 338.21(6); duties of railroads in operating trains; F.S. Ch. 351; ordinances permitted regulating audible warning signals, F.S. § 351.03; speed limit at municipal crossings, F.S. § 351.03(1). 

Sec. 28-151. - Obstructing street crossings. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to leave any railroad train or car standing or being across or in any street or alley of the city for a longer time than may be necessary in switching, or the temporary stopping of the same when being operated in the usual course of business, but in case shall such train or car stand in the street for a longer time than ten (10) minutes. 
(Code 1975, § 22-1) 
Sec. 28-152. - Crossing certain streets. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to cause any railroad train, engineer, or car to cross 8th Avenue, 10th Avenue, 7th Avenue or 11th Avenue in the city without first bringing such railroad train, engine, or car to a full stop and sending a man ahead of the train, engine or car to signal any or all persons approaching the crossing that the train, engine or car is about to cross. During the time between one-half hour after sunset and one-half hour before sunrise the flagman's signal or light shall be of such brilliancy as will be seen at least one hundred (100) feet from the crossing. 
(Code 1975, § 22-2) 
Chapter 29 - UTILITIES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2; finance, § 2-46 et seq.; alcoholic beverages prohibited in the cemetery and area adjacent to and the sewage treatment plant and area adjacent thereto, § 4-3; buildings and building regulations, Ch. 7; plumbing code adopted, § 7-111; fire prevention and protection, Ch. 13; floodplain management, Ch. 14; garbage, trash and refuse, Ch. 15; health and sanitation, Ch. 16; housing, Ch. 17; mobile homes, Ch. 21; mobile homes must be connected to the water and sewer systems of the city, § 21-4; taxation, Ch. 27; public service tax levied upon all utilities, § 27-26 et seq.; franchises, App. A. 

ARTICLE I. - MASTER UTILITY SYSTEM REGULATIONS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2013-14, §§ 2 and 3, adopted Oct. 21, 2013, repealed art. I and enacted a new article as set out herein. The former art. I, §§ 29-1-29-38 and §§ 29-40-29-44, pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 04-832, § 4, adopted Dec. 20, 2004, and Ord. No. 2012-13, § 2(a), adopted July 2, 2012. 

Sec. 29-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the following meaning: 
    Customer. The owner of title as recorded in the property appraiser's records, real estate settlement statement or as stated on a copy of a warranty deed or a tenant, lessee or occupant with established appropriate credit, applying as, and who shall be, the individual responsible for the payment of all fees and charges of the utility system, including, but not limited to, potable water, reclaimed water/reuse, sewer or waste water, solid waste/sanitation, stormwater services and fire sprinkler systems. Accounts shall be in the name of the customer. 
    Customer charge. A service charge made up of debt service associated with the system capacity that must be available to supply service on demand and other fixed costs such as billing and metering. 
    Facility. As used in this chapter, the term "facility" includes, but is not limited to, a multi-family residential or multi-unit commercial complex, project or structure. The foregoing includes, without limitation, condominiums, apartments, duplexes, mobile home parks, hotels, motels, travel trailer parks, shopping centers, office or professional buildings or complexes, or docking spaces for more than one (1) live-aboard vessels. 
    Master meter. A single meter serving two (2) or more units within a facility. 
    Revitalize. To give new life to an existing residential structure or an existing non-residential structure. 
    Unit. A complete single or wholly contained space, area, placer thing or structure which is or can be occupied by persons or objects and shall be further classified as either of the following: 
(1)  Residential unit. For purposes of this chapter, the term means one (1) or more rooms in a residential or commercial building which are used or intended for use as a separate and complete living facility for no more than one (1) family and generally including provisions for living, sleeping, eating, cooking and sanitation, regardless of whether the unit is owner or tenant occupied or available for rental, lease or other form of occupancy. For the purpose of this definition, each mobile home park rental space or lot, or a rental space or lot for other such manufactured structures, and any recreational vehicle park space or lot, or docking space for a live-aboard vessel in a marina, whether any of the foregoing are occupied or not occupied, is considered a residential unit. Each hotel, motel, guest home, adult congregate living or nursing home room is considered a separate residential unit. 
(2)  Non-residential unit. All structures, buildings or a group of one or more rooms or spaces in such buildings or structures arranged, designed, used or intended to be used for occupancy by persons or objects as a unified non-residential operation by an owner, tenant, lessee or occupant for nonresidential purposes or uses. 
    Utility, utility system or utility service. Means and includes within the context as may be clearly appropriate the master utility system, water, sewer, reclaimed/reuse water, stormwater, garbage collection, trash collection and recyclable collection services furnished or provided by the city either to or for the benefit of consumers and their property. 
(Ord. No. 2013-14, § 3, 10-21-13) 
Sec. 29-2. - Scope of provisions. 
    The provisions of this chapter, in addition to all applicable laws, rules and regulations, are hereby made part of the terms and conditions pursuant to which the city shall furnish utility service or make utility connections or perform any work of any kind in connection with the furnishing of any utility service to any person or customer. 
(Ord. No. 2013-14, § 3, 10-21-13) 
Sec. 29-3. - Right of entry. 
    Any authorized employee or agent of the city shall have reasonable access to all premises supplied with any utility service by the city for the purpose of examination in order to protect the public and the utility services from abusive use. 
(Ord. No. 2013-14, § 3, 10-21-13) 
Sec. 29-4. - City not liable for damage. 
    The city shall not be liable for any damage to any customer of any utility service furnished by the city due to back flow of the sewerage system, failure of supply, failure of collection, or interruption of services or any other cause outside the direct control of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2013-14, § 3, 10-21-13) 
Sec. 29-5. - Authority to establish regulations, standards, and specifications. 
    The city commission shall have the authority to establish by resolution such rules, regulations, standards and specifications as may be deemed necessary for the installation, construction, operation, maintenance, billing or implementation of the city utility system. Any such rules, regulations, standards and specifications shall be filed in the office of the city clerk. Violations of such rules, regulations, standards and specifications shall be deemed a violation of this article and punishable as provided for in this Code and by law. 
(Ord. No. 2013-14, § 3, 10-21-13) 
Sec. 29-6. - Service to comply with technical provisions. 
    Any utility service furnished under the provisions of this chapter shall be in accordance with and in compliance with all applicable technical provisions of this Code, state law, and other and applicable rules, regulations, standards and specifications. 
(Ord. No. 2013-14, § 3, 10-21-13) 
Sec. 29-7. - Connection required for certain buildings. 
(a)  The owner, tenant or occupant of a structure or unit within the city which abuts a street, public easement or other public right-of-way containing a city sanitary sewer or potable water line that is readily available to serve the structure or unit shall connect such structure or unit to the city sanitary sewer and potable water system and shall cease to use any other method for the disposal of sewage waste or the use of a well for potable water purposes. Sanitary sewer, potable water and reclaimed lines are considered for the purpose of this chapter to be readily available when structures or units may be connected to an accessible utility service point that is equal to or less than two hundred (200) feet from an existing water, sewer, or reclaimed main or connection point. 
    If connection is not accomplished, the city clerk or designee shall notify the property owner, tenant or occupant of such requirement and allow fifteen (15) days within which to connect to the system. If connection is still not accomplished, at the expiration of the fifteen (15) days, and upon reasonable written notice thereof by certified mail, return receipt requested or hand delivered with signed receipt, the city clerk or designee shall authorize the connection and recovery from the owner of such parcel all reasonable and actual costs, but not less than the charges set forth in this article, of making such connection, including reasonable attorney's fees and applicable interest, if necessary. Such charges shall be subject to collection procedures as set forth in section 29-37. 
(b)  With regards to new construction, any required fees relating to the provision of utility services, including impact fees or facility investment fees, however identified, of the city or Manatee County, which may become subject to collection by the city, shall be prepaid to the utility system for connection prior to the receipt of the building permit. Approved connection must be accomplished before the issuance of any certificate of occupancy or temporary certificate of occupancy. 
(c)  Prior to any new connection or any reconnection to the potable water, sanitary sewer, or reclaimed water system by any customer, any past due, delinquent or outstanding charges owed to the utility system by that customer shall be made current and paid to the system before a building permit is issued. After payment of such past due, delinquent or outstanding charges, the city will accomplish connection upon payment of any required connection or reconnection fees and any applicable security deposit. 
(d)  In order for a lot or parcel of land to receive any form of utility service from the city, it must be located within the city limits or contiguous to the city limits and consents to being annexed into the city; except that those lots or parcels located outside the city limits and receiving utility services from the city on November 1, 2013, that have not so consented at the time of approval of this article shall continue to receive such services from the city. Alternatively, if a lot or parcel is not contiguous to the city limits so as to permit voluntary annexation by the owner, then the owner must execute a valid and binding annexation agreement with the city whereby the owner agrees to and authorizes annexation of the property once the lot or parcel is contiguous and subject to voluntary annexation as allowed by state law. Such annexation agreements shall be recorded by the city in the Manatee County public records. 
(Ord. No. 2013-14, § 3, 10-21-13) 
Sec. 29-8. - Payment of connection charges prerequisite to issuance of building permit. 
    Any person requesting a building permit for construction within the city, where the building to be constructed is required or applies to be connected to the city potable water and sanitary sewer system according to the provisions of this chapter, shall pay or cause to be paid all applicable impact fees or other facility investment fees of the city or Manatee County which may become the subject of city collection, and other charges for connection to the water or sewer system, including payment of installation charges and costs of additional pipe where necessary to complete the connection before issuance of the building permit. A receipt issued by the clerk of the court verifying payment of educational impact fees must be presented before issuance of a certificate of occupancy. Additionally, as may be authorized by the city's land development regulations or other applicable City Code provisions, owners, customers or developers may be required to construct or extend the infrastructure of the utility system necessary to serve the property or development involved at their sole expense. In the event the city requests over-sizing of the infrastructure to provide greater capacity than required the property or development, the additional cost shall be paid by the city. 
(Ord. No. 2013-14, § 3, 10-21-13) 
Sec. 29-9. - Application for service and accounts. 
(a)  A customer desiring any utility service furnished by the city shall apply to the city clerk or designee. The application shall contain the name and address of the customer, as well as the name(s) and address(es) of the property owner(s) when the owner(s) is not the customer, and the names and addresses of the real parties in interest or those having an interest in the customer when it is not a natural person. The application shall also set forth the site address (if different from the account address), property tax identification number, legal description (if available), meter size requested, number of utility fixtures per unit and any other necessary and appropriate information. The customer shall present to the city some form of official identification as may be requested and reasonably necessary and intended to assist the city in adequately servicing the account and providing the utility service to the customer. This information shall also contain any credit information, deposit amounts and type of service being requested and such other necessary information as deemed by the city to be appropriate. The city may request documents such as a lease agreement, settlement statement or any other document in order to verify that the customer establishing a utility account is authorized to do so. The furnishing of utility service constitutes a special benefit to the property and to the customer being served. The customer shall be provided with utility service by agreement in accordance with applicable law, city ordinances, rules and regulations and in accordance with the application. The forms shall be provided by the city to the customer. 
(b)  In addition to the provisions of subsection (a) above, all master metered accounts for potable water will be established in the name of the property owner. In the case of condominiums, and where applicable mobile home and RV parks, the customer account shall be established in the name of the association or owner as may be appropriate. 
(Ord. No. 2013-14, § 3, 10-21-13) 
Sec. 29-10. - Annexation and inspection of premises outside city. 
    In order to protect the city's ability to serve its residents and supply its customers, the city shall not connect or reconnect any water or sewer taps outside the city limits until the premises involved has been either annexed into the city or is the subject of a valid and binding annexation agreement as provided in this chapter, and has been inspected and approved by the city. Customers who are outside city limits and receiving water and sewer services as of November l, 2013 or receiving water and sewer services as a condition of the Manatee County wholesale water agreement shall continue to receive service. 
(Ord. No. 2013-14, § 3, 10-21-13) 
Sec. 29-11. - Meters required. 
(a)  Meters. Meters for the measurement of water and/or sewer utility services provided by the city shall be furnished and installed by and shall remain the property of the city. The customer is responsible for the safekeeping of new and existing meters and for keeping sites readily accessible for reading meters and service. It is unlawful and a violation of this Code for any person to vandalize or unlock without authorization any such meter. If any obstruction or lack of accessibility is not corrected by the customer within fourteen (14) days after written notification by the city, the city may take any steps it deems reasonably necessary to ensure accessibility in order to read the meter and may charge the customer account the cost of correction. 
(b)  Individual meters required. All residential and nonresidential units, except as otherwise provided in this chapter, are required to have individual meters. 
(c)  Master meter required. All new residential and nonresidential units with a facility with common plumbing lines, are required to utilize a master meter. All master metered accounts shall be established in the name of the property owner, landlord or association, as may be appropriate. 
(d)  Installation. Unless otherwise authorized by the city, all meters must be installed at the property line adjoining or adjacent to a public street, right-of-way or easement as approved by the city and not at individual lot lines adjacent to or abutting a private street, drive or access. 
(Ord. No. 2013-14, § 3, 10-21-13) 
Sec. 29-12. - Determination of size of meter. 
    The customer may request a certain water meter size based on the application and information submitted to the city. The city shall have the final decision to determine and authorize the meter size necessary for the service requested. 
(Ord. No. 2013-14, § 3, 10-21-13) 
Sec. 29-13. - Responsibility for damage. 
    Where utility meters are broken or damaged by the negligence or willful acts of a customer or those under the customer' s control or responsibility, the cost of repair or replacement shall be charged to and paid by the customer, in advance of such repair or replacement, and prior to renewal of service. Utility service may be denied or discontinued until payment is delivered and repairs accomplished. The customer charged for the cost, repair or replacement may appeal such charges to the supervisor of customer service, or a designee, within fifteen (15) days of the assessment of the damage charge by filing with the supervisor a written appeal setting forth the basis of the appeal and the facts involved. The supervisor, or a designee, shall render a written decision on the appeal within ten (10) working days of the appeal being filed with the supervisor. The decision of the supervisor shall be final. 
    Any person or persons aggrieved by a decision of the supervisor shall have thirty (30) days from the date the supervisor issues a written decision to apply for relief to a court of competent jurisdiction in the manner provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 2013-14, § 3, 10-21-13) 
Sec. 29-14. - Unlawful connections. 
    Any person who shall causer allow or make any unauthorized connection or reconnection in any manner to any utility system owned by the city, without the prior authorization, approval or consent of the city, shall be in violation of this article. This city shall have the right to seek any and all remedies provided by this Code or at law, and to recover costs and attorney fees incurred in connection with the pursuit of such remedies. 
(Ord. No. 2013-14, § 3, 10-21-13) 
Sec. 29-15. - City employees or agents authorized to connect, disconnect, repair, replace equipment. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, other than employees of the city or the city's authorized agents, subcontractors or assigns, to connect or turn on any utility service at the city's utility point of connection without first obtaining authorization and approval by the city. 
(Ord. No. 2013-14, § 3, 10-21-13) 
Sec. 29-16. - Damage, trespass of equipment or premises. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, not having authority from the city to do so, to open any meter or water hydrant or tamper with any utility service or system furnished by the city; to in any way pollute, degrade, adulterize, contaminate, molest, damage, trespass upon, or take or convert to their own or some other person's or consumers use, any commodity, service, equipment or premises connected with any city utility service. 
(Ord. No. 2013-14, § 3, 10-21-13) 
Sec. 29-17. - Use assumed if premises connected. 
    All premises connected to or for which any utility service of the city is available, shall be assumed to be using utility services and the customer shall be charged a readiness-to-serve fee as long as either the availability of service to the premises remains, any connection continues or use of the services occur. Whenever the premises involves rental or leased property and the customer (i.e., tenant or lessee) terminates service or abandons the property, the property owner shall be responsible for the payment of the readiness-to-serve charge on an interim basis until a new customer for the premises has been established with the city. 
(Ord. No. 2013-14, § 3, 10-21-13) 
Sec. 29-18. - Owner shut off valve required. 
    Owners of premises under construction that shall be connected to any utility service of the city shall be required to install a shut off valve at the property line or immediately after the meter. Such valve shall be under the control of the owner or customer, to be used in the event of a break in the line or other necessities, so that the utility service can be shut off and repairs performed without using the city installed shut off valve. 
(Ord. No. 2013-14, § 3, 10-21-13) 
Sec. 29-19. - Maintenance of system by customer. 
    The customer of any utility service furnished by the city shall maintain and keep in good repair all connections, appliances, fixtures, lines, equipment and other apparatus located on the property. 
    A customer or other person approved for utility service and utilizing or connected to the utility system, or any person having a permit from the city authorizing the use of any utility servicer who shall use such utility service for any purpose other than as intended, or approved or authorized by the city or the permit, or who shall make any unauthorized changes in such service, shall be in violation of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2013-14, § 3, 10-21-13) 
Sec. 29-20. - Sale of service by customer. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person or entity to resell any utility service obtained from the city to others, except by written agreement, permit or arrangement with the city approved by the city commission. 
(Ord. No. 2013-14, § 3, 10-21-13) 
Sec. 29-21. - Authority to restrict use. 
    The city hereby reserves the right at any time to restrict or prevent the improper and unauthorized use of any utility service furnished by the city whether during periods of emergency or under such circumstances or conditions demanding such restriction or prevention of use as deemed appropriate by the city. 
(Ord. No. 2013-14, § 3, 10-21-13) 
Sec. 29-22. - Temporary interruption of service. 
    The city reserves the right to interrupt, discontinue or cut off any utility service without notice in case of emergencies. When an interruption in service is necessary for the maintenance and improvement of the utility system, affected customers shall be notified as reason and circumstances permit. 
(Ord. No. 2013-14, § 3, 10-21-13) 
Sec. 29-23. - Non-sanitary wastes prohibited in sanitary sewers. 
    There shall be no connections of surface drainage, stormwater or any non-sanitary waste to sanitary sewer lines, facilities or sanitary sewage system of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2013-14, § 3, 10-21-13) 
Sec. 29-24. - Industrial waste. 
    Industrial waste shall not be connected to or deposited into the city sanitary sewage system unless authorized, permitted or approved by the public works department and all appropriate pretreatment requirements have been established and implemented. Each individual case must be reviewed to determine the effect on the overall sewerage system and the sewerage treatment plant. The customer or entity seeking connection to the utility system for industrial waste shall be responsible for all costs associated with the evaluation, study and consideration of the acceptability of such waste and connection to the system. A determination of the estimated expense or cost owed by the customer must be made by the city and paid by the customer prior to any evaluation, study, connection or usage. The customer shall additionally be responsible for any and all costs associated with pretreatment, testing and determining the acceptability of industrial waste flows to the system. 
(Ord. No. 2013-14, § 3, 10-21-13) 
Sec. 29-25. - Authority to require pretreatment facilities. 
    The city shall have the right to require any customer who is a producer of industrial, non-domestic or extreme sewerage waste to implement necessary pretreatment requirements at the customer's own expense, prior to connecting to or continuing usage of the city's sewerage facilities. 
(Ord. No. 2013-14, § 3, 10-21-13) 
Sec. 29-26. - Individual private sewage treatment facilities. 
    Permitted individual septic tanks or other private sewage treatment systems or facilities for sewage treatment on a residential single lot or parcel may be installed for use by the property owner on that real property to serve one (1) residential unit within the city limits upon approval of the public works department where the city does not have or furnish sewer facilities at the lot or parcel and it would be financially unreasonable to require the owner to pay all charges to undertake connection to the system. However, once city sewer service is readily available, as determined pursuant to subsection 29-35(b) of this article, the property owner shall cease utilization of the private treatment facility and connect to the city's system in accordance with this chapter. This provision shall be interpreted and applied in keeping with the provisions of section 29-35 hereof. 
(Ord. No. 2013-14, § 3, 10-21-13) 
Sec. 29-27. - Private wells. 
    Privately owned wells may only be used or new wells drilled within the city as provided by this chapter. When the city's potable water system is not available, wells may be used for the purpose of lawn sprinkling or irrigation in accordance with the city's reclaim or reuse water provisions, or for operation of air-conditioning units, filling of swimming pools or similar non-domestic or potable water uses as may be allowed by city regulations. In areas within the city where the city does not furnish potable water, privately owned wells for domestic potable water consumption may be used or drilled upon approval of the public works department and any other applicable governmental permitting or approving agency. No wells may be drilled for a purpose not authorized by this section. However, once city potable water service is readily available, as determined pursuant to subsection 29-35(b) of this article, the property owner shall cease utilization of such well for domestic potable water consumption or service and connect to the city's system in accordance with this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2013-14, § 3, 10-21-13) 
Sec. 29-28. - Termination of service authorized. 
    The city shall have the right to discontinue, disconnect, or refuse to provide, connect or reconnect any and all city utility services, including, but not limited to water, sewer and reclaimed service, for the following reasons: 
(1)  Failure to meet the applicable requirements for service or other provisions of this chapter, other applicable city ordinances or state law; 
(2)  Violation of city policies, rules, regulations, standards and specifications pertaining to any utility service; 
(3)  Nonpayment of any utility system charges, fees or bills; 
(4)  Willful or negligent waste of any applicable utility service due to customer's improper or damaged pipes, fixtures, appliances, equipment or otherwise; 
(5)  Molesting or damaging any meter, seal or other equipment controlling or regulating the supply of utility service or any other action as proscribed by this article; and 
(6)  Theft, diversion, or unauthorized use of any utility service without first receiving proper approval and authorization and making payment therefor. 
(Ord. No. 2013-14, § 3, 10-21-13) 
Sec. 29-29. - Meter deposits-Schedule. 
(a)  Pursuant to the following schedule, a deposit for utility service shall be required on all accounts. The deposit shall be held by the city until all bills for utility service are paid in full, or until the deposit is applied to outstanding charges on the account as authorized by this article. Any remainder shall be refunded to the customer within thirty (30) days of discontinuance of service. The city will place the deposit in an appropriate account for the benefit of the city and the customer to be allocated as hereinafter provided based on the exercise of sound judgment and discretion by the city clerk or designee.

(b)  Security deposits for construction purposes are established as security against services rendered and meter losses for construction/development purposes.

Fire hydrant meter per meter ..... 650.00 
Security deposits may be retained by the city at the request of the contractor or developer for future use. If utility bills are not paid in a timely manner and such bills equal or exceed the security deposit, the city may refuse further service pending payment. 
(c)  Regarding master metered accounts an additional deposit of twenty dollars ($20.00) per unit shall be required and in the case of rental units or apartment complexes and duplex rental projects, multi-family developments or rental mobile home parks and travel trailer parks, to a total maximum deposit on the master meter of two thousand dollars ($2,000.00). 
(d)  Regarding new or additional deposits, the city may require, upon reasonable written notice or at the time of establishment of the account, a new deposit where previously waived or refunded, or an additional deposit in order to secure payment of current bills, as may be applicable based on the credit and payment history of the customer. In the case of a new account by a person who has previously been a customer of the city utility system and exhibited a poor credit or payment history or discontinued service with the city owing the utility system for previous service, the deposit amount shall be increased to not less than two hundred seventy-five dollars ($275.00) or twice the meter size deposit, whichever is greater, as recommended by the city clerk or the customer service supervisor. Prior to receiving any type of utility service, such customer must pay all outstanding charges and fees owed to the utility system for any and all services. 
(e)  As an incentive to timely and responsible payment of utility system charges and fees, any customer who has not more than one (1) late or delinquent payment within a twenty-four-month period, may request a refund of the meter deposit as a credit against future utility bills for monthly consumption charges until a refund in full occurs. However, after any such refund, if the customer has more than one (1) late or delinquent payment in a calendar year, then the customer shall, upon written notification and billing for same, be required to pay the city the applicable meter deposit as required by this article. 
(Ord. No. 2013-14, § 3, 10-21-13) 
Sec. 29-30. - Effect of transfer, moving. 
    The city shall allow for the transfer of accounts and deposits from one (1) location/billing address to another for utility services. The deposit can be transferred to another account if the account that is being closed is in good standing and there are no outstanding balances. When premises are vacated, any amounts due the city for utility service shall be paid or deducted by the city from the deposit. Utility services shall not be commenced at another location until full payment is accomplished. A request for utility services at a new location shall require an applicant to pay the deposit that is in effect at the time of such application unless it is being transferred from a previous account 
(Ord. No. 2013-14, § 3, 10-21-13) 
Sec. 29-31. - Connection charges-Generally. 
(a)  A connection charge will be paid for any connection or reconnection to the utility system. 
(b)  Connection charges: 
(1)  Connection charges for water accounts shall be the greater of the actual cost of providing the connection plus twenty-five (25) percent or a standard charge based on the tap size, as follows:

(3)  Connections to the utility system are required if the tap point is accessible and equal to or less than two hundred (200) feet from an existing main or connection point, except as required by other ordinances or planned unit development or subdivision plan reviews, at the owner's expense. 
(Ord. No. 2013-14, § 3, 10-21-13)

Any rate increases, fees or other monies charged by Manatee County to the city as a wholesale customer, whether in the volume, facility investment fee or readiness-to-serve charge category, shall be directly passed through as an appropriate equal rate increase applied to customers of the city utility system through the water rates in keeping with the charge increase to the city as a wholesale customer. Appropriate notice of this automatic increase shall be given to customers of the city's utility system. Additionally, no less than once every two (2) years the city shall review the schedule of rates, fees and charges of the utility system to determine their adequacy and adjust such rates, fees and charges as deemed to be necessary and in the public's interest. As permitted by state law, a surcharge may be levied against potable water customers for service to property not located within the city limits, unless otherwise prohibited by our wholesale water agreement with Manatee County. (2)  For those customers or users of reclaimed/reuse water provided by the city who are located within a "common area residential reuse unit" (CARU) which includes or applies to apartments, condominiums, rental mobile home parks and townhouse projects, each unit shall pay a reclaimed/reuse water charge at the rate of three dollars and sixty cents ($3.60) per month for every month or portion thereof that reclaimed/reuse water system and service is available to the customer's property.

(Ord. No. 2013-14, § 3, 10-21-13) 
Sec. 29-34. - Monthly rates-Determination for non-connected structures. 
(a)  Owners of improved property with occupied and/or unoccupied structures not connected to available water and sewer service shall be charged a monthly minimum total fixed charge for each service. 
(b)  Vacant lots shall not be subject to the monthly minimum fixed charge unless there is a water or irrigation meter installed a the property. 
(Ord. No. 2013-14, § 3, 10-21-13) 
Sec. 29-35. - Mandatory connection to system. 
(a)  It is the intent and policy of the city that all residents and structures or units within the city limits be served with potable water, sanitary sewer service and reuse water service. The city considers this policy to be of extreme public importance for both the health and welfare of the citizens, as well as the protection of the environment. The utilization of septic systems and other non-publicly owned treatment systems are prohibited when municipal services to the property are readily available. 
(b)  For the purpose of this article, services are considered to be readily available when structures or units may be connected to an accessible utility service point that is equal to or less than two hundred (200) feet from an existing water or sewer main or connection point. All new development within the city limits shall be served by the central, municipally-owned potable water, sanitary sewer system and reuse water service. Connection as provided in this chapter shall be at the expense of the customer unless a specific city program (i.e., special assessment project) is established to address connection. 
(c)  It is the policy of the city that new development be responsible for the extension of necessary utility lines and infrastructure for service from existing mains, lines or infrastructure to the new development. 
(d)  It is the policy and intent of the city that all structures or units served with utility services be within the city limits and that annexation, where legally permissible, or the execution and delivery of a valid and binding annexation agreement, is required as a condition precedent to the receipt of utility services. 
(Ord. No. 2013-14, § 3, 10-21-13) 
Sec. 29-36. - Voluntary discontinuance of service. 
(a)  Customers wishing to discontinue the use of any utility service due to transfer of the property, demolition or other permissible reason shall give prior written notice thereof to the city clerk or designee. Failure to give said notice and to close the account with payment of all charges shall render the customer responsible and liable for the payment of all bills until such account has been paid in full and closed. 
(b)  For the purpose of this chapter, it shall not be a permissible reason for obtaining or seeking voluntarily discontinuance of service at a residence occupied by the customer's spouse, or the customer's minor children, when involved in a domestic conflict or separation (unless provided so by appropriate order of a court of competent jurisdiction) in order to dislocate or remove the referenced spouse or said minor children from the residential unit. For the purpose of this provision, regardless of the fact that only one (1) spouse's name is upon the account as "customer" shall be presumed that both spouses as well as any minor children are beneficial "customers" of the system for this purpose and voluntary discontinuance shall occur only upon separate written mutual consent by each spouse or the guardian of the minor children, delivered to the city. 
(Ord. No. 2013-14, § 3, 10-21-13) 
Sec. 29-37. - Payment due. 
(a)  All bills for utility services enumerated under this article shall be due and payable prior to 5:00 p.m. on the twentieth (20th) day following the date of such bill. If the due date occurs on a weekend or holiday, the bill must be paid prior to 5:00 p.m. on the first weekday following such weekend or holiday. 
(b)  Upon failure of any customer to pay for services rendered by the utility system within forty-five (45) days of billing, the city shall discontinue service to such customer and shall not furnish or permit customer to receive further service until all amounts owed to the city on the account are satisfied and paid in full. The city may, in the event of discontinuing service, apply all or part of the security deposit held on the account to the delinquent account. If the customer shall thereafter request reinstitution of service, such customer shall deposit with the city a new security deposit in keeping with this chapter. 
(c)  For owner customers, the uncollected utility bill may constitute and be a lien upon the applicable real property. The city clerk's office shall be responsible for recording liens. The lien shall be subject to annual interest costs of not less than nine (9) percent, subject to foreclosure after one (1) year of filing and recording the lien document in the public records of Manatee County. For non-owner customers, the city shall pursue such other enforcement or collection procedures or remedies as may be allowed by law. The owner of residential or non-residential property connected to a city utility service shall be responsible for the readiness-to-serve charge during time the residential or non-residential unit is unoccupied. 
(d)  If the delinquent account is a master meter account, the owner of the property shall be responsible for payment of the utility bill and any deposit as provided by this chapter. 
(e)  In the interest of cost effectiveness, the city will not issue credit refunds for final bills of less than five dollars ($5.00) unless requested by the customer. 
(Ord. No. 2013-14, § 3, 10-21-13) 
Sec. 29-38. - Enforcement and penalties. 
(a)  Delinquency. Utility service may be discontinued on delinquent accounts. Prior notice giving a date for termination of service shall be sent by standard U.S. Mail to the billing address of record, or accomplished through personal service by posting the notice on the premises or hanging on the door in a clearly visible location such appropriate notice. If any customer shall fail to pay the delinquent amount within sixteen (16) days of said amount being due, a penalty charge equal to ten (10) percent of the amount of the current monthly charge shall be added on to the account. If the account has not been paid within forty-five (45) days of the billing date, discontinuance of service and disconnect shall be accomplished by the city. If such final due date falls on a Friday, the disconnect date shall be the next business day. 
(b)  Habitual delinquency. The city reserves the right to increase the security deposit provided for in this chapter for any customer who has had utility services disconnected by the city because of delinquency three (3) or more times, or who has presented two (2) or more bad checks within a twelve-month period. The additional security deposit may be modified as provided for in section 29-29(e). 
(c)  Discontinuance of service. Pursuant to this chapter, non-payment of account for services when due may result in: 
(1)  Discontinuance of utility services; and 
(2)  The filing of a lawsuit in a court of competent jurisdiction to enforce this chapter and to recover all charges owed. 
    For reinstatement of services, the customer must pay all delinquent fees and charges. Water service will be subject to a consumption charge based on the estimated usage, other applicable charges and the city's cost of disconnection and reconnection. This provision shall apply to connection to fire hydrants and fire lines for other than testing and emergency fire fighting. 
    The city provides a comprehensive utility service relating to and including potable water, sanitary sewer, sanitation/solid waste collection, reuse water, stormwater and other collateral and ancillary services connected with the delivery of utility services. Failure to maintain current payment terms for all utility services rendered by the city may result in discontinuance of any or all utility services provided. At the discretion of the city, payment for all utility services in arrears may be required, as well as additional deposit requirements, prior to reinitiating any utility services as provided by this chapter. The utility services provided are inter-related and an integral part (both separately and collectively) of the city's plan for the delivery of total utility service in order to protect the public health, safety and welfare, as well as protecting the natural environment. Therefore, the city may resort to the discontinuance of any and all utility services as a proper mechanism for the collection of accounts in arrears on any specific or individual utility service rendered, as well as enforcement of this chapter. 
(d)  Unauthorized use or consumption of water. Unauthorized use or consumption of water from the city utility system shall be subject to a consumption charge based on an estimated usage, all applicable charges and the city's cost of discontinuing service and enforcement. These costs include not only collection fees and charges, but a reasonable attorney's fee and costs of the city if the city resorts to litigation to enforce this chapter. 
(e)  Unauthorized disconnection from sanitary sewer system. Any customer connected to the sanitary sewer system who disconnects from that system, without authorization by the city, for other than repair purposes, shall be subject to the cost incurred by the city to reconnect the service to the system. The city shall have the right to enter private property for the purpose of reconnection. The delivery of sanitary sewer service to the citizens of the city is an important and integral part of the city's obligation to protect the public health, safety and welfare as well as protect the natural environment. 
(f)  Cross-connection/inter-connection. Failure to address or correct, upon notification by the city, any improper cross-connection or inter-connection of services by a specified date shall result in termination of utility service to all affected structures and the levying of appropriate charges by the city relating to such action. Customers who knowingly supply utility services to individuals, residences, businesses or units that have been disconnected by the city shall be liable for payment of the total monthly fixed charges for all units being served and a tampering charge will be levied to the customer in violation. This provision is in addition to any penalties or enforcement provided by the city's cross-connection control/regulations. 
(g)  All remedies retained. The city hereby retains the right to pursue all remedies available at law and equity to enforce this article, including, but not limited to a suit to recover damages or obtain equitable relief. In any action initiated by the city to enforce this article, the city is permitted and authorized to recoup its attorney's fees and costs. 
(Ord. No. 2013-14, § 3, 10-21-13) 
Sec. 29-39. - Reserved. 
Sec. 29-40. - Delinquency notice following disconnection. 
    The office of the city clerk or designee shall send a notice of delinquency to property owners of locations where the service has been cut off for non-payment and not reinstated as of the next reading date. 
(Ord. No. 2013-14, § 3, 10-21-13) 
Sec. 29-41. - Reconnection after discontinuance. 
(a)  If any utility service is discontinued for the non-payment of a bill, the customer may apply to be reinstated but only upon the payment of all amounts due plus a fee of twenty dollars ($20.00). Reinstatement of service after 5:00 p.m. on weekends or on holidays will be subject to a fee of forty dollars ($40.00). 
(b)  If any utility service is disconnected for non-payment of the bill and removal of the water meter occurs, the customer may apply for reconnection but only upon the payment of all amounts due and a reconnection fee of seventy-five dollars ($75.00). 
(Ord. No. 2013-14, § 3, 10-21-13) 
Sec. 29-42. - Additional remedy. 
    All owners of property accepting or upon which utility services are delivered from the city, by such acceptance, consent that any lawful charge made for such services shall constitute a lien upon and against the property receiving such services. This utility lien may be enforced and collected by the city through foreclosure as provided by law. This remedy shall be in addition to all other remedies available to the city. The city shall be entitled to receive all costs incurred in collection of and enforcement of the lien through foreclosure, including a reasonable attorney's fee. 
(Ord. No. 2013-14, § 3, 10-21-13) 
Sec. 29-43. - Special service charges. 
    The following special service charges shall be collected by the city, when applicable: 
Service call after 5:00 p.m., weekends or holiday ..... $40.00

plus actual

plus 20%

(Ord. No. 2013-14, § 3, 10-21-13) 
Sec. 29-44. - Effective date of rates, charges and fees. 
    All rates, charges and fees provided for herein shall, upon adoption of this article, be deemed to have been in effect as of November 1, 2013. Customers shall be responsible for payment of said rates, charges and fees, with respect to services provided by the city to the customer on or after said date. 
(Ord. No. 2013-14, § 3, 10-21-13) 
Secs. 29-45-29-60. - Reserved.
