    WHEREAS, the City Commission of the City of Palmetto deems it to be in the best interest of the City of Palmetto and its citizens to enter into the new franchise agreement prior to expiration of the current franchise agreement; 
Be it ordained by the City Commission of the City of Palmetto, Florida: 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Printed herein is the electric franchise adopted as Ordinance Number 2011-03, §§ 1-15, enacted February, 28, 2011, granting a franchise to Florida Power and Light Co. 

Section 1. - [Franchise granted.] 
    There is hereby granted to Florida Power & Light Company, its successors and assigns (hereinafter called the "grantee"), for the period of thirty (30) years from the effective date hereof, the nonexclusive right, privilege and franchise (hereinafter called "franchise") to construct, operate and maintain in, under, upon, along, over and across the present and future roads, streets, alleys, bridges, easements, rights-of-way and other public places (hereinafter called "public rights-of-way") throughout all of the incorporated areas, as such incorporated areas may be constituted from time to time, of the City of Palmetto, Florida, and its successors (hereinafter called the "grantor"), in accordance with the grantee's customary practice with respect to construction and maintenance, electric light and power facilities, including, without limitation, conduits, poles, wires, transmission and distribution lines, and all other facilities installed in conjunction with or ancillary to all of the grantee's operations (hereinafter called "facilities"), for the purpose of supplying electricity and other services to the grantor and its successors, the inhabitants thereof, and persons beyond the limits thereof. 
Section 2. - [Use of public rights-of-way.] 
(a)  The facilities of the grantee shall be installed, located or relocated so as to not unreasonably interfere with traffic over the public rights-of-way or with reasonable egress from and ingress to abutting property. 
(b)  To avoid conflicts with traffic, the location or relocation of all facilities shall be made as representatives of the grantor may prescribe in accordance with the grantor's reasonable rules and regulations with reference to the placing and maintaining in, under, upon, along, over and across said public rights-of-way; provided, however, that such rules or regulations: 
(i)  Shall not prohibit the exercise of the grantee's right to use said public rights-of-way for reasons other than unreasonable interference with motor vehicular traffic, 
(ii)  Shall not unreasonably interfere with the grantee's ability to furnish reasonably sufficient, adequate and efficient electric service to all of its customers, and 
(iii)  Shall not require the relocation of any of the grantee's facilities installed before or after the effective date hereof in public rights-of-way unless or until widening or otherwise changing the configuration of the paved portion of any public right-of-way used by motor vehicles causes such installed facilities to unreasonably interfere with motor vehicular traffic. 
(c)  Such rules and regulations shall recognize that above-grade facilities of the grantee installed after the effective date hereof should be installed near the outer boundaries of the public rights-of-way to the extent possible and such installation shall comply with the Florida Department of Transportation's Manual of Uniform Minimum Standards for Design, Construction and Maintenance for Streets and Highways. 
(d)  When any portion of a public right-of-way is excavated by the grantee in the location or relocation of any of its facilities, the portion of the public right-of-way so excavated shall within a reasonable time and as early as practicable after such excavation be restored by the grantee at its expense and in as good condition as it was at the time of such excavation. 
(e)  The grantor shall not be liable to the grantee for any cost or expense in connection with any relocation of the grantee's facilities required under subsection (b)(iii) of this section, except, however, the grantee shall be entitled to reimbursement of its costs from others and as may be provided by law. 
Section 3. - [Liability of grantor.] 
    The grantor shall in no way be liable or responsible for any accident or damage that may occur in the construction, operation or maintenance by the grantee of its facilities hereunder, and the acceptance of this ordinance shall be deemed an agreement on the part of the grantee to indemnify the grantor and hold it harmless against any and all liability, loss, cost, damage or expense, including grantor's reasonable attorneys' fees and costs incurred in defending itself against any such claims which may be asserted against grantor by others, which may accrue to the grantor by reason of the negligence, default or misconduct of the grantee in the construction, operation or maintenance of its facilities hereunder. 
Section 4. - [Rates, rules, regulations.] 
    All rates and rules and regulations established by the grantee from time to time shall be subject to such regulation as may be provided by law. 
Section 5. - [Monthly payment-Amount.] 
(a)  As a consideration for this franchise, the grantee shall pay to the grantor, commencing ninety (90) days after the effective date hereof, and each month thereafter for the remainder of the term of this franchise, an amount which added to the amount of all licenses, excises, fees, charges and other impositions of any kind whatsoever (except ad valorem property taxes and non-ad valorem tax assessments on property) levied or imposed by the grantor against the grantee's property, business or operations and those of its subsidiaries during the grantee's monthly billing period ending sixty (60) days prior to each such payment will equal six (6) percent of the grantee's billed revenues, less actual write-offs, from the sale of electrical energy to residential, commercial and industrial customers (as such customers are defined by FPL's tariff) within the incorporated areas of the grantor for the monthly billing period ending sixty (60) days prior to each such payment, and in no event shall payment for the rights and privileges granted herein exceed six (6) percent of such revenues for any monthly billing period of the grantee. Grantee shall continue to receive franchise payments under the current franchise agreement through the effective date of this new franchise agreement and during the period between the effective date of this new franchise agreement and the first payment hereunder. 
    The grantor understands and agrees that such revenues as described in the preceding paragraph are limited to the precise revenues described therein, and that such revenues do not include, by way of example and not limitation: (a) revenues from the sale of electrical energy for public street and highway lighting (service for lighting public ways and areas); (b) revenues from other sales to public authorities (service with eligibility restricted to governmental entities); (c) revenues from sales to railroads and railways (service supplied for propulsion of electric transit vehicles); (d) revenues from sales for resale (service to other utilities for resale purposes); (e) franchise fees; (f) late payment charges; (g) field collection charges; (h) other service charges. 
(b)  If during the term of this franchise the grantee enters into a franchise agreement with any other municipality located in Manatee County or Sarasota County, Florida, where the number of grantee's active electrical customers is equal to or less than fifteen thousand (15,000), the terms of which provide for the payment of franchise fees by the Grantee at a rate greater than six (6) percent of the grantee's residential, commercial and industrial revenues (as such customers are defined by FPL's tariff), under the same terms and conditions as specified in section 5 hereof, the grantee upon written request of the grantor, shall negotiate and enter into a new franchise agreement with the grantor in which the percentage to be used in calculating monthly payments under section 5 hereof shall be no greater than that percentage which the grantee has agreed to use as a basis for the calculation of payments to the other Manatee County or Sarasota County municipality, provided, however, that such new franchise agreement shall include additional benefits to the grantee, in addition to all benefits provided herein, at least equal to those provided by its franchise agreement with the other Manatee County or Sarasota County municipality. 
Section 6. - [Purchase of property by grantor.] 
    As a further consideration, during the term of this franchise or any extension thereof, the grantor agrees: (a) not to engage in the distribution and/or sale, in competition with the grantee, of electric capacity and/or electric energy to any ultimate consumer of electric utility service (herein called a "retail customer") or to any electrical distribution system established solely to serve any retail customer formerly served by the grantee, (b) not to participate in any proceeding or contractual arrangement, the purpose or terms of which would be to obligate the grantee to transmit and/or distribute, electric capacity and/or electric energy from any third party(ies) to any other retail customer's facility(ies), and (c) not to seek to have the grantee transmit and/or distribute electric capacity and/or electric energy generated by or on behalf of the grantor at one (1) location to the grantor's facility(ies) at any other location(s). Nothing specified herein shall prohibit the grantor from engaging with other utilities or persons in wholesale transactions which are subject to the provisions of the Federal Power Act or from utilizing generators and/or other electricity or energy-generating equipment during emergency situations. Nothing specified herein shall prohibit the grantee from (i) generating electric capacity and/or energy at any facility owned by the grantor for storage or utilization at that facility; (ii) using renewable energy sources to generate electric capacity and/or energy for use in demonstration projects or at grantor's facilities; or (iii) selling such generated electric capacity and/or energy to grantee or other wholesale purchases in compliance with applicable tariffs and/or federal or state laws, rules and regulations governing such transactions. 
    Nothing herein shall prohibit the grantor, if permitted by law, (i) from purchasing electric capacity and/or electric energy from any other person, or (ii) from seeking to have the grantee transmit and/or distribute to any facility(ies) of the grantor electric capacity and/or electric energy purchased by the grantor from any other person; provided, however, that before the grantor elects to purchase electric capacity and/or electric energy from any other person, the grantor shall notify the grantee. Such notice shall include a summary of the specific rates, terms and conditions which have been offered by the other person and identify the grantor's facilities to be served under the offer. The grantee shall thereafter have ninety (90) days to evaluate the offer and, if the grantee offers rates, terms and conditions which are equal to or better than those offered by the other person, the grantor shall be obligated to continue to purchase from the grantee electric capacity and/or electric energy to serve the previously-identified facilities of the grantor for a term no shorter than that offered by the other person. If the grantee does not agree to rates, terms and conditions which equal or better the other person's offer, all of the terms and conditions of this franchise shall remain in effect. 
    The parties recognize that it is the best interests of the City of Palmetto, its residents, businesses and inhabitants thereof to reduce and control the growth rates of electric consumption; to reduce the growth rates of weather-sensitive peak demand; to increase the overall efficiency and cost effectiveness of electricity production and use and to encourage further development of demand-side renewable energy systems. To that end grantor and grantee agree to use their best efforts to cooperatively work each with the other to promote incentives for customer-owned and utility-owned energy efficiency and demand-side renewable energy intended to offset all or part of a customer's electricity requirements. 
Section 7. - [Termination rights; grantee.] 
    If the grantor grants a right, privilege or franchise to any other person or otherwise enables any other such person to construct, operate or maintain electric light and power facilities within any part of the incorporated areas of the grantor in which the grantee may lawfully serve or compete on terms and conditions which the grantee determines are more favorable than the terms and conditions contained herein, the grantee may at any time thereafter terminate this franchise if such terms and conditions are not remedied within the time period provided hereafter. The grantee shall give the grantor at least one hundred eighty (180) days' advance written notice of its intent to terminate. Such notice shall, without prejudice to any of the rights reserved for the grantee herein, advise the grantor of such terms and conditions that it considers more favorable. The grantor shall then have ninety (90) days in which to correct or otherwise remedy the terms and conditions complained of by the grantee, and the grantor and grantee agree to negotiate in good faith toward a mutually acceptable resolution of grantee's claim during this ninety-day period. If the grantee determines that such terms or conditions are not remedied by the grantor within said time period, and if no mutually acceptable resolution is reached by grantee and grantor through negotiation, the grantee may terminate this franchise agreement by delivering written notice to the grantor's clerk and termination shall be effective on the date of delivery of such notice. Nothing contained herein shall be construed as limiting grantor's rights to legally contest at any time grantee's determination leading to termination. 
Section 8. - [Same; grantor.] 
    If as a direct or indirect consequence of any legislative, regulatory or other action by the United States of America or the State of Florida (or any department, agency, authority, instrumentality or political subdivision of either of them) any person is permitted to provide electric service within the incorporated areas of the grantor to a customer then being served by the grantee, or to any new applicant for electric service within any part of the incorporated areas of the grantor in which the grantee may lawfully serve, and the grantee reasonably determines that its obligations hereunder, or otherwise resulting from this franchise in respect to rates and service, place it at a competitive disadvantage with respect to such other person, the grantee may, at any time after the taking of such action, terminate this franchise if such competitive disadvantage is not remedied within the time period provided hereafter. The grantee shall give the grantor at least one hundred eighty (180) days' advance written notice of its intent to terminate. Such notice shall, without prejudice to any of the rights reserved for the grantee herein, advise the grantor of the consequences of such action which resulted in the competitive disadvantage. The grantor shall then have ninety (90) days in which to correct or otherwise remedy the competitive disadvantage. If such competitive disadvantage is not remedied by the grantor within said time period, the grantee may terminate this franchise agreement by delivering written notice to the grantor's clerk and termination shall take effect on the date of delivery of such notice. Nothing contained herein shall be construed as limiting grantor's rights to legally contest at any time grantee's determination leading to termination. 
Section 9. - [Failure to comply; grantee.] 
    Failure on the part of the grantee to comply in any substantial respect with any of the provisions of this franchise shall be grounds for forfeiture, but no such forfeiture shall take effect if the reasonableness or propriety thereof is protested by the grantee until there is final determination (after the expiration or exhaustion of all rights of appeal) by a court of competent jurisdiction that the grantee has failed to comply in a substantial respect with any of the provisions of this franchise, and the grantee shall have six (6) months after such final determination to make good the default before a forfeiture shall result with the right of the grantor at its discretion to grant such additional time to the grantee for compliance as necessities in the case require. 
Section 10. - [Same; grantor.] 
    Failure on the part of the grantor to comply in substantial respect with any of the provisions of this ordinance, including but not limited to: (a) denying the grantee use of public rights-of-way for reasons other than unreasonable interference with motor vehicular traffic; (b) imposing conditions for use of public rights-of-way contrary to Florida law or the terms and conditions of this franchise; (c) unreasonable delay in issuing the grantee a use permit, if any, to construct its facilities in public rights-of-way, shall constitute breach of this franchise and entitle the grantee to withhold all or part of the payments provided for in section 5 hereof until such time as a use permit is issued or a court of competent jurisdiction has, upon action instituted by grantee, determined to be equitable, just, and reasonable, considering the totality of the circumstances, until such time as a use permit is issued or a court of competent jurisdiction has reached a final determination (after the expiration or exhaustion of all rights of appeal) in the matter. The grantor recognizes and agrees that nothing in this franchise agreement constitutes or shall be deemed to constitute a waiver of the grantee's delegated sovereign right of condemnation and that the grantee, in its sole discretion, may exercise such right. 
Section 11. - [Records examination.] 
    The grantor may, upon reasonable notice and within ninety (90) days after each anniversary date of this franchise, at the grantor's expense, examine the records of the grantee relating to the calculation of the franchise payment for the year preceding such anniversary date. Such examination shall be during normal business hours at the grantee's office where such records are maintained. Records not prepared by the grantee in the ordinary course of business may be provided at the grantor's expense and as the grantor and the grantee may agree in writing. Information identifying the grantee's customers by name or their electric consumption shall not be taken from the grantee's premises. Such audit shall be impartial and all audit findings, whether they decrease or increase payment to the grantor, shall be reported to the grantee. The grantor's right to examine the records of the grantee in accordance with this section shall not be conducted by any third party employed by the grantor whose fee, in whole or part, for conducting such audit is contingent on findings of the audit. 
Section 12. - [Validity.] 
    The provisions of this ordinance are interdependent upon one another, and if any of the provisions of this ordinance are found or adjudged to be invalid, illegal, void or of no effect, the entire ordinance shall be null and void and of no force or effect. 
Section 13. - [Definition.] 
    As used herein "person" means an individual, a partnership, a corporation, a business trust, a joint stock company, a trust, an incorporated association, a joint venture, a governmental authority or any other entity of whatever nature. 
Section 14. - [Repeal of conflicting ordinances and resolutions.] 
    Ordinance No. 114, passed and adopted March 2, 1981 and all other ordinances and parts of ordinances and all resolutions and parts of resolutions in conflict herewith, are hereby repealed; provided, however, that the repeal of Ordinance No. 114 in no way removes grantee's obligation to remit to grantor those payments collected pursuant to Ordinance No. 114 during the term of that ordinance. The obligation for grantee to collect and remit such payments remains a continuing obligation pursuant to the terms of this ordinance. 
Section 15. - Effective date. 
    This ordinance shall take effect as provided for by law and by City, Charter, section 14, upon execution by the mayor, or if disapproval occurs, upon reconsideration by the city commission, passing of the ordinance by at least four (4) votes, and upon grantor's acceptance filed with the city clerk within thirty (30) days of adoption of this ordinance. The effective date of this ordinance shall be the date upon which the grantee files such acceptance. 
    Passed and duly adopted, by the City Commission of the City of Palmetto, Florida, with a quorum present and voting, in regular session assembled, this 28th day of February, 2011. 
ARTICLE II. - GENERAL TELEPHONE COMPANY[3] 
ORDINANCE NO. 527 
An ordinance granting to General Telephone Company of Florida, a corporation organized and existing under the laws of the State of Florida, certain rights, privileges and franchises in the City of Palmetto. 
Be it ordained by the city council of the City of Palmetto: 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Printed herein is the telephone franchise for General Telephone Company ordinance number 527 enacted June 5, 1961. It should also be noted that Ord. No. 476, adopted June 1, 1992, extended the term of the franchise agreement for one year, with the termination date of June 7, 1993; and Ord. No. 499, adopted June 7, 1993, extended the agreement for an additional one year with the termination date of June 7, 1994. 
Cross reference- Telecommunications service tax, § 27-51 et seq. 

Section 1. - [Franchise granted.] 
    That the General Telephone Company of Florida, a corporation organized, existing and doing business under the laws of the State of Florida, be and it, and its successors and assigns, are hereby granted the right, privilege and franchise for the period of thirty (30) years from the date that this ordinance goes into effect to construct, maintain and operate within the limits of the City of Palmetto as the same now exists, or may hereafter be extended, a telephone system for public and private use, to set poles, string wires and lay conduits over, along and under all streets, alleys and avenues of the said city, with the privilege of charging tolls, rates and hire for the use of its telephone and lines or other instruments operated in connection therewith. The said company agrees to repair all streets, sidewalks, alleys and avenues of said city in a workmanlike manner immediately after setting poles, stringing wires and laying conduits over, along and under said streets, alleys and avenues. 
Section 2. - [Rates, rentals, charges.] 
    That the rates, rentals and hire to be charged by the said company for telephone service rendered by it under this franchise and within the limits of said city, shall be such rates, rentals and charges as shall be established pursuant to the laws of the State of Florida in such case made and provided. 
Section 3. - [Quarterly payments.] 
    That General Telephone Company of Florida, its successors and assigns, shall pay to this municipality, as consideration for the grant of this franchise, one (1) percent of its gross local service revenues derived during each quarter of the calendar year from customers located within the corporate limits of this municipality. Such consideration shall be payable not more than thirty (30) days after the end of such quarter. If the company agrees to pay or is otherwise required to pay to any other municipality more than one (1) percent of its gross local service revenues as consideration for a franchise, which overage is not passed on to the company's subscribers located in such municipality, the company shall, on the effective date of such payment, also begin paying such greater percentage to this municipality. 
(Ord. No. 637, § 7-17-72) 
Section 4. - [Purchase of system by city.] 
    That the said city shall have the right, and the said company, as a condition precedent to the taking effect of this grant, shall give and grant to the said city the right, at and after the expiration of this franchise, to purchase the telephone system installed and operated under this grant or other property used by said company within the limits of the said city under or in connection with this franchise or right, or such part of said property as the said city may desire to purchase, at a valuation of such property, real and personal, desired, which shall be fixed by arbitration as may be provided by law. 
Section 5. - [Repeal of conflicting ordinances.] 
    That all ordinances or parts of ordinances in conflict with the terms of this ordinance be and the same are hereby repealed. 
Section 6. - [Acceptance of franchise.] 
    The General Telephone Company of Florida shall signify its acceptance of the franchise hereby granted in writing within sixty (60) days from the date this ordinance goes into effect. 
PASSED by the City Council of the City of Palmetto this 5th day of June, 1961. 
ARTICLE III. - SOUTHLAND COMMUNICATIONS OF PALMETTO, INC.[4] 
ORDINANCE NO. 67 
An ordinance of the City of Palmetto, Florida, granting a franchise for the construction, acquisition, operation and maintenance of a cable television system within the city limits of the City of Palmetto, Florida, to Southland Communications of Palmetto, Inc., d/b/a Communicable of Palmetto; and providing for an effective date. 
Whereas, the City of Palmetto, Florida, after full public proceedings affording due process, has determined that Southland Communications of Palmetto, Inc., d/b/a Communicable of Palmetto, possessed of the requisite legal, character, financial, technical and other qualifications to construct, own, and operate a cable television system to serve the City of Palmetto; and that its construction and financing plans are adequate and feasible, now therefore, 
Be it ordained by the City Council of the City of Palmetto, Florida, in regular session assembled that: 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Printed herein is the cable television franchise for Southland Communications of Palmetto, Inc., Ordinance Number 67, enacted on May 7, 1979. 

Section 1. - [Granted; purpose.] 
    There is hereby granted to Southland Communications of Palmetto, Inc., d/b/a/ Communicable of Palmetto, its heirs, successors, and assigns, for a term of fifteen (15) years, the right, authority, and power, to establish, construct, acquire, maintain, and operate a cable television system within the City of Palmetto, to render, furnish, and sell cable service therefrom within the territorial limits of the franchise area, and to use and occupy the public streets, rights-of-way, and easements (including all easements dedicated for utility purposes) for such purposes, subject to the terms and conditions of the City of Palmetto Cable Television Ordinance and the rules of the Federal Communications Commission, which are hereby incorporated by reference and made a part of this franchise contract. 
Section 2. - [Nonexclusive franchise.] 
    This franchise is nonexclusive and is limited to those areas of the City of Palmetto hereinafter described and designated on the attached map (e.g., the entire incorporated area of Palmetto). 
Section 3. - [Construction; conflicts.] 
    This franchise is in lieu of any and all other rights, privileges, immunities, and authorities which may be held by the grantee or the successors to any interest of the grantee, pertaining to the construction, acquisition, operation or maintenance of any cable television system in the City of Palmetto, and the acceptance of this franchise by the grantee shall operate as an abandonment of any and all such rights, privileges, immunities, and authorities within the City of Palmetto. Any and all construction, operation and maintenance by any grantee of any cable television system in the City of Palmetto shall be in all instances and respects under and pursuant to this franchise and not under or pursuant to any other right, privilege, immunity or authority whatsoever. 
Section 4. - [Timely compliance.] 
    Time is of the essence in this franchise, and the grantee shall not be relieved of its obligation to comply promptly with any of the provisions of this ordinance by any failure of the City of Palmetto to enforce prompt compliance. 
Section 5. - [Scope of franchise.] 
    This franchise merely authorizes the construction, acquisition, operation and maintenance of a cable television system as provided by the City of Palmetto Cable Television Ordinance [Chapter 8 of the Code of Ordinances], and does not take the place of any other license or permit which may be legally required of the grantee in order to conduct such a business. 
Section 6. - [Acceptance by grantee.] 
(1)  This franchise shall take effect immediately and remain in force for a term of fifteen (15) years upon the filing of an unconditional acceptance by the grantee. Such acceptance must: 
(a)  Be in the form of a writing duly executed and sworn to; 
(b)  Contain a promise that the grantee shall comply with and abide by all terms, provisions and conditions of this franchise; and, 
(c)  Be filed with the agency within thirty (30) days from the date of passage of this ordinance. Grantee shall exercise none of the rights granted by this ordinance until evidence of compliance with the bonding and insurance requirements of Section 6(3) and (4) of the Cable Television Ordinance [Code of Ordinances section 8-6] has been filed with the agency. 
(2)  Should the grantee fail to comply with paragraph (1), above, it shall acquire no rights, privileges, or authority under this franchise whatsoever. 
Passed May 7, 1979. 
ARTICLE IV. - GTE FLORIDA INC.[5] 
An ordinance granting to GTE Florida Incorporated, the permission to occupy municipal streets and rights-of-way in the City of Palmetto, Florida, as a means of providing communication services; prescribing the terms and conditions accompanying the grant of franchise; providing for the repeal of ordinances in conflict herewith; and providing an effective date. 
The City of Palmetto does ordain: 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 551, §§ 1-11, adopted Nov. 20, 1995, has been included as Art. IV of this Appendix, at the discretion of the editor. A history note in parentheses following a particular section indicates amendment subsequent to Ord. No. 551. 

Section 1. - Findings. 
(A)  The City of Palmetto (hereinafter "Grantor" or the "City") deems it necessary, desirable and in the interest of the health, safety and welfare of its citizens to establish by ordinance a franchise granting the permission to occupy municipal streets and rights-of-way in the City of Palmetto, Florida, under Section 362.01 Florida Statutes (1993) to facilitate communications to, from, or among its citizens. 
(B)  GTE Florida Incorporated (hereinafter "Grantee" or the "Company") is willing to place and maintain Grantee's communications facilities within the city under a franchise from Grantor pursuant to Sections 362.01 and 337.401 Fla. Stat. (1993). 
Section 2. - Short Title. 
    This Ordinance shall be known and may be cited as the "GTE Florida Incorporated Franchise." 
Section 3. - Grant of Authority. 
(A)  There is hereby granted by Grantor, to Grantee, the right and privilege to construct, erect, operate, own and maintain, in, upon, along, across, above, over and under rights-of-way now laid out or dedicated, and all extensions thereof, and additions thereto in the City, poles, wires, cables, underground conduits, manholes and other communication fixtures necessary or proper for the maintenance and operation of its lawful business, provided that all visible portions of the same shall conform to the National Electrical Code. This Franchise is awarded subject to the provisions of general or special laws of Florida now existing or hereinafter enacted. 
(B)  Non Exclusive Use. The right to use and occupy rights-of-way for the purposes herein set forth shall be non-exclusive. 
Section 4. - Term of Franchise. 
    The franchise and rights herein granted shall take effect and be in force from and after the final passage here, as required by law and upon the filing of an acceptance by Grantee of all the terms thereof with the Grantor and shall continue in force and effect for a term of five (5) years after the effective date of this franchise. 
Section 5. - Payment to Grantor. 
    The Grantee shall pay to the Grantor monthly as a franchise fee under this franchise a sum of one percent (1%) of the monthly gross receipts from recurring local service revenues, as prescribed in Section 337.401(3), Florida Statutes, (1993) derived from customers receiving service from the Grantee within the Grantor's corporate limits. Should the Florida Statutes be modified to permit a higher percentage or broader base of services to be subject to franchise fees, the percentage or base specified in this agreement shall be automatically modified to the maximum amount permitted by law upon reasonable notice from Grantor to Grantee. 
    The Grantee shall collect from its customers receiving telecommunications and other services within the corporate limits of the City one percent (1%) of the recurring local service revenues collected from each customer and transmit same to the City within thirty (30) days after the end of each calendar month. "Recurring Local Service Revenues", includes but is not limited to all service revenues presently set out or which in the future may represent those presently set out in revenue accounts 5000-5069 as established by the Federal Communication Commission for local network service revenues in accordance with 47 CFR Section 32 Subpart D and any subaccounts as established by the local service provider under those account numbers. 
    Upon the annexation of any territory to the City of Palmetto, the right, privilege and franchise hereby granted shall extend to the territory so annexed, and all facilities owned, maintained or operated by said Company, located within the territory so annexed, upon any of the streets, alleys, avenues or other public places situate in such annexed territory, shall thereafter be subject to all the terms hereof. 
Section 6. - Grantee Obligations. 
(A)  Restoration. The Company hereby agrees at its expense to cause the replacement of all paving, roads, sidewalks and other portions of public or private property disturbed or changed by the Company in the installation of facilities, the making of repairs, and every phase of the Company's operation. 
(B)  Indemnification. The Company hereby covenants and agrees to hold the City completely harmless and to indemnify it from any and all liability, loss and damage of every nature whatsoever resulting from the Company's operations and facilities of every nature whatsoever, including but not limited to, the operation, placing and repair of the Company's equipment, poles, lines, guy wires, conduits and holes or alterations in the streets, sidewalks and property of the City. 
Grantee shall reimburse Grantor for damages which Grantee, or its representative, negligently or willfully causes to any of Grantor's water lines, sewers and traffic light controls resulting from the actions of Grantee, or its representatives, in the construction, operation or maintenance of its facilities in the area of this franchise. 
(C)  Grantee shall maintain, and by its acceptance of this franchise specifically agrees that it will maintain throughout the terms of this franchise, liability insurance insuring the Grantor and Grantee with regard to all damages: 
(a)  $1,000,000 for bodily injury or death to a person, within the limit; $3,000,000 for bodily injury or death resulting from any one accident. 
(b)  $50,000 for property damage resulting from any one accident. 
(c)  $1,000,000 for all other types of liability. 
(D)  The Certificate of Insurance, with Grantor named as an additional insured, shall be filed with the City Clerk. 
(E)  Cable Systems Conditions. Grantee agrees that unless allowed specifically by applicable State or Federal Law, it will not provide consumer/subscriber video programming services and operate its facilities as a cable system without a duly executed cable system franchise within the corporate limits of Grantor. 
Section 7. - Approval of Transfer. 
    The rights and privileges granted by this Franchise shall not be sold, assigned, transferred, leased or pledged in whole or in part without the Grantor's prior written approval, which shall not be unreasonably withheld. No such sale or transfer shall be effective until the vendee, assignee or lessee has filed with the Grantor an instrument, duly executed, reciting the fact of such sale, assignment or lease accepting the terms of the franchise, and agreeing to perform all the conditions thereof. 
Section 8. - Records. 
    Such financial records as are required under this agreement hereof shall be kept and maintained in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles. All of the said records shall, upon reasonable notice, be open for examination and audit by Grantor during ordinary business hours. 
Section 9. - Ordinances in Conflict. 
    That all Ordinances or parts of Ordinances in conflict with the terms of this Ordinance be and the same are hereby repealed. 
Section 10. - Acceptance. 
    Grantee shall signify its acceptance of the Franchise terms in writing prior to City Council's approval of the ordinance by filing such written acceptance with the City Clerk. 
Section 11. - Effective Date. 
    This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon adoption and acceptance by Grantee. 
Passed November 20, 1995. 
ARTICLE V. - SOUTHERN GAS COMPANY[6] 
ORDINANCE NO. 394 
An Ordinance Granting to Southern Gas Company, Its Successors and Assigns, a Non-Exclusive Franchise to Construct, Operate, Repair and Maintain Facilities and Equipment for the Transportation of Gas and to Use the Public Ground of the City of Palmetto, Florida, for Such Purposes; and Prescribing Certain Terms and Conditions Thereof; and Providing for an Effective Date. 
Be It Ordained By the City of Palmetto, Florida: 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 394, §§ 1-19, adopted Feb. 5, 1990, has been included as Art. V of this Appendix, at the discretion of the editor. The ordinance has been set out as enacted, with the exception that a uniform style of capitalization and numbering have been employed. A history note in parentheses following a particular section indicates amendment subsequent to Ord. No. 394. 

Section 1. - Definitions. 
    The following terms shall mean: 
(a)  Company. Southern Gas Company, a Division of Donovan Companies, Inc., a corporation duly authorized to do business in Florida, and its successors and assigns. 
(b)  Gas. Natural gas, manufactured gas, mixture of natural gas and manufactured or other forms of gas energy as delivered from the company's central distribution point(s) via gas mains, pipes, and distributing lines and measured by meter upon entry into the customer's premises. It does not include propane or other gases which are delivered by truck and stored in tanks on the property of customers for future use. 
(c)  City. The City of Palmetto, Florida. 
(d)  Public ground. All streets, alleys, public ways, utility easements, bridges, viaducts, parks and public grounds of the city as to which it has the right to grant the use to the company. 
Section 2. - Grant of nonexclusive franchise. 
(a)  The city hereby grants unto the company, for a period of fifteen (15) years from the effective date hereof, the nonexclusive right to import, transport, distribute and sell gas for public and private use in the City as now laid out and hereafter extended and for these purposes to construct, operate, repair and maintain, on, over, under and across the public ground of the city, all facilities and equipment used in connection therewith, and to do all things which are necessary or customary in the accomplishment of these objectives, subject to zoning ordinances, other applicable ordinances, permit procedures, customary practices, and the provisions of this franchise; provided, however, that the city reserves the right to permit the use of such public places for any and all other lawful purposes and subject always to the paramount right of the public in and to such public places for the term of this franchise. 
(b)  At the end of the franchise period, the city shall renew the franchise for a period of fifteen (15) years, unless the city determines that the company has failed to perform its duties under this ordinance, state statutes and rules and regulations issued by any appropriate state agency. 
(c)  The company shall, at all times during the life of this franchise, be subject to all lawful exercises of the police power and regulatory authority of the city and to such regulation as the city shall hereafter provide by ordinance or resolution; provided, however, such regulations shall not be inconsistent with the terms hereof. 
(d)  The right is hereby reserved to the city to adopt, in addition to the provisions herein contained and existing, applicable resolutions or laws, such additional regulations and increased fees and charges as it shall find necessary in the exercises of the police power and lawful authority vested in said city, provided that such regulations shall be reasonable and not conflict with the rights herein granted and not in conflict with the laws of the State of Florida. The city shall have the right, but not the duty, to inspect all construction or installation work performed. 
Section 3. - Franchise fee. 
    The company hereby agrees to pay to the city a franchise fee in the amount of five (5) percent of the company's annual gross operating revenue receipts derived from monthly service charges to defray the cost of regulations and for use of city rights-of-way and public places. The company shall pay the five (5) percent franchise fee monthly on or before the twentieth of the month. Said fee shall be shown as a separate, additional charge on utility bills. The city may require certification by a certified public account [accountant] that the five (5) percent franchise fee has been collected by the company and disbursed to the city in accordance with the terms of this franchise. Nothing in the foregoing shall in any way be construed to prevent the imposition of any utilities tax by the city, which may be applicable to the company, its operations, business, activities, or the company's customers. 
Section 4. - Duties of the company. 
(a)  The facilities of the company shall be so located or relocated and so erected as to interfere as little as possible with traffic over streets, alleys, bridges and public places, and with reasonable egress from and ingress to abutting property. The location or relocation of all facilities shall be made under these provisions and with the approval of such representatives as the governing body of the city may designate for such purpose, but not so as to unreasonably interfere with proper operation of the company's facilities and service. In the event that at any time the city shall lawfully elect to alter or change the grade or to relocate or widen or otherwise change any such public use, the company shall, upon reasonable notice by the city, remove, relay and relocate its fixtures at the company's expense. The company shall not locate any of its facilities nor do any construction in such a manner as to create any obstructions or conditions which are or may become dangerous to the traveling public. In the event any public ground under or upon which the company shall have located its facilities shall be closed, abandoned, vacated or discontinued, the city shall retain an easement not less than fifteen (15) feet in width for the benefit of the company or, if a beneficiary of the closing, abandoning, vacating or discontinuance of public grounds requests that the company's right of use of the public ground be terminated, the beneficiary shall pay to the company in advance, the company's estimated cost of removal and relocation of the company's facilities in order to continue the company's service. 
(b)  The company shall not open or disturb the surface of any public ground for any purpose without first having obtained a permit from the city, for which the city may impose any appropriate fees, as applicable, to be paid by the company. The permit conditions imposed on the company shall not be more burdensome than those imposed on other utilities for similar facilities or work. When any portion of public ground is excavated by the company in the location or relocation of any of its facilities, the portion of the public ground so excavated shall, within a reasonable time and as early as practicable after such excavation, be replaced and repaired by the company, at the company's expense, to the condition of the public ground prior to the excavation and the company shall maintain such public ground for one (1) year thereafter in good condition. 
(c)  Notwithstanding anything to the contrary set forth herein, the company may open and disturb the surface of any public ground without a permit where an emergency exists requiring the immediate repair of its facilities. The company, in such event, shall request a permit not later than the second working day thereafter. 
(d)  The rights, powers, privileges and franchise hereby granted to the company are upon the conditions that the company shall use all due care in the exercise of its rights hereunder. 
(e)  The company shall have the authority to promulgate such rules, regulations, terms and conditions covering the conduct of its business as shall be reasonably necessary to enable the company to exercise its rights and perform its obligations under this franchise and to issue an uninterrupted service to each and all of its consumers; provided, however, that such rules, regulations, terms and conditions shall not be in conflict with the provisions hereof or with the laws of the State of Florida. 
(f)  The company shall supply the city with copies of its federal and state regulatory operating reports and trouble reports, if any. 
Section 5. - Street improvements, paving or resurfacing. 
    The City of Palmetto shall give the company reasonable written notice of plans for street improvements where paving or resurfacing of a permanent nature is involved. The notice shall contain the nature and character of the improvements, the streets upon which the improvements are to be made, the extent of the improvements and the approximate time when work will start. The notice shall be given to the company a sufficient length of time in advance of the actual commencement of the work to permit the company to make any additions, alterations or repairs to its facilities the company deems necessary. 
Section 6. - Rates. 
    The rates to be charged by the company for gas or gas service hereunder and the standard of service shall be such as may be fixed from time to time by the company and the Florida Public Service Commission, or such other rate-making body as may hereinafter be established under the laws of the State of Florida. 
Section 7. - Hold harmless clause. 
    The company shall indemnify and hold the city, its officers and employees, the mayor and members of the city council harmless from any loss sustained by the city (including attorney fees and court costs incurred by the city) on account of suit, judgment, execution, claim or demand whatsoever resulting from negligence, or intentional, wanton, willful or reckless acts on the part of the company in the construction, operation or maintenance of the natural gas system under the terms of this franchise. The city shall notify the company promptly after presentation of any claim or demand. 
Section 8. - Insurance. 
(a)  The company shall at all times maintain public liability and property damage insurance in a minimum amount of five million dollars ($5,000,000.00). 
(b)  The company shall cause the city to be duly notified by the insurer in the event of any modifications in the terms of such insurance policy. The amount of insurance shall be adjusted by the company as required from time to time by the city council in accordance with good business practices as determined by safe business standards as established by the city council for the protection of the city and the general public and for any liability which may result from any action of the company. 
(c)  Said insurance shall name the City of Palmetto as an additional insured. 
(d)  A certificate of insurance shall be filed with the city annually. 
Section 9. - Actions against company by third parties. 
    Any claim of any person resulting from any act of the company or its employees or agents may be prosecuted directly by such person against the company. 
Section 10. - Termination rights. 
    The city shall have the right to terminate this franchise at any time during the franchise period or renewal thereof, if the city council determines that the company has failed to perform its duties or to provide services or gas in accordance with this ordinance, state statutes, or the rules and regulations of any regulatory agency of the state with jurisdiction over the company's operations. Prior to making such a determination, the city council shall direct the mayor to deliver a written notice to the company specifying the failure of the company. The company shall have a reasonable time, not to exceed ninety (90) days (except in the case of a failure to make the payment required under section 3 or maintain liability insurance under section 8, in which event the time to cure shall not exceed ten (10) days), to cure the failure. If the company does not cure the failure, then the city shall make a determination that the company has failed to perform as required herein and shall terminate this franchise. 
Section 11. - Contractual agreement. 
    It is specifically agreed by and between the parties hereto that this ordinance shall be considered a franchise agreement between the company and the city and as such a contractual instrument recognized under the statutes and laws of the State of Florida. This franchise agreement is not intended to create rights or actions running in favor of third parties, except as herein specifically provided. 
Section 12. - Examination of records. 
    City may, at its option, upon reasonable notice to grantee, at any time within ninety (90) days after the close of each fiscal year of the company during the franchise period or renewal thereof, at the sole expense of the city, examine the books of the company as such books relate to calculation of the franchise payment to the city. Such examination of company's books and records shall be during company's regular business hours and at the general office of the company except that those records reflecting the geographic location of grantee's residential, commercial and industrial customers within the city limits may be examined, subject to the same conditions applicable to the examination of other books and records, at the district office of the company where such records are kept. 
Section 13. - Annexation. 
    Upon the annexation of any territory to the city, the right, privilege and franchise hereby granted shall extend to the territory so annexed, and all facilities owned, maintained or operated by the company, located within the territory so annexed, upon any of the public ground situated in such annexed territory, shall thereafter be subject to all the terms hereof. 
Section 14. - Assignment. 
    The company, only with prior approval of the city, shall have the right and authority to assign all rights conferred upon it by this franchise to any person. The assignee of such rights, by accepting such assignment, shall become subject to the terms and provisions of this ordinance. 
Section 15. - Change in form of government. 
    Any change in the form of government of the city shall not affect the validity of this franchise. Any governmental unit succeeding the city shall, without the consent of the company, automatically succeed to all of the rights and obligations of the city provided in this ordinance. 
Section 16. - Severability. 
    Should any section or provision of this ordinance or any portion hereof be declared by a court of competent jurisdiction to be invalid, such decision shall not affect the validity of the remainder as a whole or as to any part, other than the part declared to be invalid. 
Section 17. - Notice. 
(a)  Any notice required by this franchise shall be sufficient if delivered, postage prepaid, certified mail, return receipt requested, to the parties at the following address: 
COMPANY: Southern Gas Company 
1565 State Street 
Post Office Box 3499 
Sarasota, Florida 33577 
Attention: General Manager 
CITY: City of Palmetto 
City Hall 
Post Office Box 1209 
Palmetto, Florida 34221 
Attention: Mayor 
(b)  If either party changes its address, the other party shall be provided written notice thereof within ten (10) days of the change, and such change shall become effective upon receipt of such notice. 
Section 18. - Acceptance. 
    Southern Gas Company shall, within thirty (30) days after the effective date of this ordinance, file with the city clerk of the City of Palmetto, its written acceptance of the rights, privileges and obligations set forth in this ordinance. Said written acceptance shall specifically refer to this ordinance and accept the terms of this ordinance. Should Southern Gas Company fail to submit its written acceptance in a timely manner, then the provisions of this ordinance shall be null and void. 
Section 19. - Effective date. 
    This ordinance shall become effective immediately upon its passage, approval and publication according to law. 
    First Reading: January 15, 1990. 
    Publication: January 20, 1990. 
    Second Reading: February 5, 1990. 
    Passed by the city council of the City of Palmetto, Florida, in regular session assembled, this 5th day of February, 1990. 
ARTICLE VI. - WASTE MANAGEMENT INC. OF FLORIDA 
Franchise agreement 
This franchise agreement, made and entered into this 1st day of March 2004, by and between the City of Palmetto, a municipal corporation of the State of Florida, ("City"), and Waste Management Inc. of Florida, a Florida corporation, with its principal place of business located at 2700 N. W. 48th Street, Pompano Beach, Florida 33073 ("WMIF" or "Authorized Collector"). 
Witnesseth: 
Whereas, pursuant to F.S. section 125.01, Chapter 85-457, Laws of Florida, and section 15-24, City of Palmetto Code of Ordinances, the City is authorized to grant exclusive franchises for the collection of solid waste, recyclable materials, and yard trash within the incorporated city limits; and 
Whereas, WMIF and Manatee County are parties to that certain Solid Waste Franchise Agreement for unincorporated Manatee County between Waste Management Inc. of Florida and Manatee County, dated May 2, 2000 (the "County Agreement"), which county agreement was secured by competitive solicitation; and 
Whereas, city desires to utilize the previously bid County Agreement to secure the collection and disposal services from WMIF without competitive bidding pursuant to subsection 2-57(c) of the City of Palmetto Code of Ordinances; and 
Whereas, WMIF is able and willing to contract with the City pursuant to the terms of the general county agreement; and 
Whereas, WMIF has presented satisfactory evidence to the City that it has adequate physical, operational, financial and technical capabilities to provide the services described in this agreement in compliance with all rules and regulations of the City; and 
Whereas, the City has determined that the granting of an exclusive franchise to the authorized collector for residential and commercial solid waste, recyclable materials, and yard trash collection services is in the best interest of the City. 
Approved, with a quorum present and voting, on the 1st day of March, 2004. 
(Ord. of 3-1-04) 
ARTICLE VII. - VERIZON FLORIDA LLC. 
ORDINANCE NO. 06-904 
An ordinance of the City of Palmetto, Florida, granting a cable television franchise to Verizon Florida LLC. Authorizing execution of said cable television franchise (a copy of which is attached hereto and made a part hereof); providing certain rights, privileges and conditions relating thereto; providing a severability clause, effective date, and repealing all ordinances or parts of ordinances in conflict herewith. 
Whereas, the City of Palmetto is a "franchising authority" as defined by Title VI of the Communications Act (see 47 U.S.C. § 522(10)) and is authorized to grant one (1) or more nonexclusive cable franchises pursuant to F.S. section 166.046; 
Whereas, Verizon Florida LLC ("franchisee") is in the process of installing a fiber to the premise telecommunications network ("FTTP Network") that will occupy the public rights-of-way within the City of Palmetto for the transmission of non-cable services pursuant to its status as a telecommunications carrier as set forth in Title II of the Communications Act and under authority granted by the State of Florida; 
Whereas, the FTTP Network, once installed, will enable the provision of cable service to the residents of Palmetto; 
Whereas, negotiations between the franchising authority and the Franchisee have resulted in an agreement entitled "An Agreement Between the City of Palmetto, Florida and Verizon Florida LLC., Granting Nonexclusive Rights to Operate and Provide Cable Services Within the City of Palmetto, Florida and Setting Forth Terms and Conditions Relating to the Exercise of Those Rights" ("Franchise Agreement"), which agreement comports with the requirements of F.S. section 166.046; 
Whereas, in accordance with F.S. section 166.041 and Article II of the City's Charter, first reading of the franchise agreement is slated for November 6, 2006; 
Whereas, in accordance with F.S. section 166.041 and Article II of the City's Charter, second reading the franchise agreement is slated for November 20, 2006; 
Whereas, in accordance with F.S. section 166.041 and Article II of the city's Charter, notice of public hearing before the city commission to consider the proposed cable franchise agreement was properly published in the Bradenton Herald, a newspaper of general circulation, on November 10, 2006; 
Whereas, the franchising authority's staff has reviewed the legal, technical and financial qualifications of the franchisee to operate and provide cable service within the city and prepared a staff report dated October 2006 ("Staff Report") setting forth those qualifications, the future cable-related needs and interests of the City of Palmetto and its residents, and examining each of the requirements and criteria set forth by federal, state and local law with respect to granting an additional cable television franchise, as well as any applicable provisions in the existing franchise; and 
Whereas, following thorough evaluation of franchisee's proposal to provide cable service in Palmetto, Florida, after receiving the comments of interested parties at a public hearing affording due process to all parties, in deliberation of the entire record regarding this matter before it, including other pertinent information, and specifically considering each of the requirements and criteria enumerated in F.S. section 166.046, 47 U.S.C. § 541(a), and all other applicable provisions of law, as well as any applicable provisions in the existing franchise, the franchising authority determines that is in the public interest to approve the proposed cable television franchise agreement and authorize and direct the execution of the proposed franchise agreement. 
Now, therefore, be it ordained by the mayor and city commission of the City of Palmetto, Florida: 

Section 1. - [Franchise.] 
    The "Whereas" clauses set forth above shall be deemed true and correct and shall be deemed a part of this ordinance as if they had been set forth in full in the body of this ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 06-904, § 1, 11-20-06) 
Section 2. - [Franchise granted.] 
    The franchising authority concludes that the cable-related needs and interests of the City of Palmetto, Florida and the franchisee's legal, technical, and financial qualifications to operate and provide cable service within the city are accurately identified by the attached staff report, which is hereby adopted by the franchising authority in its entirety as its ascertainment of the cable-related needs and interests of the city, the franchisee's qualifications to operate and provide cable service within the city, and supporting the franchising authority's consideration of each of the requirements and criteria enumerated in F.S. section 166.046, 47 U.S.C. § 541(a), all other applicable provisions of law, as well as any applicable provisions in the existing franchise. 
(Ord. No. 06-904, § 2, 11-20-06) 
Section 3. - [Finding of fact.] 
    The franchising authority determines that is in the public interest to grant a nonexclusive franchise to operate and provide cable service to Verizon Florida LLC and, evidencing its consideration of each of the factors enumerated in F.S. section 166.046, 47 U.S.C. § 541(a)(3), all other applicable provisions of law, as well as any applicable provisions in the existing franchise, hereby adopts the attached findings of fact in support of this determination. 
(Ord. No. 06-904, § 3, 11-20-06) 
Section 4. - [Nonexclusive franchise.] 
    The franchising authority authorizes the grant of a nonexclusive franchise to the franchisee to operate and provide cable service within the city. This authorization is made in accordance with the applicable provisions of Title VI of the Communications Act and made in accordance with F.S. section 166.046. A copy of the franchise agreement in the form in which it is attached hereto was considered in a public hearing on November 20, 2006, and is directed to be retained in the office of the city clerk for the purpose of public inspection. 
(Ord. No. 06-904, § 4, 11-20-06) 
Section 5. - [Contractual agreement.] 
    That certain franchise agreement in the form presented to the city commission at this public hearing is approved, and the mayor is authorized and directed to execute that agreement on behalf of the franchising authority following its execution by the franchisee. 
(Ord. No. 06-904, § 5, 11-20-06) 
Section 6. - [Severability.] 
    If any part of this ordinance is declared invalid by a court of competent jurisdiction, such part of parts shall be severable and the remaining part of parts shall continue to be in full force and effect. 
(Ord. No. 06-904, § 6, 11-20-06) 
Section 7. - [Acceptance.] 
    This ordinance shall take effect as provided for by law and by City Charter, Section 14, upon execution by the mayor or, if disapproval occurs, upon reconsideration by the city commission and passing of the ordinance by at least four (4) votes. 
(Ord. No. 06-904, § 7, 11-20-06) 
Section 8. - [Effective date.] 
    All ordinances or parts of ordinances not specifically in conflict herewith are hereby continued in full force and effect, but all ordinances or parts of ordinances in conflict herewith are hereby repealed. 
First Reading: November 6, 2006. 
Publication Date: November 10, 2006. 
Second Reading: November 20, 2006. 
(Ord. No. 06-904, § 8, 11-20-06) 
Passed and duly adopted, by the city commission of the City of Palmetto, Florida, with a quorum present and voting, in regular session assembled, this 20th day of November, 2006. 
ARTICLE VIII. - CABLE TELEVISION[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 08-964, adopted April 21, 2008, removed sections 8-1-8-25 from Chapter 8 of this Code and recodified said provisions in a new Article VIII of Appendix A. Former Chapter 8 pertained to Cable Franchises and derived from Ord. No. 01-715, adopted October 15, 2001. 
Cross reference- Licenses and business regulations, Ch. 19. 

Section 1. - Repeal of existing ordinance; adoption of new ordinance; title. 
    The Code of Ordinances of the city is hereby amended by repealing the existing cable television ordinance of the city found in this article and consisting of section numbers 8-1 through 8-31, inclusive, in its entirety, and by adopting a new cable television ordinance consisting of section numbers [1] through [25], inclusive, which new ordinance shall be known and cited as the "City of Palmetto Time Warner Cable Cable Television Ordinance." 
(Ord. No. 08-964, § 2, 4-21-08) 
Section 2. - Definitions. 
    The following terms, phrases, and words shall have the meaning given hereinafter unless the context clearly indicates that another meaning is intended. When consistent with the context, words used in the present tense include the future; words in the plural number include the singular number; and words in the singular number include the plural number. The word "shall" is always mandatory and not merely directory. 
    Cable act means the Cable Communications Policy Act of 1984, and the Cable Television Consumer Protection and Competition Act of 1992 and amendments thereto (hereinafter referred to collectively as the "cable act"). 
    Cable service means the one-way transmission to subscribers of video programming or other programming service and subscriber interaction, if any, which is required for the selection or use of such video programming or other programming service. Cable service includes the provision of cable modem service such as "Road Runner," unless classified otherwise under applicable law. 
    Cable system has the meaning set forth in the cable act. 
    Channel means a band of frequencies in the electromagnetic spectrum, or any other means of transmission (including, without limitation, optical fibers or any other means now available or that may become available) which is capable of carrying a video or audio signal. 
    City means the City of Palmetto, Florida, a municipality of the State of Florida. 
    Communications services tax simplification law means F.S. chapter 202, cited as the "communications services tax simplification law." 
    Council means the city council of the city, and any entity which may succeed to its authority with respect to cable television franchises. 
    Control or controlling interest means actual working control in whatever manner exercised, including, without limitation, working control through ownership or management, as the case may be, of the cable system or of the grantee. 
    Economically and technically feasible and viable means capable of being provided: 
(1)  Through technology which has been demonstrated to be feasible for its intended purpose; 
(2)  In an operationally workable manner; and 
(3)  In a profitable manner. 
    Effective date means the date on which this agreement shall take effect, as further defined in section 8-25 hereof. 
    Federal Communications Commission or FCC is the federal agency of that name as constituted by the Communications Act of 1934 or any successor agency created by the United States. 
    Franchise is an authorization granted by the city by ordinance which permits the construction, operation, and maintenance of the cable system within the city. 
    Grantee means the holder of this cable television franchise, Time Warner Entertainment-Advance/New House Partnership, d/b/a Time Warner Cable. 
    Gross revenue means, except as otherwise specifically provided herein, all revenue received by grantee from the provision of cable service including, but not limited to, advertising and, to the extent permitted by law, franchise fees. "Gross revenue" shall not include any deposits given to the grantee for converters or other equipment; refunds to subscribers by the grantee; or any sales or use tax or other tax or fee (except franchise fees of any kind) that the grantee collects on behalf of the city or any other taxing authority. 
    Ordinance means this ordinance. 
    Person means any natural person or any association, firm, partnership, joint venture, corporation, or other legally recognized entity, whether for-profit or not-for-profit, but shall not mean the city. 
    Prime time means the three (3) hours of cable television service occurring between 8:00 p.m. and 11:00 p.m. daily. 
    Public buildings include municipal office buildings, fire stations, public libraries, public schools and the city-owned community center. 
    Schools include all public state-accredited educational institutions. 
    Service means any services, whether originated by the grantee or any other person, which are distributed over the cable system. 
    Street includes the surface of and the space above and below any public street, right-of-way, road, highway, freeway, bridge, lane, path, alley, court, sidewalk, parkway, drive, communications or utility easement, and all extensions thereof, now or hereafter existing within the city. 
    Subscriber shall mean any person receiving service from the grantee. 
(Ord. No. 08-964, § 2, 4-21-08) 
Section 3. - Grant of franchise. 
    There is hereby granted by the city to the grantee the non-exclusive right and privilege to construct, erect, operate and maintain, in, upon, along, across, above, over and under the streets and all extensions thereof, and additions thereto, in the city, poles, wires, cables, underground conduits, manholes, and other conductors and fixtures necessary for the maintenance and operation in the city of a cable television system for the purpose of providing such cable service or other service as the grantee may from time to time choose to provide. 
(Ord. No. 08-964, § 2, 4-21-08) 
Section 4. - Term of franchise. 
    The franchise granted hereunder shall continue for a term of fifteen (15) years from the effective date (the "term"). Upon the written request of either the city or the grantee, this franchise shall be considered for renewal by the city under the provisions specified in 47 U.S.C. Section 546 of the cable act which are in effect as of the date of this article unless federal law preemptively provides otherwise. 
(Ord. No. 08-964, § 2, 4-21-08) 
Section 5. - Limitations of franchise. 
    The following limitations shall apply to the franchise. 
(1)  The franchise granted herein is non-exclusive. The grantor specifically reserves the right to grant, at any time, one (1) or more additional franchises for a system in accordance with state and federal law; provided, however, no such future franchise shall be granted on terms or conditions more favorable or less burdensome than those contained herein. 
(2)  This franchise is granted pursuant to the terms and conditions contained herein. Such terms and conditions shall be subordinate to all applicable provisions of state and federal laws, rules and regulations. Grantee's rights hereunder are subject to the police powers of the city to adopt and enforce ordinances necessary to the health, safety and welfare of the public that are not otherwise inconsistent with the terms and conditions of this article. Grantee shall comply with all applicable general laws and ordinances enacted by the city pursuant to that power. 
(3)  Nothing in this agreement shall vest in the grantee any rights in the property of the city, nor shall the city be compelled to maintain any of its property any longer than or in any fashion other than, in the city's sole judgment, its own business or needs may require. 
(4)  This franchise is granted solely to the grantee. The grantee shall not sell, transfer, assign, or otherwise dispose of the cable system or its rights or obligations under this article, in whole or in part, to any person, nor shall title therein, either legal or equitable, or any right or interest therein, pass to or vest in any person, either by act of the grantee, by act of any person holding control of or any interest in the grantee or the cable system or the franchise, by operation of law, or otherwise, without prior authorization of the city, which consent shall not be unreasonably withheld. Prior to authorization of any such disposition, the city shall examine the proposed transferee's legal, financial, and technical qualifications to construct, operate, and maintain the cable system in the city. In the case of a proposed disposition, the city shall conduct a formal public hearing thereon within sixty (60) days subsequent to receipt by the city of the grantee's request for transfer approval with due notice to the public and to the grantee. As a condition precedent to authorization of any such disposition, the proposed transferee shall execute and file with the city a written instrument in form and content reasonably acceptable to the city, accepting all of the terms and conditions of this article. Notwithstanding the provisions set forth above, the grantee shall have the right to transfer the franchise to any person controlling, controlled by or under the same common control as the grantee. Under such circumstances, the grantee may transfer the franchise without the prior consent of the city. 
(Ord. No. 08-964, § 2, 4-21-08) 
Section 6. - Indemnification, emergency rights and insurance requirement. 
(a)  At all times the grantee shall indemnify, defend and hold the city harmless and, without limitation, any officer, agent, elected official or employee of the city, against any and all damage, penalty, claim, action, suit, liability, loss, cost or expense, including but not limited to reasonable attorneys' fees, which may accrue, arise, or be claimed as a result of the award of this franchise or the grantee's construction, installation, repair, operation, replacement, maintenance, upgrade or removal of the cable system hereunder, whether or not the acts or omissions complained of are authorized, allowed, or prohibited. The city, in order to assert or claim indemnification in accordance with the terms hereof, must promptly notify the grantee of the claim, action, suit or other matter giving rise to such right of indemnification; must afford the grantee the opportunity to participate in and fully control the defense, compromise, settlement, resolution or other disposition of such claim, action, suit or other matter; and, must fully cooperate in the defense against such claim, action, suit or other matter and make available to the grantee all materials and information in the possession or under the control of the city relating thereto; provided, however, the terms of a non-monetary compromise or settlement shall be submitted to the city for its review and approval, which approval shall not be unreasonably withheld. If, after receiving written notice from the city of a matter requiring such indemnification, the grantee shall, within a reasonable time subsequent to the receipt of such notice, fail to perform its obligation to indemnify, defend and hold the city harmless, the city, upon delivery of written notice to the grantee of its default hereunder, shall have the right to retain the services of attorneys to represent the interests of the city and any other person included as an indemnified party under this section, in any such matter and the city shall be reimbursed for reasonable attorney fees and related expenses incurred by the city for such representation. The grantee shall, at its own cost and expense, replace, repair, or restore any damaged property to its prior condition and shall pay appropriate compensation in the event of any injury to or death of any individual person occasioned by any act or failure to act of the grantee, or any officer, employee, agent or subcontractor thereof, in connection with the construction, operation, maintenance or upgrade of the cable system. Notwithstanding anything to the contrary contained herein, neither the city nor any other person included as an indemnified party under this section shall be indemnified against any matter to the extent to which the city, its officers, agents, elected officials or employees or other indemnified person shall have been guilty of or liable for negligence, willful misconduct or criminal acts. 
(b)  The city may, at any time, in case of fire, disaster, or other emergency, as determined by the city in its reasonable discretion, cut or move any of the wires, cables, amplifiers, appliances, or other parts of the cable system, in which event the city shall not incur any liability to the grantee, or any other person. All costs to repair or replace such wires, cables, amplifiers, appliances or other parts of the cable system shall be borne by the grantee. Notwithstanding the provisions of this section, except in such cases where there is a reasonable basis to suspect that a person's life, safety, or well-being is in immediate jeopardy, or where there is an immediate threat of a material loss of property, the city shall first make a reasonable attempt to notify the grantee in order to give the grantee an opportunity to take the necessary action in regard to the cable system within the time period specified by the city. 
(c)  In non-emergency situations, prior to performing any public work, public improvement, alteration of any municipal structure, any change in the grade or level of any street, or the limitation, discontinuation or temporary closing of any street, the city shall provide the grantee with advance notice of such activities at least seventy-two (72) hours prior to the commencement thereof and the grantee shall, at its expense, with reasonable speed take such steps as the grantee shall deem necessary in order to protect the cable system. In the event the grantee fails to act within a reasonable time, or if the acts of the grantee are not sufficient to protect the cable system, the city shall have no liability to the grantee for any damage caused as a result of or in connection with all reasonable steps taken for the protection, breaking through, movement, removals, alteration, or relocation of any part of the cable system by or on behalf of the grantee or the city. The provisions of this section shall not be applicable if the city fails to notify the grantee of any such pending work. 
(d)  At or before the effective date, the grantee shall, at the grantee's sole cost and expense, furnish to the city a certificate or certificates evidencing that the grantee has in place a general comprehensive liability insurance policy in a form which shall insure (i) the grantee and (ii) the city and its officers, boards, commissioners, elected officials, agents and employees, as additional insureds, against liability for loss due to personal injury, death, property damage (both automobile and non-automobile caused), or other damages. Such policy or policies shall be issued by companies duly authorized to do business in the state and shall contain provisions requiring a minimum of thirty (30) days notice to the city prior to cancellation.
