Such policy or policies shall be issued with minimum combined single limits of liability coverage in the amount of one million dollars ($1,000,000.00). The foregoing limitations shall not prohibit the grantee from obtaining a liability insurance policy or policies in excess of such limitations. The liability insurance policies required by this section shall be maintained by the grantee throughout the term of this article and such other period of time during which the grantee operates or is engaged in the removal of the cable system pursuant to an extension of the franchise granted to the grantee. From time to time during the term of the franchise, the city may require the grantee to increase the minimum amount of combined single limits of liability coverage to an increased level of coverage which does not exceed the increase in the Consumer Price Index occurring from and after the effective date hereof to the date of the request for an increase in the minimum amount of combined single limits of liability coverage. "Consumer Price Index" shall mean the Consumer Price Index as now published the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics under the caption "United States City Average for Urban Wage Earners and Clerical Workers All Items" 1982-1984 equals 100. If the Consumer Price Index shall become unavailable to the public because publication is discontinued or otherwise, or if equivalent data is not readily available to enable the city to make the adjustment contemplated hereby, the city will substitute therefore a comparable index based upon changes in the cost of living or purchasing power of the consumer dollar published by any other governmental agency. 
(Ord. No. 08-964, § 2, 4-21-08) 
Section 7. - Service standards complaints. 
(a)  The grantee may interrupt service for good cause only, such as to maintain, repair, upgrade or conduct FCC testing of the cable system and for the shortest time possible and, except in emergency situations, only after prior notice to subscribers and the city of the anticipated service interruption; provided, however, planned maintenance, repair, upgrade or testing which does not require more than four (4) hours interruption of service and does not occur during prime time, shall not require such notice. 
(b)  Except for permitted interruptions under subsection 7(a), upon request grantee shall give any subscriber pro-rata credit toward his or her charges for services when service to the subscriber is interrupted for a period of four (4) hours or more and the interruption in service is not attributable to any act of the subscriber or any person on or about said subscriber's premises with the consent of the subscriber. The pro-rata credit shall be given to each subscriber for the period of time beginning when the subscriber first becomes aware of the interruption in such subscriber's service, and ending when the service is restored. The credit shall appear on the next ensuing bill prepared after the service is restored, or as soon thereafter as practicable. 
(c)  Grantee shall comply with and city shall be entitled to enforce all customer service and consumer protection standards, rules and regulations now or hereafter adopted or approved by the FCC. 
(d)  Except as otherwise permitted by applicable law, throughout the term of this agreement and any renewal thereof, the grantee shall not discriminate between or among any persons, in the rates, terms and conditions relating to the delivery of cable television service, provided that nothing herein shall prevent the grantee from: (i) charging commercial subscribers rates different from those charged to residential subscribers; or, (ii) from setting rates as necessary to meet competitive market circumstances which may vary from time to time and/or from place to place; or, (iii) from providing any other discounted or promotional rate permitted by law. Further, the grantee shall ensure that access is not denied to any group of potential subscribers because of the income of the residents of the area in which such group resides. 
(Ord. No. 08-964, § 2, 4-21-08) 
Section 8. - Subscriber right to privacy. 
    The grantee shall operate the cable system in a manner that protects against invasions of any person's privacy. The grantee shall comply with the provisions of Section 631 of the Cable Act (47 U.S.C. §551). 
(Ord. No. 08-964, § 2, 4-21-08) 
Section 9. - Technical requirements. 
(a)  The cable system operated by the grantee shall be installed, maintained and operated at all times in full compliance with the technical standards of the Federal Communications Commission. The results of annual performance tests conducted in accordance with FCC rules shall be retained for at least five (5) years and shall be available for inspection. 
(b)  The grantee shall have the ability to demonstrate to the city, by instruments or otherwise, that a signal of adequate strength and quality is being delivered by the cable system. The grantee shall furnish the city with a written report of the results of the grantee's annual system proof of performance tests, as required by the FCC, within ten (10) days after receipt of a request by the city. The city, by written notice to the grantee, shall have the right to require additional proof of performance tests should the city have reasonable cause to believe that the cable system is not providing quality service transmission to the subscribers in accordance with FCC technical standards, which notice shall include the identity of the engineer selected by the city to conduct such tests. Within ten (10) days after grantee's receipt of the city's request for additional proof of performance tests the grantee shall either approve of the engineer designated by the city to conduct such tests, which approval shall not be unreasonably withheld; or, if the grantee does not approve of the engineer selected by the city, the grantee, within such ten-day period, shall submit an alternate selection for approval by the city, which submission shall be accompanied by the qualifications of such alternate. If the results of such tests show that the cable system is not providing service in accordance with FCC technical standards to the subscribers as required by this article, the grantee shall pay the cost of such tests. However, if such tests show that the cable system is providing service in accordance with FCC technical standards to the subscribers as required by this article, the city shall pay the cost of such tests. 
(Ord. No. 08-964, § 2, 4-21-08) 
Section 10. - Safety requirements. 
(a)  The grantee shall at all times employ ordinary care and shall install and maintain in use commonly accepted methods and devices for preventing failures and accidents which are likely to cause damage, injuries, or nuisances to the public. 
(b)  All construction, installation and maintenance of the cable system and any upgrade thereto shall comply with the NESC. 
(c)  The grantee shall install and maintain its wires, cables, fixtures, and other equipment in accordance with the requirements of the city's generally applicable codes and ordinances, including permitting and notice requirements set forth therein, and in such manner that they will not interfere with any installations of the city or of a public utility serving the city. The grantee's use of the streets shall not interfere with the city's provision of public services or with the public's right of access to and use of the rights-of-way. 
(d)  On streets and roads where electrical and telephone utility wiring is installed underground, the cable system must also be installed underground. On streets and roads where electrical and telephone utility wiring is currently installed above ground but is subsequently required to be moved underground, the grantee agrees to move the cable system installation underground provided that adequate easements for such installation are available. In the event that a city street shall be vacated, the grantee agrees to remove and relocate the cable system upon the condition that the grantee is provided with an alternate easement which will permit the grantee to provide, at no greater expense, cable services to the subscribers which are being served by the cable system located within the vacated street. All of the grantee's structures and all lines, equipment, and connections in, over, under, and upon the streets of the city, wherever situated or located, shall at all times be kept and maintained by the grantee in a safe and suitable condition, and in good order and repair at the grantee's expense. If any provider of electrical or telephone utility services is compensated by city for a required relocation of its facilities underground or due to the vacation of a street and the grantee is also subject to such relocation requirement, then the grantee shall be similarly compensated by the city. 
(e)  Grantee shall give adequate advance notice to the city of any repair to or installation of cable system which will require disturbance of any city pavement, sidewalk, driveway, or other surface, grass or landscaping except that normal service drops to subscribers shall not require such advance notice. If the grantee has damaged or disturbed any pavement, sidewalk, driveway, or other surface, grass, or landscaping, the grantee shall, at the sole expense of the grantee promptly repair, replace and restore such damage or disturbance to a condition which is equivalent to the condition prevailing prior to such damage or disturbance (which repair, replacement or restoration shall be warranted as to workmanship and materials for one (1) year), or agree on a monetary settlement for the damage caused by the grantee. 
(Ord. No. 08-964, § 2, 4-21-08) 
Section 11. - Cable television service within the city. 
    The grantee shall make cable television service available throughout the city to the extent cable television service can be provided in an economically and technically feasible and viable manner which shall be interpreted to mean a minimum of thirty-five (35) homes per mile as measured from existing distribution lines. However, the grantee agrees that it shall extend its cable system and make cable television service available in the city even in those instances which may not be normally economically feasible and viable in any case where the subscriber agrees to pay for the labor costs incurred and materials used in making the connection for cable television service. 
(Ord. No. 08-964, § 2, 4-21-08) 
Section 12. - Communications services tax, franchise fees, reports and other payments. 
(a)  The communications services tax simplification law prohibits the city from regulating the terms and conditions related to franchise fees and the definition of gross revenues or other definitions or methodologies related to the payment or assessment of franchise fees on providers of cable services. If the provisions of the communications services tax simplification law prohibiting the aforementioned activities by city are declared invalid or unenforceable, or are repealed, superceded or amended by any court, agency, commission, legislative body, or other authority of competent, superseded or amended by any court, agency, commission, legislative body, or other authority of competent jurisdiction, then grantee shall pay city a franchise fee on gross revenues in accordance with subsections (b) through (h) hereof, inclusive. Grantee's total annual payment obligations whether under the communications services tax simplification law or this agreement, shall not on a percentage or gross revenue base exceed: 
(1)  That of any other cable or video provider in the city over which the city has the authority to impose a fee; 
(2)  The amount of the local portion payable by grantee under the communications services tax simplification law; or 
(3)  The federal cap of five (5) percent of gross revenues from the provision of cable services. 
(b)  From and after the effective date and continuing thereafter during the franchise term, a franchise fee equal to five (5) percent of gross revenue shall be paid by the grantee to the city. During the franchise term the city may increase or decrease the franchise fee but in no event may the amount of the franchise fee exceed the maximum amount permitted by the cable act. The city must give the grantee adequate advance written notice of such change so that the grantee can provide notice of the date of change to its subscribers as is required by law. Grantee must pay the franchise fee due to the city on a semi-annual basis. Payment for the period January 1 through June 30 of each calendar year shall be tendered to the city not later than July 30 of the same calendar year. Payment for the period July 1 through December 31 of each calendar year shall be tendered to the city not later than January 30 of the ensuing calendar year. 
(c)  In the event that, during the course of the franchise term, the city annexes adjacent or surrounding areas which areas, subsequent to the annexation process, shall be incorporated into the municipal boundaries of the city, the city shall provide the grantee with written notice of such annexation at least sixty (60) days in advance of the date upon which such annexation shall become effective. Any such notice of annexation shall include a schedule identifying the street addresses of the existing residential and commercial properties located within the area to be annexed. 
(d)  At the time of payment of the franchise fee, the grantee shall provide the city with a report prepared in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles and certified by a certified public accountant or certified by a financial officer of grantee which shall reflect the gross revenue of the grantee during the preceding franchise fee period (January 1 through July 30 or July 1 through December 31) and the calculation of the franchise fee paid. 
(e)  Upon reasonable notice and during normal business hours, the city shall have the right to inspect the records of the grantee relating to gross revenue and, no later than six (6) months subsequent to the delivery of the semi-annual report, to audit such semi-annual report to verify the franchise fee calculation. The city shall, within such six (6) month audit period, notify the grantee of any deficiency alleged to be due as a result of such audit, which notice shall specify the reasons for such deficiency. The grantee shall have forty-five (45) days from the date of such notice to deliver to the city written notice objecting to the deficiency and specifying the reasons for such objections. If the grantee delivers notice of objection the city shall provide its written response thereto within thirty (30) days thereof. Upon receipt by the grantee of the city's response to its objections, the grantee shall, within the time period set forth in subsection 12(f) hereof, either pay the additional amount claimed or contest such claim as permitted in subsection 12(f) hereof. 
(f)  If the city claims that additional franchise fees are due the city, the grantee shall have the right to contest such claim by appearance before the city council and/or in a court of competent jurisdiction sitting in the county. If the grantee contests any such claim before city council or in a court of competent jurisdiction within ninety (90) days after receipt of notice that additional franchise fees are due, then the grantee shall not be required to pay the amount claimed until such time as a final decision or judgment has been entered, or the parties agree to a settlement. 
(g)  If the result of any audit accepted by the grantee or a final judgment in a judicial proceeding relating to an audit confirms that the grantee's annual franchise fee payment to the city for the preceding calendar year should be increased by ten (10) percent or more, the cost of such audit shall be paid by the grantee. If, as a result of such audit or judicial determination, the franchise fee payment due is increased by less than ten (10) percent, all costs of the audit shall be paid by the city. 
(h)  In the event that any franchise fee or recomputed amount is not paid on or before the applicable dates specified herein, interest shall be charged from such date at the annual interest rate then chargeable for unpaid federal income taxes (26 U.S.C. § 6621). 
(i)  Subject to the time limitation of the six-month audit period provided for in subsection 12(e), acceptance of any franchise fee or portion thereof by the city shall not be construed as a waiver, release, or accord and satisfaction of any claim the city may have against the grantee. 
(Ord. No. 08-964, § 2, 4-21-08) 
Section 13. - Regulation of rates by city. 
    The city reserves the right, after approval by the city council, to become certified in accordance with the cable act and FCC regulations and, subsequent to receipt of certification, to regulate the rates for basic cable service as permitted by law. 
(Ord. No. 08-964, § 2, 4-21-08) 
Section 14. - Cable television service to public buildings. 
    The grantee shall provide, without charge, the most commonly provided cable television service offering by means of a single drop to each governmental office building, fire station, police station, and public school building that is passed by its cable. 
(Ord. No. 08-964, § 2, 4-21-08) 
Section 15. - Written notice. 
    All notices or demands required to be given under this franchise shall be deemed to be given upon the date actually received as evidenced by registered or certified mail receipt addressed as follows: 
If to the city: The Mayor of the City of Palmetto P.O. Box 1209 Palmetto, FL 34220-1209 If to Grantee: Time Warner Cable System Manager P.O. Box 25206 Bradenton, FL 34206    and Time Warner Cable 2600 McCormick Drive, Suite 255 Clearwater, Florida 34619  
Such addresses may be changed by either party upon notice to the other party given as provided in this section. 
(Ord. No. 08-964, § 2, 4-21-08) 
Section 16. - Breach of article. 
(a)  In the event that the grantee has in any manner violated, breached, or failed, refused or neglected to abide by any material provision hereof, or of any applicable federal, state or generally applicable local law, rule or regulation, then the city council may make a written demand on the grantee that it remedy such alleged violation which shall be described with reasonable particularity. The written demand on the grantee shall be sent by registered or certified United States mail. The grantee shall, within thirty (30) days after receipt of such notice, either: 
(1)  In a written response to the city, present facts and arguments refuting or excusing the allegations; or, 
(2)  Cure such breach; provided, however, that if such breach cannot be reasonably cured within such thirty (30) day period, grantee shall advise the city of the manner in which the breach will be cured setting forth the method and reasonable time schedule for commencing and accomplishing such cure and, upon receipt of the city's approval which shall not be unreasonably withheld, grantee shall diligently proceed with such cure in which event the time for such cure shall be automatically extended for the period of the cure. 
(b)  Upon the grantee's failure to meet the requirements for a cure or failure to provide a response which is acceptable to the city as set forth in subsection (a) above, the city shall conduct a public hearing on the matter. The city shall provide at least thirty (30) days' written notice to the grantee of the time and place of the public hearing by serving the grantee with the written notice in person or by depositing the notice in the United States mail, either registered or certified mail properly addressed to the grantee. At the time of the public hearing the grantee and the city may present evidence on the current status of the alleged breach of the chapter. 
(c)  If, at the public hearing, the city council determines that a material breach exists, the city council may adopt a resolution which may either revoke the grantee's franchise effective thirty (30) days following adoption of the resolution. The grantee shall have the right to appeal the action of the city council to a court of competent jurisdiction within thirty (30) days subsequent to the adoption of such resolution and if the grantee shall appeal such decision, the enforcement of such decision shall be delayed until such time as a final judgment has been entered or the city and grantee have otherwise agreed to a settlement. 
(Ord. No. 08-964, § 2, 4-21-08) 
Section 17. - Termination. 
(a)  Upon termination of the franchise or denial of renewal of the franchise, and after all appeals of such termination or denial of renewal, the city may direct the grantee to remove, at the sole cost and expense of the grantee, all or any portion of the cable system from all streets and other public property within the city, subject to the following: 
(1)  This provision shall not apply to buried cable which cannot be removed; 
(2)  In removing the cable system, or any part thereof, the grantee shall refill and compact, at its own expense, any excavation that shall be made by it and shall leave all streets and other property in as good condition as that prevailing prior to the removal of the cable system by the grantee and without affecting, altering or disturbing in any way any electric, telephone or other utility cables, wires or attachments; 
(3)  The city shall have the right to inspect and approve the condition of such streets and property after any such removal; 
(4)  The liability insurance and indemnity provisions of this article shall remain in full force and effect during the entire period of removal and associated repair of all streets and other property; 
(5)  The removal of the cable system shall be commenced within one hundred twenty (120) days after the date of the removal order by the city and shall be completed within a reasonable time thereafter, including the associated repair of all streets and other property; 
(6)  If, in the reasonable judgment of the city, the grantee fails to commence removal of the cable system, or such part thereof as designated by the city, within the said one hundred twenty-day period after the city's removal order, or if the grantee fails to substantially complete such removal, including all associated repair of streets and other property, within a reasonable time thereafter, then, the city shall remove the cable system property at the grantee's expense. 
(b)  As an alternative to the removal of the cable system and, if acceptable to the city and the grantee, the cable system, or any part thereof, may be transferred to a third party upon payment to grantee of: 
(1)  An equitable price if the franchise is revoked for cause; or, 
(2)  Fair market value in all other circumstances. 
(Ord. No. 08-964, § 2, 4-21-08) 
Section 18. - Financial condition. 
    The grantee shall throughout the term of this franchise and thereafter, for as long as the grantee is required to construct, operate and maintain the cable system pursuant to this article, maintain adequate financial resources to perform all obligations pursuant to this article. 
(Ord. No. 08-964, § 2, 4-21-08) 
Section 19. - No waiver. 
    No failure on the part of the city to exercise, and no delay in the exercising of any right hereunder shall operate as a waiver thereof, nor shall any single or partial exercise of any such right preclude any other right, all subject to the conditions and limitations established in this article. A waiver of any right or remedy by the city at any one time shall not affect the exercise of such right or remedy or any other right or other remedy by the city at any other time. In order for any waiver by the city to be effective, it must be in writing. The failure of the city to take any action in the event of a material breach by the grantee shall not be deemed or construed to constitute a waiver of or otherwise affect the right of the city to take any action permitted by this article at any other time in the event that such material breach has not been cured, or with respect to any other material breach by the grantee. 
(Ord. No. 08-964, § 2, 4-21-08) 
Section 20. - Severability. 
    If any paragraph, subparagraph, sentence, clause, phrase, or portion of this article is for any reason held invalid or unconstitutional by any court of competent jurisdiction, such portion shall be deemed a separate, distinct and independent provision and, except as otherwise expressly provided herein, such holding shall not affect the validity of the remaining portions thereof, all of which will remain in full force and effect, except as otherwise provided for herein. 
(Ord. No. 08-964, § 2, 4-21-08) 
Section 21. - Certain override provisions. 
(a)  Any right, power, protection, privilege, immunity or obligation which is provided, granted or imposed on the grantee under or by virtue of the cable act or the Constitution of the United States shall remain inviolate and shall be available to the grantee notwithstanding any contrary provision of this article. The acceptance by the grantee of this article shall not constitute or be deemed to be a waiver, release, or renunciation by the grantee of any right, power, protection, privilege, immunity, or obligation under the Constitution of the United States or any applicable law. 
(b)  This article shall be legally binding upon the city and the grantee and, as such, the provisions hereof cannot be amended, modified, or changed unilaterally by either party. 
(c)  All existing franchises and ordinances and parts of ordinances specifically relating to cable television matters which are in conflict herewith shall be and the same are hereby repealed or superseded. 
(d)  The franchise is subject to applicable law of the United States and the state. 
(Ord. No. 08-964, § 2, 4-21-08) 
Section 22. - Force Majeure. 
    If the performance of the respective obligations of city or grantee shall be prevented or interfered with by reason of an event of force majeure, then city or grantee, as the case may be, shall not be liable to the other or subject to any penalty or otherwise disadvantaged for its failure to perform such obligations hereunder. "Force majeure" as used herein shall mean fire, flood, epidemic, earthquake, explosion, accident, labor dispute or strike, an act of God or public enemy, riot or civil disturbance, war (whether declared or undeclared) or armed conflict, failure of common carrier or supplier, any state or federal law, governmental order or regulation or order of any court of competent jurisdiction, or any other thing or occurrence not within the control of either city or grantee. 
(Ord. No. 08-964, § 2, 4-21-08) 
Section 23. - Maps. 
    Grantee shall maintain on file with the city a true and accurate map or set of maps showing all cable system equipment installed and in place in streets and other public places; provided, however, upon written request of the grantee and to the extent allowed by applicable law, information of a proprietary nature, the dissemination of which will likely cause injury to the grantee's business, will not be made available for public inspection. 
(Ord. No. 08-964, § 2, 4-21-08) 
Section 24. - Attorney's fees. 
    If any legal action is filed by the city or the grantee for the purpose of enforcing the terms and provisions of this article or because of any alleged dispute, breach, default or misrepresentation in connection with any of the provisions of this article, the successful or prevailing party shall be entitled to recover reasonable attorney's fees and other costs incurred in that action or proceeding and any related appellate proceeding, in addition to any other relief to which the city or grantee may be entitled. 
(Ord. No. 08-964, § 2, 4-21-08) 
Section 25. - Adoption and effective date. 
    This article has been adopted as provided by law and by City Charter, Section 13, i.e., upon execution by the mayor or, if disapproval occurs, upon reconsideration by the city council and passing of the chapter by at least four (4) votes and shall become effective upon the date of execution and acceptance by the grantee; provided, however, that the grantee shall forfeit and shall be deemed to have forfeited and abandoned all rights and privileges conferred by this article and this article shall be null and void and of no force and effect unless grantee shall, prior to sixty (60) days subsequent to the date of adoption, accepts and approves the rights and privileges hereby conferred and the terms, conditions and restrictions hereby imposed. 
(Ord. No. 08-964, § 2, 4-21-08)

ARTICLE I. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 1.1. - Effect on pending or future prosecution. 
    The adoption of this code shall not affect nor prevent any pending or future prosecution of, or action to abate violations of the previous City of Palmetto Zoning Code occurring prior to the effective date of this code. 
Sec. 1.2. - Legislative authority. 
    This code is enacted pursuant to the provisions of Chapter 166, Florida Statutes and Chapter 63-1599, Laws of Florida, whereby authority is conferred on the Palmetto City Council for the purpose of promoting health, safety, morals and the general welfare of the citizens of Palmetto, to permit the city council to establish zoning classifications within the corporate limits of the City of Palmetto: 
(a)  To regulate and restrict the erection, construction, alteration and repair of buildings. 
(b)  To regulate and restrict the uses of land, buildings, and structures. 
(c)  To regulate and restrict the percentage of lot occupancy, size of yards and open spaces, and density of population. 
(d)  To preserve and facilitate transportation, water, sewerage, schools, and parks. 
(e)  To lessen congestion on highways and secure safety from fires and other dangers. 
Sec. 1.3. - Intent and purpose. 
    This code is adopted as one of the instruments of implementation of the public purposes and objectives of the Comprehensive Plan and is declared to be in conformance therewith. 
    It is the intent and purpose of the comprehensive plan and of this code, which aids in implementing the Comprehensive Plan, to promote the public health, safety, morals, convenience, comfort, amenities, prosperity, and general welfare of the citizens of Palmetto and to provide, among other matters, a wholesome, serviceable, and attractive community; to increase the safety and security of home life; to preserve and create a more favorable environment in which to rear children; to stabilize and enhance property and civic values; to develop meaningful and productive relationships between the private sector and city government; to provide for a more uniformly just land use pattern and tax assessment base; to aid in development and redevelopment of the city; to increase traffic safety and ease transportation problems; to provide more adequately for vehicular parking, parks, parkways, recreation, schools, public buildings and facilities, housing, job opportunities, light, air, water, sewerage, sanitation, and other public requirements; to lessen congestion, disorder, and danger which often occur in unplanned and unregulated suburban, urban, and rural development; to prevent overcrowding of land and undue concentration of population; to ensure compatibility of new development with existing development and open space; to conserve and enhance the manmade resources of the city; to provide for the appropriate utilization, conservation, and protection of natural resources in the city; and to provide more reasonable and serviceable means and methods of protecting and safeguarding the economic and social structure upon which the good of all depends. 
    To further the objective of the Comprehensive Plan and the intent and purpose of this code, the city is divided into districts of such number, shape, characteristics, area, common unity of purpose, adaptability, or use as will accomplish the objectives of the comprehensive plan and this code. 
Sec. 1.4. - Conflicting regulations. 
    When any provision of this code imposes more stringent or less stringent requirements, regulations, restrictions, or limitations than are imposed or required by the provisions of any other ordinance or law, the provisions which are more restrictive or which impose higher standards or requirements, shall govern. 
Sec. 1.5. - Area of coverage. 
    The regulations of this code shall apply throughout the corporate limits of the City of Palmetto. 
Sec. 1.6. - Code affects all lands, water, structures, uses and occupancies. 
    No building, structure, land or water shall hereafter be used or occupied, and no building, structure, or part thereof shall hereafter be erected, reconstructed, moved, located, or structurally altered except in conformity with the regulations set out generally herein and for the district in which it is located. 
Sec. 1.7. - Code affects height and bulk of buildings, population density, lot coverage, yards and other open spaces, off-street parking and loading, signs and other matters. 
    In particular, no building or structure or part thereof shall hereafter be erected, constructed, reconstructed, located, moved or structurally altered in any manner so as: 
(a)  To exceed the permitted height, bulk or floor area; 
(b)  To accommodate or house a greater number of families or other occupants, or to provide a greater number of dwelling units; 
(c)  To occupy a greater percentage or portion of lot area; 
(d)  To provide less lot area per dwelling unit or to occupy a smaller lot; 
(e)  To provide narrower or smaller yards or other open spaces, or spaces of separations between buildings or portions thereof; 
(f)  To provide less off-street parking or off-street loading space; 
(g)  To display more signs, signs of greater area, or signs of a different character; 
(h)  To permit the use of the building or structure for a use not permitted in the district in which it is located; 
than herein required or limited, or in any other manner contrary to any provisions of this code. 
Sec. 1.8. - Yard, area, open space, off-street parking and off-street loading space for one structure or use not to be used to meet requirements for another. 
    No part of a yard, area, open space, or off-street parking or off-street loading space required for one (1) structure or use shall be included as meeting requirements for another, except where specific provisions therefor are made in this code. 
Sec. 1.9. - Creation of new lots; reduction of lot or yard dimensions below minimum requirements prohibited. 
    No new lot shall be created after the effective date of this code except in conformity with the requirements of applicable regulations. No yard or lot existing at the time of passage of these regulations shall be reduced by private action in width, depth, or area below the minimum requirements set forth herein. 
Sec. 1.10. - Reduction of required off-street parking or off-street loading space prohibited. 
    No off-street parking or off-street loading space affected by these regulations which meets all or part of the requirements of this code for such space shall be reduced or eliminated by private action, except where approved alternative off-street parking or off-street loading space meeting such requirements is provided, unless no longer required by this code. 
Sec. 1.11. - Required accessory uses on same zoning lot with same zoning. 
    All required accessory uses for any principal use, including, but not limited to, off-street parking and loading areas, retention or drainage areas, and private sewer or water systems shall be located on the same zoning lot as the principal use and shall have the same zoning district designation as the principal use, except as permitted elsewhere in this code. 
Sec. 1.12. - Short title. 
    This code may be referred to and cited as the Palmetto Zoning Code.
